Permit Name: Employer Registration for Unemployment Insurance, Withholding, and Wage Reporting for Business Employer (NYS 100)
Permit Description:
Unemployment Insurance benefits provide temporary income for eligible workers who become unemployed through no fault of their own and have sufficient work and wages in covered employment. The NYS Unemployment Insurance Law requires employers to pay contributions on the wages paid to their employees. It also provides for the payment of unemployment insurance benefits to eligible claimants. The NYS Department of Labor's Unemployment Insurance Division determines if a business is liable for unemployment insurance as well as whether an unemployed worker qualifies for unemployment.

General Business employers are those who employ persons in any type of business except household (domestic), non-profit organizations, governmental entities, Indian tribes or agricultural. General business employers are liable on the first day of the calendar quarter they pay remuneration of $300 or more or the day they obtain any or all of the business of a liable employer.

You must complete an employer registration form for us to decide if you are liable under the New York State Unemployment Insurance law.

After registration, each liable employer is assigned an eight-digit employer registration number.  This registration number should be used on all correspondence, quarterly returns and payments sent to the NYS Department of Labor.
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Name: Permit to Operate Mobile Food Service Establishments and Foodcarts (DOH-3915)
Permit Description: Permit grants permission to operate a mobile food service establishment or foodcart, as required by NYS Public Health Law and State Sanitary Code
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Food Service and Processing

Permit Name: Permit to Operate Vending of Food and Beverages (DOH3915)
Permit Description: Permit grants permission to operate food and beverage vending machines as required by NYS Public Health Law and State Sanitary Code.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Food Service and Processing

Permit Name: Employer Registration for Unemployment Insurance, Withholding, and Wage Reporting for Household Employer (NYS 100)
Permit Description:
Unemployment Insurance benefits provide temporary income for eligible workers who become unemployed through no fault of their own and have sufficient work and wages in covered employment. The NYS Unemployment Insurance Law requires employers to pay contributions on the wages paid to their employees. It also provides for the payment of unemployment insurance benefits to eligible claimants. The NYS Department of Labor's Unemployment Insurance Division determines if a business is liable for unemployment insurance as well as whether an unemployed worker qualifies for unemployment.

General Household (Domestic) employers are those who employ persons in personal or domestic services in their home or homes within New York. General Household (Domestic) employers are liable on the first day of the calendar quarter they pay remuneration of $500 or more.

You must complete an employer registration form for us to decide if you are liable under the New York State Unemployment Insurance law.

After registration, each liable employer is assigned an eight-digit employer registration number.  This registration number should be used on all correspondence, quarterly returns and payments sent to the NYS Department of Labor.
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Description: A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The association listed below is for reference purposes only and does not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Construction,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Name: Employer Registration for Unemployment Insurance, Withholding, and Wage Reporting for Governmental Entities (NYS 100G)
Permit Description:
Unemployment benefits provide temporary income for eligible workers who become unemployed through no fault of their own and have sufficient work and wages in covered employment. The NYS Unemployment Insurance Law requires employers to pay contributions on the wages paid to their employees. It also provides for the payment of unemployment insurance benefits to eligible claimants. The NYS Department of Labor's Unemployment Insurance Division determines if a business is liable for unemployment insurance as well as whether an unemployed worker qualifies for unemployment. 

Governmental entities are defined as the State of New York, municipal corporations, and any other governmental subdivisions, and any instrumentality of one or more of the foregoing.  Governmental entities are liable as of the first day of the calendar quarter in which they pay remuneration to persons in covered employment.

After registration, each liable employer is assigned an eight-digit employer registration number. Use this registration number on all correspondence, quarterly returns and payments sent to the NYS Department of Labor.
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Name: Employer Registration for Unemployment Insurance, Withholding, and Wage Reporting for Non-profit Employment (NYS 100N)
Permit Description:
Unemployment benefits provide temporary income for eligible workers who become unemployed through no fault of their own and have sufficient work and wages in covered employment. The NYS Unemployment Insurance Law requires employers to pay contributions on the wages paid to their employees. It also provides for the payment of unemployment insurance benefits to eligible claimants. The NYS Department of Labor's Unemployment Insurance Division determines if a business is liable for unemployment insurance as well as whether an unemployed worker qualifies for unemployment. 

A non-profit organization is set up and operates exclusively for religious, charitable, scientific, literary or educational purposes.  Generally, this includes all organizations that qualify for exemption under Section 501(c) (3) of the Internal Revenue Code.  Employers of non-profit labor are liable on the first day of the calendar quarter they pay remuneration of $1,000 or more; or the first day of the calendar year they employ four or more persons on at least one day in each of 20 different weeks (during that year or the prior calendar year).  

After registration, each liable employer is assigned an eight-digit employer registration number. Use this registration number on all correspondence, quarterly returns and payments sent to the NYS Department of Labor.
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Description: A trust is a separate legal entity created under state law solely to transfer property from one party to another. The entity is separated by law from both the grantor and the beneficiaries.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Name: Employer Registration for Unemployment Insurance, Withholding, and Wage Reporting for Indian Tribes (NYS 100IT)
Permit Description:
Unemployment benefits provide temporary income for eligible workers who become unemployed through no fault of their own and have sufficient work and wages in covered employment. The NYS Unemployment Insurance Law requires employers to pay contributions on the wages paid to their employees. It also provides for the payment of unemployment insurance benefits to eligible claimants. The NYS Department of Labor's Unemployment Insurance Division determines if a business is liable for unemployment insurance as well as whether an unemployed worker qualifies for unemployment. 

The law defines an Indian tribe as any Indian tribe, subdivision, subsidiary or business enterprise wholly owned by such Indian tribe as defined in Section 3306(u) of FUTA.  All Indian tribes, as defined in Section 3306(u) of FUTA, are liable on the first day of the calendar quarter in which they pay wages to employees in covered employment, without regard to the amount of remuneration paid or the number of employees under NYS Unemployment Insurance Law.

After registration, each liable employer is assigned an eight-digit employer registration number. Use this registration number on all correspondence, quarterly returns and payments sent to the NYS Department of Labor.
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Name: Employer Registration for Unemployment Insurance, Withholding, and Wage Reporting for Agricultural Employment (NYS 100A)
Permit Description:
Unemployment Insurance benefits provide temporary income for eligible workers who become unemployed through no fault of their own and have sufficient work and wages in covered employment. The NYS Unemployment Insurance Law requires employers to pay contributions on the wages paid to their employees. It also provides for the payment of unemployment insurance benefits to eligible claimants. The NYS Department of Labor's Unemployment Insurance Division determines if a business is liable for unemployment insurance as well as whether an unemployed worker qualifies for unemployment. 

NYS Labor Law, Section 511, defines agricultural labor as services workers perform: on a farm, in the employ of any person, in connection with cultivating the soil or raising or harvesting any agricultural or horticultural commodity, including the raising, shearing, feeding, caring for, training and management of livestock, bees, poultry, fur-bearing animals and wildlife; in the employ of the owner, tenant or other operator of a farm in connection with the operation, management, conservation, improvement, or maintenance of the farm and its tools and equipment, or in salvaging timber or clearing land of brush and other debris left by a hurricane, if the major part of such service is performed on a farm; or in handling, planting, drying, packing, packaging, processing, freezing, grading, storing any agricultural or horticultural commodity (but not commercial canning or freezing), or delivering to storage or to market or to a carrier for transportation to market, any agricultural or horticultural commodity but only if such service is performed in the employ of an operator of a farm, and as an incident to farming operations; or in the case of fruits and vegetables, as an incident to the preparation of such fruits or vegetables for market; or before delivery to a terminal market for distribution for consumption. 

Services are NOT considered agricultural employment if they are performed in connection with: commercial canning, commercial freezing, any agricultural or horticultural commodity after its delivery to a terminal market for distribution for consumption. Also, services NOT considered agricultural employment, even when located on a farm, if done in connection with: converting a primary product to a secondary derivative, such as grapes to wine or a retail operation. 

The NYS Unemployment Law definition of a farm includes: stock farm, crop farm, dairy farm, horse farm (includes breeding, raising, training, boarding), poultry farm, vineyard, seed farm, game farm, peat farm, clam, oyster or other shellfish beds, raising of fur-bearing animals, fruit and truck farms, plantations, nurseries, greenhouses, other similar structures, used primarily to raise agricultural or horticultural commodities, and orchards.

Employers of agricultural labor are liable the first day of the calendar year in which they employ 10 or more workers in agricultural labor on at least one day in each of 20 different weeks (during that year or the prior year); or the first day of the calendar quarter in which they pay cash remuneration of $20,000 or more to workers they employ in agricultural labor; or the first day of the calendar quarter in which they pay any remuneration to workers they employ in agricultural labor, if they are liable under FUTA with respect to farm workers. 

You must complete an employer registration form for us to decide if you are liable under the New York State Unemployment Insurance law.

After registration, each liable employer is assigned an eight-digit employer registration number. This registration number should be used on all correspondence, quarterly returns and payments sent to the NYS Department of Labor.
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Name: Business Corporation (Domestic Professional Service) Certificate of Incorporation (DOS-1523-f)
Permit Description:
A professional service corporation may be formed under Business Corporation Law Article 15 by one or more individuals authorized by law to render a professional service in New York State. Profession, as defined in Business Corporation Law Section 1501(b), includes any practice as an attorney and counsellor-at-law, as a licensed physician, or those professions designated in Title 8 of the NYS Education Law. Filing a Certificate of Incorporation pursuant to Business Corporation Law Section 1503, forms a professional service corporation. In conjunction with this responsibility, the Secretary of State serves as statutory agent for professional service corporations against whom process may be served.

STEPS IN FILING A CERTIFICATE OF INCORPORATION: 

The NYS Department of State has a Certificate of Incorporation form for a professional service corporation available on its website. You may also draft your own form pursuant to Section 1503 of the NYS Business Corporation Law, or purchase a form from a legal stationery store in New York.

A Certificate of Good Standing from the appropriate Appellate Division or a Certificate of Authority (Form PLS709) from the NYS Education Department, Division of Professional Licensing Services, Corporations Unit, 89 Washington Avenue, 2nd Floor, Albany, NY 12234, (518) 474-3817, certifying that each of the proposed shareholders, officers and directors is authorized by law to practice a profession which the corporation is being formed to practice, must be submitted to the Department of State with the Certificate of Incorporation. 

Availability of Name: (optional) In order to assure that the proposed name of the corporation is not already in use by an existing corporation, limited liability company or limited partnership you may request a name search. The request must be in writing to the Department of State. The search fee for each name submitted is $5.00. 

Reservation of Name: (optional) If the name is available, you may wish to reserve it while finalizing your business plans. To reserve the name for 60 days, file an "Application for Reservation of Name.” The Department of State will send you a Certificate of Reservation. Attach this Certificate of Reservation to your Certificate of Incorporation when filing. The fee for filing an Application for Reservation of Name is $20.00.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
Applicable Laws:  
 
The NYS Arts and Cultural Affairs Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations linked below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description:
Industrial Homework, or wage labor performed in the home, is any work done in your home on an article which belongs to an employer or with materials supplied by the employer, and which you return to him or deliver, mail, or ship to others.  This includes articles that you prepare, alter, repair, finish, assemble, handle and insert, process, or collate.  Most industrial homeworkers work for an employer who has a factory-type setting to manufacture its product.  No articles of food, dolls or doll clothes, and stuffed animals or toys can be manufactured for a factory in a home.  Industrial Homework is also known as Work-at-Home entities.  An industrial homeworker is considered an employee and not an independent contractor. 
 
There are many work-at-home schemes, that don't really offer work in the home, but sell ideas for setting up home businesses.  Typical types of work-at-home schemes are home assembly of crafts or articles of clothing or fabrics, billing services including medical, and clerical services.  Other schemes require you to raise animals.  Many schemes require you to produce items, such as sewing baby booties or aprons, making Christmas wreaths or toys, or fabricating other specialty products.  You are not told that you will have to sell these items yourself and that there is generally little or no market for them.  The promoters of such schemes are only interested in selling you something, that is, the idea, animals, or materials you may need to start your business.  To prevent falling victim to a work-at-home scheme make sure the business has a permit or has applied for a permit with the NYS Department of Labor to distribute homework.  Ask for, in writing, from the homework company, the steps required to perform the job, how you will get paid either by salary or by commission, who pays this salary, and what is your total cost.  The Federal Trade Commission has published a brochure called Facts for Consumers:  Work At Home Schemes.  To receive a free copy, visit the link below.  This brochure suggests some precautions for potential investors and some steps investors can take if they believe they are involved with a work-at-home scheme that is not legitimate. 
 
Only employers who hold a valid permit issued through the NYS Department of Labor can distribute homework and employ industrial homeworkers.  The industrial homeworker must also obtain, through the employer, a homeworker certificate, to perform homework services.  A person at least 16 years of age can work as a homeworker.  If the person is between the ages of 16 and 18 years, an Employment Certificate is also required.  In some industries, such as the glove and artificial flower industries, there are additional restrictions.  Homes in which industrial homework is done may be inspected by representatives of the NYS Department of Labor.  The NYS Department of Labor does not allow industrial homework done in any home found unsanitary or with an infectious or communicable disease.  Employers who violate the Industrial Homework Law may be assessed a civil penalty of up to $2,500 for each violation.  A firm that holds a current Industrial Homework Permit to Distribute issued by the NYS Department of Labor can issue Homeworker Certificates to their workers for a fee of $25.00 per employee working at home. 
 
To receive an application or for detailed information about industrial homework regulations contact the NYS Department of Labor, Division of Labor Standards, Apparel Industry Task Force or visit their website. 
 
The NYS General Business Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Manufacturing

Permit Description:
Translators of language transfer ideas and concepts expressed in written form from one language to another.  Translators are skilled in writing, editing, research, and terminology.  The State of New York does not have licensing or certification requirements for translators at this time.  New York does have certain tax requirements for translation services.  Certified translations consist of a statement signed by the translator and notarized by a Notary Public attesting that the translator believes the translation is accurate and complete.  The American Translators Association (ATA) offers a booklet entitled, 'Getting Started:  A Newcomer's Guide to Translation and Interpretation.'  The ATA also offers an accreditation program consisting of written examinations in more than 20 language pairs to verify that individual translators meet professional standards.  For detailed information about the ATA's services and accreditation program contact the American Translators Association or visit their website.
 
The New York Circle of Translators (NYCT) is a chapter of the American Translators Association.  Its members are independent translators and interpreters as well as companies and organizations.  NYCT organizes continuing education workshops and seminars for its members as well as promotes its members' professional services through its website.  For more information contact the New York Circle of Translators. 
 
Interpreters of language use the spoken word to transfer their meaning between languages.  Interpreters must be fluent in both languages and possess excellent memory, listening, concentration, and analytical skills.  The interpreter must convey both the meaning and tone of the original statement clearly and accurately.  There are five types of interpreting fields: legal, medical, community, and conference as well as sign language. 

Court interpreters also known as judiciary or legal interpreters work in legal settings.  The U.S. Court Interpreters Act, 28 U.S.C. Section 1827, requires the Office of the United States Courts' Administrative Office to prescribe, determine, and certify the qualifications of persons who serve as certified interpreters in federal court proceedings.   The Administrative Office classifies three categories of interpreters:  certified interpreter, professionally qualified interpreters, and language-skilled interpreters.  Certified interpreter must pass a certification examination.  To date, Spanish, Navajo and Haitian-Creole language interpreters must pass a battery of exams to become certify interpreters.  One way to classify as a professionally qualified interpreter, in languages other than Spanish, Navajo, and Haitian-Creole, is to have had previous employment as a conference interpreter with any U.S. agency, the United Nations, or a similar entity.  To qualify as a language-skilled interpreter one must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the court their ability to effectively interpret the foreign language into English and vice-versa. 

New York tests and approves court interpreters but does not certify for federal proceedings.  For information on court interpreter testing for New York, contact Court Interpreting Services or visit their website.
 
The National Association of Judiciary Interpreters and Translators (NAJIT) is a professional association.  The association's mission is to promote quality interpretation and translation services in the judicial system.  For information contact NAJIT, or visit their website.
 
Medical interpreters trained in interpretation skills and medical terminology; facilitate understanding in communication between people speaking different languages in health care settings.  At this time, there are no New York certification requirements for medical interpreters.  The National Council on Interpreting in Health Care is a multidisciplinary organization whose goal is to establish a framework that promotes culturally competent health care interpreting, including standa
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Name: Business Corporation (Foreign Professional Service) Application for Authority (DOS-1627-f-a)
Permit Description:
A foreign professional service corporation may be authorized to do business in New York State pursuant to Business Corporation Law Article 15-A (Foreign Professional Service Corporations). A foreign professional service corporation is a professional service corporation organized under the laws of a state or territory of the United States, other than New York. Profession includes any practice as an attorney and counsellor-at-law, licensed physician, or any of the professions designated in Title 8 of the NYS Education Law. To see a listing of designated professions, visit the NYS Education Department's website. All of the shareholders, directors and officers of a foreign professional service corporation must be authorized and licensed to practice the profession for which such corporation is licensed to do business, except that all of the shareholders, directors, and officers of a foreign professional service corporation which provides health services in New York must be licensed in New York State. A foreign professional service corporation may apply for authority to do business in New York State by submitting an Application for Authority to the Department of State for filing pursuant to Business Corporation Law section 1530. In conjunction with this responsibility, the Secretary of State serves as statutory agent for foreign professional service corporations against whom process may be served. 

STEPS IN FILING AN APPLICATION FOR AUTHORITY:

The NYS Department of State has an Application for Authority form available on its website. You may also draft your own form pursuant to Section 1530 of the NYS Business Corporation Law, or purchase a form from a legal stationery store in New York. 

Availability of Name: (optional) In order to assure that the name of the corporation is not already in use by an existing corporation, limited liability company or limited partnership you may request a name search. The request must be in writing to the Department of State. The search fee for each name submitted is $5.00. 

Reservation of Name: (optional) If the name is available, you may wish to reserve it while finalizing your business plans. To reserve the name for 60 days, file an "Application for Reservation of Name.” The Department of State will send you a Certificate of Reservation. Attach this Certificate of Reservation to your Application for Authority when filing. The fee for filing the Application for Reservation of Name is $20.00. 

A Certificate of Existence, Certificate of Good Standing or Certificate of Status from the official who files and maintains corporate records in the jurisdiction of the corporation must be submitted to the Department of State with the Application for Authority. 

A Certificate of "Good Standing" from the appropriate Appellate Division or a Certificate of Authority (Form PLS709) from the NYS Education Department, Division of Professional Licensing Services, Corporation Unit, 89 Washington Avenue, 2nd Floor, NY 12234, (518) 474-3817, must be submitted to the Department of State with the Application for Authority. 

If a foreign professional service corporation has been conducting business in New York State prior to filing its Application for Authority, it must obtain the consent of the NYS Tax Commission. To obtain the consent, call the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance at (518) 485-2639.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
A Group Child Care service is any program providing child care to 3 or more children under of 6 years of age for 5 or more hours per week, for more than 30 days in a 12-month period, primarily operating in a non-residential space. 

This information encompasses health and safety related aspects of the regulatory requirements of a group child care permit. Users should be aware that reading the documents included here will be necessary to properly understand the various provisions of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene regulations. For
those programs that have funding from the NYC Department of Education and the Administration of Children Services, there may be additional requirements.

The Group Child Care permit, once granted, is issued for a two-year period. The permit is non-transferable. A permit will contain:
-Permit Number
-Issue Date
-Expiration Date
-Name of Program
-Permit Capacity
-Floors and Classrooms
-Ages of Children
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description: To view applicable laws for gun shows, please see the NYS General Business Law, Article 39-DD,  Sales of Firearms, Rifles, or Shotguns at Gun Shows and NYS General Business Law, Article 39-DDD, Private Sale or Disposal of Firearms, Rifles and Shotguns.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Recreation,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Name: Design Professional Service Corporation Certificate of Incorporation
Permit Description:
A design professional service corporation is a profession service corporation organized under NYS Business Corporation Law, Article 15 by specified design professionals that are licensed and registered through Title 8 of the NYS Education Law to practice professional engineering, architecture, landscape architecture, land surveying, or geology or practicing any combination of such professions. Registration allows design firms the flexibility of offering an ownership interest in the corporation to non-licensees via the design professional service corporation. Shareholders may include employees of the corporation not licensed as design professionals or employee stock ownership plans (ESOPs), provided that greater than 75 percent of the voting shares of the corporation shall be owned by design professionals and greater than 75 percent of the directors and officers shall be design professionals. The president, chairperson of the board, chief executive officer and the single largest shareholder also must be design professionals. The name of a design professional service corporation must end with the words "Design Professional Corporation" or the abbreviation “D.P.C.” The Certificate of Incorporation of a design professional service corporation is filed with the New York Secretary of State. In conjunction with this responsibility, the Secretary of State serves as statutory agent for design professional service corporations against whom process may be served.

STEPS IN FILING A CERTIFICATE OF INCORPORATION: 

You must draft your own Certificate of Incorporation pursuant to Section 1503 of the NYS Business Corporation Law.

A Certificate of Authority (Form PLS709) under seal from the NYS Education Department, Division of Professional Licensing Services, Corporations Unit, 89 Washington Avenue, 2nd Floor, Albany, NY 12234 (518) 474-3817 extension 400, must be submitted with the Certificate of Incorporation. 

Availability of Name: (optional) In order to assure that the proposed name of the corporation is not already in use by an existing corporation, limited liability company or limited partnership, you may request a name search. The request must be in writing to the Department of State. The search fee for each name submitted is $5.00. 

Reservation of Name: (optional) If the name is available, you may reserve it while finalizing your business plans. To reserve the name for 60 days, file an "Application for Reservation of Name." The Department of State will send you a Certificate of Reservation. Attach the Certificate of Reservation to your Certificate of Incorporation when filing. The fee for reservation of name is $20.00.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
A religious corporation is a corporation created for religious purposes pursuant to the Religious Corporations Law.

For tax exemption information, contact the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance, Corporation Tax Bureau, W.A. Harriman State Campus, Albany, NY 12227, (518) 485-2889 and the United States Internal Revenue Service at (877) 829-5500.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
A not-for-profit corporation may be formed under the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law as a “charitable corporation” or a “non-charitable corporation” unless it may be formed under any other corporate law of New York State (See Not-for-Profit Corporation Law section 201). A not-for-profit corporation may not be formed for pecuniary profit or financial gain. The Department of State's Division of Corporations is responsible for filing and maintaining certificates filed by the Department of State for not-for-profit corporations pursuant to the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. In conjunction with this responsibility, the Secretary of State serves as statutory agent for not-for-profit corporations against whom process may be served.

Optional Services: 

Availability of Name: In order to determine whether the proposed name of the corporation is available (distinguishable from the names of all existing or authorized corporations, limited liability companies and limited partnerships) you may request a name availability search. The request must be in writing to the Department of State. The search fee for each name submitted is $5.00. 

Reservation of Name: (optional) You may reserve the proposed name of your corporation while finalizing your plans. To reserve the name for 60 days, file an "Application for Reservation of Name" with the Department of State. The fee for reserving a name is $10.00. When submitting your Application for Authority to the Department of State for filing you must include the Certificate of Reservation issued by the Department of State.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description: There are federal requirements for transporting flammable liquids or gases, contact the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration for further information.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail,Licenses and Permits, Services,Licenses and Permits, Transportation and Pubic Utilities

Permit Description:
A foreign not-for-profit corporation is a corporation organized under the laws of a jurisdiction other than New York State, which if formed under the laws of this state, would be within the definition of the term “corporation” as defined in Not-for-Profit Corporation Law section 102(a)(5). A foreign not-for-profit corporation may apply for authority to conduct its activities in the State of New York by submitting an Application for Authority pursuant to Section 1304 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law to the Department of State. In conjunction with this responsibility, the Secretary of State serves as statutory agent for not-for-profit corporations against whom service of process may be served. 

Sections 301 and 404 of the NYS Not-for-Profit Corporation Law include provisions relating to restrictions on the use of certain words and phrases in the name of the corporation. The name of the corporation may not include a word or phrase restricted by the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law or another statute unless the Application for Authority complies with the restriction. Certain activities and purposes also require the consent or approval from another state agency prior to filing. 

Section 404 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law also requires corporations formed for certain purposes to include the written consent or approval of the specified state agency when submitting their Application for Authority to the Department of State for filing. 

A Certificate of Existence, Certificate of Good Standing or Certificate of Status from the official who files and maintains corporation records in the jurisdiction of the corporation must be submitted with the Application for Authority. In most U.S. states this official is the state’s Secretary of State. 

The completed application, together with the filing fee of $135, should be forwarded to the NYS Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231. However, if the foreign corporation has been conducting activities in New York State prior to filing its Application for Authority, it must obtain the consent of the State Tax Commission (§1304 (a)(8), Not-for-Profit Corporation Law). To request consent, call the New York State Tax Commission at (518) 485-2639. The completed Application for Authority, together with the required consent attached, and the statutory filing fee of $135 should be forwarded to the New York Department of State at the address indicated above. 

Foreign corporations that do not require the consent of the NYS Tax Commission should send their Application for Authority, together with the filing fee directly to the NYS Department of State, Division of Corporations. 

Optional Services: 

Availability of Name: In order to determine whether the proposed name of the corporation is available (distinguishable from the names of all existing or authorized corporations, limited liability companies and limited partnerships) you may request a name availability search. The request must be in writing to the Department of State. The search fee for each name submitted is $5.00. 

Reservation of Name: (optional) You may reserve the proposed name of your corporation while finalizing your plans. To reserve the name for 60 days, file an "Application for Reservation of Name" with the Department of State. The fee for reserving a name is $10.00. When submitting your Application for Authority to the Department of State for filing you must include the Certificate of Reservation issued by the Department of State.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
Two or more people may join together in a general partnership to carry on a trade or business for profit. Each general partner is personally liable for the obligations of the business, including debts. Each general partner includes their share of the business income on their personal tax return. The partnership agreement stipulates a designated period of time for the life span of the business or until a dissolution event occurs.

Application Information:

A partnership must complete, notarize, and file an “assumed name certificate” also known as a DBA with the county clerk in each county in which business is conducted or transacted. Many counties have sample forms or you may purchase a form from a legal stationery store in New York. You may wish to have an attorney assist you in the preparation of this or any other legal document.

Fees:

The basic filing fee is $25 in all counties except for the five counties of New York City where the fee is $100. The fee for a certified copy is $4.00/per copy or $10.00/per copy in New York City.
Processing Information:

The county clerk keeps the original form on file.

Additional Requirements/ Information:

Provide certified copies to banks where the business has bank accounts as well as for display at the business premises. NOTE: Some business licenses may require a certified copy. 

Certificates of Conversion

A domestic partnership or limited partnership may be converted into a limited liability company by filing a Certificate of Conversion pursuant to Section 1006 of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law. 
Mail the completed Certificate of Conversion (see link below), together with the statutory fee of $200, to the New York Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231.

Online Filing:

Contact the County Clerk's Office in the County where your business will be located to find out about online filing availability.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
The simplest form of a business structure owned by one individual is a sole proprietorship. All business responsibilities and decisions are those of the single owner. The owner of a sole proprietorship has unlimited liability for the business. Income and expenses of the business are included on the owner's own tax return. The retirement or death of the sole proprietor ends the life span of the business. 

Application Information:

To operate as a sole proprietorship using an assumed name, you must complete, notarize, and file an "assumed name certificate" also known as a DBA with the county clerk where the business is conducted or transacted. Purchase this form from a legal stationery store in New York. You may wish to have an attorney assist you in the preparation of this or any other legal document. 

Fees:

The basic filing fee is $25 in all counties except for the five counties of New York City where the fee is $100. The fee for a certified copy is $4.00/per copy and $10.00/per copy in New York City. 

Processing Information:

The county clerk keeps the original form on file. 

Additional Requirements/ Information:

You may require certified copies for banks where the business has bank accounts as well as for display at the business premises. NOTE: Some business licenses may require a certified copy. 

Online Filing:

Contact the County Clerk's Office in the County where your business will be located to find out about online filing availability.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description: An estate is a separate legal entity created under state law solely to transfer property from one party to another. The entity is separated by law from both the grantor and the beneficiaries.

Permit Description: The Federal Trade Commission prohibits certain claims that any body wrapping treatment causes consumers to lose inches from their body measurements unless the claim is both true and substantiated by scientific evidence.  It requires a disclosure that the reduction is temporary and that the treatment does not cause weight loss; unless the treatment has competent and reliable scientific evidence to the contrary which must accompany any inch-loss claims.  The FTC recommends advertisements should state that treatments may be dangerous to persons suffering from certain physical conditions, and that the person should consult a doctor before using the treatments.  Establishments should provide these warnings in brochures given to clients and should post these warnings in a prominent place in the reception area of the establishment.

Permit Name: Lead Base Paint Activities (Lead Abatement Contractors)
Permit Description:
Lead is a highly toxic metal that was used for many years in products found in and around homes built before 1978.  Lead may cause a range of health effects. 
 
New York does not have an authorized lead program.  The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) certifies lead service providers in states that do not operate their own program.  The EPA's program requires training, certification, and adherence to specific work practice standards when conducting lead base paint activities that include inspection, risk assessment, and abatement. 
 
The EPA requires all lead abatement contractors be certified by passing a U.S. EPA approved training program for lead abatement. 
 
For further information pertaining to lead abatement, contact the  EPA Headquarters Lead Program, Office of Pollution Prevention & Toxics or visit their website.   
 
You may also contact the National Lead Information Center (NLIC) through the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Construction,Licenses and Permits, Retail,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS:

The Federal Trade Commission's Mail or Telephone Order Merchandise Trade Regulation Rule (Part 435) applies to most goods a customer orders from the seller by mail, telephone, fax or the internet.  The Rule requires that when you advertise merchandise, you must have a reasonable basis for stating or implying that you can ship within a certain time.  If you make no shipment statement, you must have a reasonable basis for believing that you can ship within 30 days.  It is commonly known as the 30-day rule.  The booklet  A Business Guide to the Federal Trade Commission's Mail or Telephone Order Merchandise Rule explains the Rule's requirements. For more information contact the FTC.

Permit Description:
New York state does not license travel agents or travel agencies, but NYS General Business Law, Article 10-A, Truth in Travel Act sets forth regulations that must be followed.  To view applicable laws, visit the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.

An agent, by definition, is one whom a principal officially appoints. Many different principals may appoint a travel agent such as airlines, cruise lines, hotels, and other suppliers of travel related services. Usually, there are two ways in which an agent obtains these appointments. First, a supplier may appoint them directly, as with hotels, car rental companies, and tour operators. In this scenario, the agent must contact each supplier directly to work out an agreement how they will make bookings and how commissions will be awarded.

The second option is for agents to be appointed by a coordinating body accepted by the various suppliers. This is a common practice among the airlines. The two coordinating bodies for the airlines are the Airlines Reporting Corporation (ARC) and the International Airlines Travel Agency Network (IATAN).  Their links are below.  (Note: If you plan to purchase an existing agency, keep in mind that the agency's appointments do not automatically transfer to the new owner.)

To get an Airlines Reporting Corporation (ARC) appointment, you must have a bond or letter of credit. To access Circular 570 to obtain a list of bonding companies and additional information see the link below. 

Letters of credit can be obtained from most federally insured banks.  Some banks may be unfamiliar with the Airlines Reporting Corporation Letter of Credit requirements.  You can refer them to Section 30.8 of the Airlines Reporting Corporation's Industry Agent Handbook.

Reference Books:

Guide to Starting and Operating a Successful Travel Agency by Laurence Stevens

How to Open Your Own Travel Agency by Douglas Thompson

Permit Description:
Local government entities license electrical contractors.  Separate or additional permits may be required to perform the electrical work.   
 
Inspections for electrical work performed must be made by an approved electrical inspection agency.  The electrical inspection agencies are all private companies hired by an electrician or homeowner that performs electrical inspections.  An electrician cannot perform electrical inspections; it has to go through an electrical inspection agency. 
 
The National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) is an independent, nonprofit organization whose mission is to reduce the worldwide burden of fire and other hazards on the quality of life.  It provides and advocates scientifically based consensus codes and standards, research, training, and education.  The NFPA developed and updates the National Electrical Code (NEC).  Considered the blueprint for electrical safety throughout the world, the NEC focuses on the proper installation of electrical systems and equipment.  For more information contact their office or visit their website. To order a copy of the National Electrical Code book go to the link below. 
 
NYC REQUIREMENTS: 
 
In New York City, electricians are required to be licensed by the Department of Buildings.  Only licensed electricians or their employees may perform electrical work.  An electrical permit is also required for work performed; including all handling of electrical wires.  The NYC Department of Buildings, Bureau of Electrical Control issues electrical permits.  For information on the requirements, applications and scheduled test dates, please contact the NYC Department of Buildings, Bureau of Electrical Control or visit their website.

Permit Description:
Copyrights provide protection to authors of original works including literary works; dramatic works; musical works; pantomimes and choreographic works; pictorial, graphic and sculptural works; motion pictures and other audiovisual works; sound recordings; and architectural works.  Copyrights do not protect facts, ideas, titles, names, short phrases, slogans, systems, or methods of operation.   Copyright protection starts the moment the original work is created and fixed in a tangible form so that it is perceptible either directly or with the aid of a machine or device.  This protection is available to both published and unpublished works.  A copyright generally gives the owner of the copyright the exclusive right to do and to authorize others to do the following:  reproduce the work; prepare derivative works based upon the work; distribute copies or phonorecords of the work; perform and/or display the work publicly; and in the case of sound recordings, perform the work publicly by means of a digital audio transmission. 
 
Registration of the original work is recommended with the U.S. Copyright Office but is not a requirement.  Registration establishes a public record; gives prima facie evidence in a court of law if registered within five years of publication; may help with statutory damages and attorney's fee in court actions; and gives protection with the U.S. Customs Service against importation of infringing copies.  A copyright registration is effective on the date the U.S. Copyright Office receives all the required elements.  The U.S. Copyright Office recommends submitting the registration by registered or certified mail and to request a return receipt.  Normal processing time takes approximately five to six months.   
 
To obtain information on copyright law, current fees, registration requirements and forms, circulars, etc., contact the Library of Congress, Copyright Office or go to their website.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Name: Domestic Relations Law (Getting Married in New York State)
Permit Description:
New York State Domestic Relations Law, Article 3, Section 13 requires a marriage license for couples who intend to marry in New York State.  The couple must apply in person to any town or city clerk in the state.  A representative cannot apply for the license on behalf of the bride or groom.  The marriage ceremony may not take place within twenty-four hours from the time the license was issued unless a judicial waiver is obtained.  A marriage license is valid for 60 days after it is issued.  Marriage licenses issued by a town or city clerk in New York State outside of New York City cost $40.  Marriage licenses issued by the city clerk of the City of New York cost $35.  A New York State marriage license may be used in New York State only.  If the marriage ceremony takes place outside of the State of New York, the marriage license will not be filed in New York State.   

Marriage ceremonies conducted in New York must be performed by an individual specified in Section 11 of the NYS Domestic Relations Law.   Persons performing ceremonies within the City of New York must be registered with the City Clerk's office ((212) 669-2400).  The officiate does not have to be a resident of New York State.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Miscellaneous

Permit Description:
The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation has a dry cleaner program initiated through 6 NYCRR Part 232 Perchloroethylene Dry Cleaning Facilities.  This air pollution control regulation is applicable to all dry cleaning facilities in the state which use perchloroethylene solvent (Perc).  Part 232, which took effect on May 15, 1997, requires the use of several regulatory strategies to reduce and contain the release of perchloroethylene and to minimize exposure to the public. 
 
Each Perc dry cleaning facility is required to be inspected at least once each calendar year by an independent DEC-approved Registered Compliance Inspector.  Facility inspection reports are reviewed by regional DEC engineering staff for compliance and enforcement purposes.  Part 232 provides for public access to these reports. 
 
Perc dry cleaners are also required to post a NYSDEC informational sign in a place where it can be read by the public.  This posting notice informs readers that the shop uses Perc, lists where the public may report odors and other problems, and where they may get additional information about the potential health effects of Perc exposure.  
 
Most Perc dry cleaners must obtain a NYS Air Facility Registration Certificate.   Large facilities must get a State or Title V Facility Permit.   
 
All major facilities must obtain a Title V permit.  Major facilities are defined as having the potential to emit above the thresholds specified in Part 201.  For Hazardous Air Pollutants (HAPs), like Perc, the threshold is 10 tons per year of a single HAP.  If more than one HAP is emitted, the threshold is 25 tons per year total HAPs.  For volatile organic compounds (VOCs), like petroleum solvents, the threshold is dependent on the attainment status of the area in which the dry-cleaner is located.  Downstate the major facility threshold for VOCs is 25 tons per year, and upstate the threshold is 50 tons per year.  
 
New dry cleaning facilities with emissions less than the Title V major source thresholds, but greater than or equal to 50 percent of the major source thresholds, are required to apply for a state facility permit.  For Perc dry-cleaners, this would be between 5 and 10 tons per year.  Perc dry cleaners below 50 percent of the Title V major source thresholds (i.e., below 5 tons per year), have been required to obtain DEC registrations and answer specific questions regarding their facility with their registration application.  
 
Exempt dry-cleaning solvents:  CO2 dry-cleaning machines and wet-cleaning machines are currently exempted from the requirement to obtain an air facility permit or registration certificate. 
 
Machine removal:  Part 232.15(b) requires dry cleaners removing Perc dry cleaning machines to notify the appropriate DEC Regional Air Pollution Control Engineer that the machine has been removed within 30 days by certified mail, return receipt requested. 
 
Ownership transfer:  Dry cleaners transferring ownership of a facility must file an Application for Permit Transfer form within 30 days of the change of ownership at the appropriate DEC Regional Air Program office.  New Owners-Managers and Operators must be certified prior to taking over the facility. 
 
New facility, new machine, new solvents:  In all cases dry cleaners are required to apply for the permit or registration certificate prior to installing a new facility, new machine, or changing solvents. 
 
For additional information, please contact the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation or at their website.

Permit Description:
Effective November 1, 2004, New York enacted standards for immigration assistance service consultants.  Immigration assistance service consultants must post a surety bond of at least $50,000; must provide clients with a plain-language contract in both English and their native language including the name, address and telephone number of the immigration assistance provider, the services provided and the fees charged; must permit the client to cancel contracts within three business days and provide a refund upon such cancellation; must provide clients with copies of all documents submitted to the government on their behalf; must post signs and disclose in their advertising and contracts stating that the consultant is not an attorney and cannot provide legal services, and must retain all documents and forms for three years and provide them to the client on demand and without a fee.  The new law will not affect attorneys or individuals and organizations accredited by the Federal Board of Immigration Appeals. 
 
The Federal Board of Immigration Appeals recognizes organizations and/or accredits representatives to act/speak for an alien in immigrations proceedings.  For information, contact the U.S. Department of Justice, Board of Immigration Appeals or visit their website.

Permit Description:
All state court papers should be served in accordance with the law of the state having original jurisdiction (where the complaint is filed).  New York State General Business Law outlines requirements for process servers in New York.  There are Federal laws which prohibit interference with the service of process. Title 18 U.S.C. Section 1501, provides in part that if anyone knowingly and willingly obstructs, resists or opposes any officer of the United States, or other person duly authorized, in serving, or attempting to serve or execute, any legal or judicial writ or process of any court of the United States they shall, except as otherwise provided by law, be fined not more than $300 or imprisoned not more than one year, or both. 
 
New York City requires that all persons who serve process within the 5 boroughs (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Bronx, Staten Island, Queens) be licensed through the NYC Department of Consumer Affairs.  A person or business must have a Process Server Organization license if engaged in hiring persons to act as process servers.  A Process Server Individual license is required if you serve personally or by substituted service, five (5) or more processes in any one-year period.  For more information, contact the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs Licensing Center or visit their website.

Permit Description:
Some publishing activities may require you to register as a sales tax vendor with the NYS Tax Department. See Publication 750, A Guide to Sales Tax in New York State, and Tax Bulletin TB-ST-620, Newspapers, Periodicals, and Shopping Papers, through the links below for more information. 

A publisher should apply for its own International Standard Book Number (ISBN) publisher prefix and plan to identify and circulate its books properly in the industry supply chain.  An ISBN is a unique, numerical commercial book identifier used to establish and identify one title or edition of a title from one specific publisher and is unique to that edition, allowing for more efficient marketing of products by booksellers, libraries, universities, wholesalers and distributors of a book and book-like products published internationally. The 10-digits format assigned before 2007 and 13-digit format assigned after 2007 was developed by the International Organization for Standardization and published as an international standard.  It is based upon the 9-digit Standard Book Numbering (SBN) code.  Every ISBN consists of a 10-digit or 13-digit number and whenever it is printed, it is preceded by the letters ISBN.  The 10-digit or 13-digit number is divided into four parts of variable length, each part separated by a hyphen.  The four parts of an ISBN are:  Group or country identifier which identifies a national or geographic grouping of publishers; Publisher identifier which identifies a particular publisher within a group; Title identifier which identifies a particular title or edition of a title; and the Check digit is the single digit at the end of the ISBN which validates the ISBN. 
 
In the United States, the U.S. ISBN Agency is responsible for the assignment of the ISBN Publishers Prefix for publishers (which is unique to each publisher) with a residence or office in the United States that are publishing their titles within the United States.  Contact the U.S. ISBN Agency, R.R. Bowker, LLC or visit their website for information on the International Standard Book Number.   
 
Intellectual Property refers to creations of the mind such as musical, literary, and artistic works; inventions; and symbols, names, images, and designs used in commerce including  copyright, trademark, patent, and related rights. Under Intellectual Property Law, the holder of one these abstract properties has certain exclusive rights to the creative work, commercial symbol, or invention which is covered by it.  Intellectual property rights are a bundle of exclusive rights over creations of the mind, both artistic and commercial.  Intellectual property rights give the creator the exclusive right to their creations, thereby providing an incentive for the author or inventor to develop and share the information rather than keep it a secret.  The legal protections granted by Intellectual Property laws are credited with significant contributions toward economic growth.  It is advisable to consult with an attorney who specialized in the field of Intellectual Property Law.   
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business. The 4  associations listed below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.

Permit Description:
If you sell clothing, footwear, or items used to make or repair exempt clothing for less than $110 per item or pair of items, your sales are exempt from the New York State 4% sales and use taxes. This exemption does not apply to local sales and use taxes unless the county or city imposing the taxes elects to provide the exemption.

Permit Description:
NYS law regulates the sale of home improvement goods and services and applies to most types of improvements costing more than $500 purchased by homeowners, co-op owners and tenants.  A contactor must also continue to comply with any local licensing laws.  Home improvement contractors should be aware of important provisions in the law.   
 
Home improvement contracts must be in writing, legible and in plain English.  A copy must be given to the customer before any work is done.  The contract must contain: the contractor's name, address, and telephone number.  The approximate start and completion dates; including any contingencies which would change the completion date; and a specific description of the work and materials, including brands, model numbers, and other identifying information, along with the price.  Also included in the contract may be:  
 
Progress Payments:  any schedule of progress agreed to in the contract must bear a 'reasonable relationship' to the work done, materials purchased or other project-related costs. 
 
Escrow Accounts:  any contract payment received by a contractor from a customer prior to substantial completion of the job must be put into a escrow account in a bank located in New York within five business days and the customer must be informed where the money is being held within ten business days.  The contractor is allowed to withdraw the deposit under the terms of the payment schedule agreed upon by the contractor and customer; upon substantial completion of the job; or if the customer violates the contract, but only to the extent that the amount covers the contractor's reasonable costs. 
 
Alternative Surety Bond is used in lieu of the escrow account.  The contractor must deliver to the customer a 'bond' or 'contract of indemnity,' guaranteeing that the customer's money will be properly used or returned.  This bond must be delivered within ten business days after the contractor receives the customer's money. 
 
Consumer Notice:  any contract should have the following information stated within the home improvement contract:  an unconditional right to cancel the contract until midnight of the third business day after the contract was signed; the contractor is legally required to deposit all progress payments received prior to completion in an escrow account or post a bond; and the contractor or subcontractor who does the work and is not paid may have a claim against the customer's property under the NYS Lien Law. 
 
To view applicable laws for home improvement contracts, visit the NYS Legislature's website link below. 
 
To view applicable laws on dealings with mortgage brokers, and the Regulation of Dealings of Mortgage Brokers and Home Improvement Contractors, see the links below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Construction

Permit Description:
Effective January 1, 2012, sale or use of phosphorus fertilizer is restricted. Phosphorus fertilizer means any fertilizer in which the available phosphate (p205) content is greater than 0.67 percent by weight, excluding compost.  
 
Compost means the biologically stable humus-like material derived from composting or the aerobic, thermophilic decomposition of organic matter.  
 
Fertilizer means the same as "specialty fertilizer". Phosphorus runoff poses a threat to water quality. Therefore under New York State law phosphorus-containing fertilizer may only be applied to lawn or non-agriculture turf under certain circumstances.  
 
Contact the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets or the NYS Environmental Conservation for information on how to comply with the law.  
 
A local government may enact more stringent standards for the application of fertilizer for lawn and non-agricultural turf than established in this title, provided, however, that any local government that enacts such standards after January 1, 2011 must demonstrate to the department prior to enactment that additional or more stringent standards are necessary to address local water quality conditions.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description:
The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions.   A professional license is the authorization to practice and use a professional title in New York State.   If you meet all the licensure requirements, you will be issued a license number and be entitled to practice in New York State as of the effective date of licensure.  To practice in New York under the authority of your license, you must register every three years (two years for medicine). You are automatically registered for your first registration period when your license is issued.

The practice of the profession of athletic training is defined as the application of principles, methods and procedures for managing athletic injuries, which shall include the preconditioning, conditioning and reconditioning of an individual who has suffered an athletic injury through the use of appropriate preventative and supportive devices, under the supervision of a physician and recognizing illness and referring to the appropriate medical professional with implementation of treatment pursuant to physician's orders. Athletic training includes instruction to coaches, athletes, parents, medical personnel and communities in the area of care and prevention of athletic injuries.

An athletic trainer means any person who is duly certified in accordance with NYS Education Law, Article 162 to perform athletic training under the supervision of a physician and limits his or her practice to secondary schools, institutions of postsecondary education, professional athletic organizations, or a person who, under the supervision of a physician, carries out comparable functions on orthopedic athletic injuries, excluding spinal cord injuries, in a health care organization. Supervision of an athletic trainer by a physician shall be continuous but shall not be construed as requiring the physical presence of the supervising physician at the time and place where such services are performed.

To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions  or visit their website.   The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms.

Permit Description:
At this time, New York State does not regulate the practice of electrolysis.  Electrology is a hair removal process that uses solid needle/probe devices called a needle epilator.  The electrologist inserts the needle epilator into the hair follicle and discharges a small amount of electrical energy.  The electrologist then removes the hair from the skin after the current destroys the hair's regenerative cell.  Electrolysis usually requires a series of treatments over a period of time because of hair growth cycles.  From a medical standpoint, electrology that uses needle-type devices is the only safe and effective method to permanently remove hair.  Permanent removal of the stimulus for hair growth in an area never really occurs.  However, when competently and skillfully accomplished, it may permanently eliminate the regenerative ability of the hair. 
 
Electrologist may be trained in the three modalities of electrolysis:  short-wave (thermolysis), galvanic multiple needle, and the Blend (a combination of both).  They are also trained to  recognize hair growth patterns and outward symptoms that may require referral to physicians such as an endocrinologist.  National organizations certify electrology practitioners after they complete their recognized certification programs and pass an exam.  These certifications are Clinical Certified Electrologist (CCE), Clinical Medical Electrologist (CME), or a Certified Professional Electrologist.  Two non-profit organizations that offer training and certification for electrologist are linked below. 
 
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), and the Association for Practitioners in Infection Control and Epidemiology (APIC) have information on infection control and standard precautions to use.  Some standard precautions include:  hand washing, the use of gloves, sterilization of critical items used in electrology treatments, the proper disinfections of semi-critical and non-critical items, and the proper cleaning of environmental surfaces.  Voluntary compliance to these standards is encouraged.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services,Professional Licenses

Permit Description:
The U.S. Customs and Border Protection is responsible for ensuring that all goods entering and exiting the United States follow all U.S. laws and regulations.  Their website provides an overview of importing and exporting issues.  You will find links for information on duty rates, the Harmonized Tariff Schedule, regulations, publications, and forms.  For general information about how to import into the United States contact the US Customs Headquarters Office or visit their website.

The U.S. Department of Commerce, USA Trade Center is the U.S. government export portal.  This website contains information on exporting and importing.  You will find links to contact lists, tariffs and taxes, U.S. Export Controls Schedule B (Shipper's Export Declaration), Export.gov Newsletter, and export licensing.  For general information about how to export, the publication A Basic Guide to Exporting is an excellent resource and is available on-line through the link below.  

Small businesses looking to increase sales and profit are taking their businesses global. The U.S. Small Business Administration's Office of International Trade provides counseling, training and financing to support small business export opportunities. They can be reached by phone or visit their website available through the link below.

The NYS Empire State Development's (ESD) International Trade Division provides assistance to businesses starting or expanding an international company by counseling, education, and marketing programs, as well as overseas trade exhibitions to help businesses find customers and promote products in foreign markets. ESD offers New York's small businesses a full range of trade development assistance through the Export Marketing Assistant Service (EMAS).  For information contact their office or visit their website.

The NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets is a member of a consortium called the Food Export USA-Northeast that helps promote the sale of U.S. products internationally.  The Department facilitates meetings between New York food companies and buyers from foreign countries as well as provides technical and grant assistance and export counseling.  For information on marketing products internationally, contact the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets office or visit their website. 

To encourage and facilitate international trade, more than 300 free ports, free trade zones, and similar customs privileged facilities are now in operation in 75 foreign countries, usually in or near seaports or airports. The United States implemented the Foreign Trade Zones Act in 1934 and refers to free zones as Foreign-Trade Zones.  New York State has twelve U.S. Foreign-Trade Zones. Many U.S. manufacturers and their distributors use foreign-trade zones for receiving shipments of goods that are reshipped in smaller lots to customers throughout the surrounding area. The purpose of the zone is to attract and promote international trade and commerce.  Using foreign-trade zones can be profitable for operations involving foreign dutiable materials and components being assembled or produced here for re-export.  For export operations, foreign-trade zones can provide accelerated export status for purposes of excise tax rebates and customs drawback. Information about free trade zones, free ports, and similar facilities internationally may be found in, Tax-Free Trade Zones of the World published by Matthew Bender & Co.  For information contact their office or visit their website.

New York may also have additional requirements for certain products imported into New York.  If you plan to import the following products, please contact the associated state agencies  or visit their website for their requirements:

- Petroleum and petroleum products such as gasoline, motor fuels, diesel fuels, heating oil, kerosene, kero-jet fuel, white-water kerosene, marine gas oil, liquefied petroleum gas fuels (propane, ethane, or butane), contact the NYS Department of Taxatio
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Miscellaneous,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description: The U.S. Postal Service has the authority to ensure the security and safety of the mail.  A Commercial Mail Receiving Agency is a private business that accepts mail delivery from the U.S. Postal Service for others, holds mail for pickup or re-mails packages or letters to another address with payment of new postage.  To become a commercial mail receiving agency, contact the local postmaster in your area to file PS Form 1583-A, Application to Act as a Commercial Mail Receiving Agency.  The commercial mail receiving agency must have each addressee or firm receiving mail at the agency complete and retain PS Form 1583, Application for Delivery of Mail through Agent.  To obtain copies of PS Forms 1583-A and 1583 or to find the nearest postmaster, visit the U.S. Postal Service's website at www.usps.com.

The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions. The practice of the profession of audiology shall mean the application of principles, methods and procedures of measurement, testing, evaluation, consultation, counseling, instruction and habilitation or rehabilitation related to hearing, its disorders, related communication impairments and vestibular disorders for the purpose of non-medical diagnosis, prevention, identification, amelioration or modification of such disorders and conditions in individuals and/or groups of individuals.

Permit Description:
Before beginning a new or expanded INTERSTATE trucking operation, contact the appropriate regulatory agencies in every state in and through which you will operate to obtain information regarding various State rules applicable to interstate authorities.  You are responsible to comply with registrations, fuel tax and other State regulations and procedures.   

INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE

Certain trucks, truck tractors, and buses used on public highways with a registered gross weight or combined gross weight of 55,000 pounds or more are subject to federal excise tax. Federal Heavy Highway Vehicle Use Tax (HVUT) is paid directly to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) for the tax period from July 1 - June 30 each year.  For information about this tax or to obtain Form 2290, Heavy Highway Vehicle Use Tax Return, contact the IRS or visit their website.

FEDERAL MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY ADMINISTRATION (US DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION)

To operate as an interstate motor carrier, a company may need to register with the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) to get a USDOT number and/or apply for operating authority.  

USDOT Number:

A USDOT number is the number that the FMCSA assigns to each motor carrier that starts interstate operations.  A USDOT number is required if you have vehicles that are over 10,000 pounds, if you transport between 9 and 15 passengers (including the driver) for compensation, if you transport 16 or more passengers, or haul hazardous materials in interstate commerce. 

New York State requires that all trucks and truck/trailers that are used in business with a gross vehicle weight or a gross combination weight of 10,001 pounds or more have a USDOT number.

The USDOT number must be marked on both sides of all vehicles.  The lettering of the business name and the USDOT number need to contrast sharply with the background color and be readable from 50 feet.  Complete Form MCS-150 (Motor Carrier Identification Report) to obtain a USDOT number.  The MCS-150 can be completed online by accessing the link below or call to have an application mailed to you. 

After being issued a USDOT Number as a new entrant registration, the carrier will be subject to an 18-month safety-monitoring period.  During this safety-monitoring period, the carrier will receive a safety audit and have their roadside crash and inspection information closely evaluated.  The carrier is required to demonstrate that it has the necessary systems in place to ensure basic safety management controls.  For more information on this requirement, request an Educational and Technical Assistance (ETA) package (A Motor Carrier's Guide to Improving Highway Safety) by calling or visiting the link provided below.

Interstate Operating Authority – MC Number:

Generally, if operating as a for-hire motor carrier of regulated commodities or passengers in interstate commerce, you must also obtain interstate operating authority (MC number) from the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA).  The Form OP-1, Application for Motor Property Carrier and Broker Authority, is required for a motor carrier of property (including household goods) and Form OP-1(P), Application for Motor Passenger Carrier Authority, is required for a motor carrier of passengers.   You can apply online through the link provided below or request an application be mailed to you by calling their office.

Proof of Liability and/or Cargo Insurance:

In addition to filing for operating authority, motor carriers, forwarders and brokers must have specific insurance documents on file with the FMCSA.  The required filings vary based on the type of registrations involved.  Liability and cargo insurance forms must be submitted directly by the home office of the insurance company furnishing the coverage.  The FMCSA does not furnish copies of insurance forms.  For more information on insurance requirements, visit the link provided below for the overview.

Designation of Agents for Motor Carriers, Br
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Transportation and Pubic Utilities
