Permit Description:
U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY 
 
All persons who generate, transport, recycle, treat, store or dispose of hazardous wastes are required to have an EPA Identification Number.  To obtain a Notification of Regulated Waste Activity, Form 8700-12, or for more information, contact the agency or visit the link provided below. 
 
NYS DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION 
 
Anyone engaged in the transport of regulated waste generated or disposed of within New York State must possess a valid New York State Part 364 Waste Transporter Permit.  Regulated waste includes: 
 
Hazardous waste (requires USEPA ID number) 
Nonhazardous commercial/industrial waste 
Waste oil (required USEPA ID number) 
Petroleum-contaminated soil 
Regulated medical waste 
Waste tires 
Asbestos 
Residential septage 
Nonresidential raw sewage or sewage-contaminated wastes 
Sludge from a sewage treatment plant or water supply treatment plant, 
Low-level radioactive waste (LLRW) - highway transport through the state requires a permit, regardless of whether or not you stop to pick up or dispose. 
 
It is the responsibility of the transporter and generator to accurately classify the waste. This includes any testing that may be needed to determine whether or not the waste is hazardous.  
 
General liability insurance is required for transporters of non-hazardous waste.  For hazardous waste, regulated medical waste and low-level radioactive waste specified amounts are required.   You must have insurance in place before you transport any of the above listed wastes.  You must submit proof of insurance to the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation at the time of permit renewal. 
 
Permitted waste transporters are obligated to meet the operating requirements as set forth in New York State law and regulation.  For more information, visit the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's link provided below. 
 
Certain waste types and waste transported under certain conditions are exempt from needing a Waste Transporter Permit.  Listed below are the most frequently applied for exemptions.  
 
A waste transporter permit is NOT required to transport the following:  
 
Municipal solid waste (i.e., household garbage) 
A single truckload of nonhazardous regulated waste (except hazardous, regulated medical and residential septage) weighing less than 500 pounds 
Construction and demolition debris (that does not contain friable asbestos) 
Nonfriable asbestos 
Nonhazardous scrap (such as scrap metal, plastic) 
 
For questions regarding the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's Waste Transporter Permit Program, contact them or visit their website.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail,Licenses and Permits, Services,Licenses and Permits, Transportation and Pubic Utilities

Permit Description:
The Code of Federal Regulations Title 21, Section 1040.20 created performance standards for sunlamp products and ultraviolet lamps intended for use in the tanning industry.  The Food and Drug Administration's Center for Devices and Radiological Health is responsible for the labeling of these devices and the Federal Trade Commission is responsible for investigating false, misleading, and deceptive advertising. 
 
As of July 1, 2010, indoor (ultraviolet) tanning services are subject to a 10 percent Federal excise tax under the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.   Qualified physical fitness facilities that offer tanning services are exempt from this tax.   For information on the indoor tanning tax, contact the Internal Revenue Service or visit their website. 
 
Effective August 15, 2012, Section 3555 of the Public Health Law has been amended to prohibit the use of indoor tanning devices by children less than 17 years of age and requires teens between  the ages of 17 and 18 to obtain parental consent.  For more information on the law, view the NYS Public Health Law through the link below.

Permit Description:
To operate a pay-per-call service (900 number) or provide billing for a pay-per-call service the Federal Trade Commission has adopted rules governing this industry.  The Telephone Disclosure and Dispute Resolution Act required the Federal Trade Commission to adopt the 900-Number Rule effective November 1993.   
 
Under the 900-Number Rule, pay-per-call services (900 numbers) must provide: 
 
1.  Ad information.  All print, radio, and television advertisements for the 900-number service must include the total cost of the call if there is a flat fee; the per-minute rate of the call is charged by the minute, as well as any minimum charges.  If the length of the program is known in advance, the ad also must state the total cost of the complete program; the range of fees if there are different rates for different options.  The ad must state the initial cost of the call and any minimum charges; the cost of any other 900 number to which the customer may be transferred; and any other fees the service might charge.  This information cannot be hidden in small print.  The cost of the call must be next to the 900 number and printed in a size that is at least half the size of the 900 number.  In a television ad, an audio cost disclosure must be made. 
 
2.  Introductory message (preamble).  All 900-number services that cost more than $2 require an introductory message or 'preamble.'  This message is free of charge.  It must briefly describe the service, the name of the company providing the service, and the cost of the call.  It also must state that anyone under age 18 needs parental permission to complete the call.  Once this information is provided, the service must allow the customer three seconds to hang up without incurring a charge. 
 
3.  Prize claims by pay-per-call services.  It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to offer a consumer a prize which would require the consumer to call the pay-per-call service to claim the prize and be charged a fee. 
 
4.  Procedures for resolving billing disputes. For each 900 call, statements should include the date, time, and for services that have per-minute rates, the length of the call.  These charges must appear separately from local and long distance charges.  Statements must include a local or toll-free number for questions about the pay-per-call charges.  
 
Additional ad disclosures are required for services that: 
 
1. Promote sweepstakes or games of chance; 
2. Provide information about a federal program (but are not sponsored by a federal agency); and 
3. Target individuals under 18 years of age.  (Note:  ads directed to children under 12 years of age are prohibited.) 
 
The NYS Office of the Attorney General also has information entitled Pager and 900 Number Scams.  To receive a copy contact their office or visit the direct link below.  
 
Applicable Laws:  
 
The NYS General Business Law is available through the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Name: Copyright of Sound Recordings or Performing Arts
Permit Description:
Copyright is a form of protection provided by the laws of the United States, U.S. Code, Title 17, to the authors of original works of authorship, including literary works; dramatic works (including any accompanying music); musical works (including any accompanying words); artistic works; certain other intellectual works; pantomimes and choreographic works; pictorial, graphic, and sculptural works; motion pictures and other audiovisual works; and sound recordings. This protection is available to both published and unpublished works.  Section 106 of the 1976 Copyright Act generally gives the owner of the copyright the exclusive right to and to authorize others to do the following:  reproduce the work in copies or phono-records; to prepare derivative works based upon the work; to distribute copies or phono-records of the work to the public by sale or other transfer of ownership, or by rental, lease, or lending; to perform the work publicly, in the case of literary, musical, dramatic, and choreographic works, pantomimes, and motion pictures and other audiovisual works; to display the copyrighted work publicly, in the case of literary, musical, dramatic, and choreographic works, pantomimes, and pictorial, graphic, or sculptural works, including the individual images of a motion picture or other audiovisual work; and in the case of sound recordings, to perform the work publicly by means of a digital audio transmission.

In addition, certain authors of works of visual art have the rights of attribution and integrity as described in Section 106A of the 1976 Copyright Act.  For further information, check out Circular 40, Copyright Registration for Works of the Visual Arts at the link below.

Securing a copyright is automatic when the work is created.  A work is created when it is fixed in a copy or phono-record for the first time. Copies are material objects from which a work can be read or visually perceived either directly or with the aid of a machine or device, such as books, manuscripts, sheet music, film, videotape, or microfilm. Phono-records are material objects embodying fixations of sounds (excluding, by statutory definition, motion picture soundtracks), such as cassette tapes, CDs, or LPs. Thus, for example, a song (the work) can be fixed in sheet music (copies) or in phonograph disks (phono-records), or both.

If a work is prepared over a period of time, the part of the work that is fixed on a particular date constitutes the created work as of that date.

Publication is the distribution of copies or phono-records of a work to the public by sale or other transfer of ownership, or by rental, lease, or lending. The offering to distribute copies or phono-records to a group of persons for purposes of further distribution, public performance, or public display constitutes publication.  A public performance or display of a work does not of itself constitute publication.

Notice of copyright is important because it informs the public that the work is protected by copyright, identifies the copyright owner, and shows the year of first publication.  Furthermore, in the event that a work is infringed, if a proper notice of copyright appears on the published copy or copies to which a defendant in a copyright infringement suit had access, then no weight shall be given to such a defendant's interposition of a defense based on innocent infringement in mitigation of actual or statutory damages, except as provided in Section 504(c)(2) of the copyright law.  Innocent infringement occurs when the infringer did not realize that the work was protected.  Notice of copyright is the responsibility of the copyright owner and does not require advance permission from, or registration with, the Copyright Office.

Sound recordings are defined in the law as works that result from the fixation of a series of musical, spoken, or other sounds, but not including the sounds accompanying a motion picture or other audiovisual work.  Common examples include recor
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
A winery is a building or property that produces wine, or a business involved in the production of wine, such as a wine company.  Besides wine making equipment, larger wineries may also feature warehouses, bottling lines, laboratories, and large expanses of tanks.  In the U.S. a winery crushes grapes, ferments the juice, and bottles the finished product.  A vineyard is a plantation of grape-bearing vines, grown mainly for wine-making, but also for raisins, table grapes and non-alcoholic grape juice.  The science, practice, and study of vineyard production is known as viticulture.  New York classifies wine-making in three license categories:  winery, farm winery, and farm micro-winery.

A winery is a facility that manufactures wine from crushed grapes, grape concentrate or from honey; that blends wine, bottles wine received in bulk from its parent facility that may be located outside of New York; sells wine to wholesalers or retailers in sealed containers of not more than 15 gallons each of wine; and/or sells wines in excess of 15 gallons to food, wine, vinegar and/or pharmaceutical manufacturers.   

A farm winery is a facility that manufactures wine or cider manufactured entirely from grapes or other farm or agriculture products grown or produced in New York and that produces less than 150,000 finished gallons per year.  

A farm micro-winery is a farm-winery where wine or cider is manufactured and sold from the licensed premises to a licensed wholesaler or retailer, or at retail for consumption off the premises and produces or manufactures not more than 1,500 of finished gallons of wine annually produced exclusively from grapes or other fruits or agricultural products grown or produced in New York.

The NYS Liquor Authority licenses wineries, farm wineries, and farm micro-wineries.  The NYS Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, Article 6, outlines the differences of each type of winery and other requirements.  See the link provided below.  For information on NYS Liquor Authority licensing requirements, contact the NYS Liquor Authority or visit their website.  Other possible licenses from the NYS Liquor Authority may include brand labeling, wine tastings, custom crush operations and sales at farmer's markets.

The NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets regulates any type of beverage manufacturing including wineries and farm wineries through food processing establishment Article 20-C licensing.  Other possible licenses from the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets may include Farm Products Dealers license and requirements from the Department's Division of Plant Industry.  For information on NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets licensing requirements, contact the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets or visit their website. 

The NYS Department of Taxation and Finance provides information on sales tax requirements and tax exemptions for manufacturing facilities.  Other requirements from the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance may include Distributor of Alcoholic Beverages Registration requirements.  For information on tax requirements, contact the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance or visit their website. 

The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation regulates the usage of pesticides and chemicals.  Contact the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation or visit their website for pesticide licensing or chemical usage requirements.  

If the project involves construction and/or land clearing activities, other New York State agencies may have additional requirements that must be met before commencing.  

The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation may require a State Environmental Quality Review (SEQR) and a State Pollution Discharge Elimination System (SPDES) review.  For information on these requirements, contact the regional office near the location area.  To find a listing and contact information of regional offices, visit the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's website.

Permit Description:
Consumer reporting agencies collect and/or provide information to help businesses evaluate customers.  Consumer reporting agencies include credit bureaus, employment screening services, tenant screening companies, check verification services, and medical information services.

The Federal Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA, 15 U.S.C.) and the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act of 2003 set restrictions and standards for consumer reporting agencies.  For detailed information regarding federal requirements, visit the Federal Trade Commission's website through the link below.
 
The NYS General Business Law, Article 25, Fair Credit Report Act also set standards for the operation of consumer reporting agencies in New York.  The NYS General Business Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.
 
Consumer reporting agencies may be required to register with the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance to collect sales tax. Contact the NYS Business Tax Information Center to learn whether your business requires a Certificate of Authority.
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations linked at the bottom are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Copyrights, Patents, Trademarks and Service Marks
Permit Description:
Copyrights protect literary, artistic, and musical works and are registered with the federal government.  Patents protect inventions and improvements to existing inventions and are registered with the federal government.  Trademarks/service marks are brand names and/or designs that are applied to products or used in connection with services and are registered with the federal government and can be registered in New York State.  

COPYRIGHT

Copyrights provide protection to authors of original works including literary works; dramatic works; musical works; pantomimes and choreographic works; pictorial, graphic and sculptural works; motion pictures and other audiovisual works; sound recordings; and architectural works.  Copyrights do not protect facts, ideas, titles, names, short phrases, slogans, systems, or methods of operation.   Copyright protection starts the moment the original work is created and fixed in a tangible form so that it is perceptible either directly or with the aid of a machine or device.  This protection is available to both published and unpublished works.  A copyright generally gives the owner of the copyright the exclusive right to do and to authorize others to do the following:  reproduce the work; prepare derivative works based upon the work; distribute copies or phonorecords of the work; perform and/or display the work publicly; and in the case of sound recordings, perform the work publicly by means of a digital audio transmission.

Registration of the original work is recommended with the U.S. Copyright Office but is not a requirement.  Registration establishes a public record; gives prima facie evidence in a court of law if registered within five years of publication; may help with statutory damages and attorney's fee in court actions; and gives protection with the U.S. Customs Service against importation of infringing copies.  A copyright registration is effective on the date the U.S. Copyright Office receives all the required elements.  The U.S. Copyright Office recommends submitting the registration by registered or certified mail and to request a return receipt.  Normal processing time takes approximately five to six months.  

To obtain information on copyright law, current fees, registration requirements and forms, circulars, etc., contact the Library of Congress, Copyright Office or visit their website.

PATENTS

A patent gives the inventor the property right to exclude others from making, using, selling, or importing the invention in the United States.  The federal government grants patents to true inventors.  In return for this legal protection, an inventor must fully disclose the invention to the public.  Methods of doing business, an idea or suggestion, or printed matter cannot be patented.  The term length of a new patent is 20 years from the date on which the application for the patent was filed in the United States or, in special cases, from the date an earlier related application was filed.  There are three types of patents.  A utility patent is granted on any new useful process, machine, or composition of matter.  A design patent protects the ornamental design for an article of manufacture.  A plant patent is granted on any distinct and new variety of an asexually reproduced plant, including cultivated mutants, hybrids, and newly found seedlings.

There are two ways to apply for a patent in the United States.  A non-provisional application begins the examination process that may lead to a patent, or a provisional application that establishes a filing date but does not begin the examination process.  A provisional application provides the inventor with a one-year period to further develop the invention for marketability, funding or capital, or licensing agreements.  In using a provisional application, the inventor must file a non-provisional application within 12 months of the filing date of the provisional application.  There is a required filing fee that must accompany both types of a
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
The federal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act as well as the NYS Debt Collection Procedures imposes restrictions on various practices for the collection of debts by either a creditor or an independent third party collection agency.  Debt collection agencies are allowed to contact debtors in person, by mail, telephone, telegram or fax.  Agencies are restricted from contacting debtors at inconvenient times or places.  Agencies are prohibited from contacting debtors at their place of employment if the collection agency knows the debtor's employer disapproves of this practice.  Debt collection agencies are prohibited from certain harassing or abusive tactics.  For detailed information regarding the federal law, contact the Federal Trade Commission or visit their website. 
 
For information regarding New York state requirements contact the NYS Attorney General's Office or the NYS Department of Financial Services or by visiting their websites.
Permit Categories: General Business Information,Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
A franchise is a legal and commercial relationship between the owner of a trademark, service mark, trade name, or advertising symbol and an individual or group seeking the right to use that identification in a business.  The franchise governs the method for conducting business between the two parties. 
 
A franchisor owns the right to a name or trademark and sells that right to a franchisee.  This is referred to as product/trade name franchising  Business from franchises often provide a full range of services, including site selection, training, product supply, marketing plans, and financing.    A franchisee sells goods or services supplied by the franchisor or sells goods or services that meet the franchisor's quality standards. 
 
The Federal Trade Commission's Full Disclosure Rule requires franchisors to give prospective franchisees a disclosure document or a franchise offering circular at least ten business days before the franchisee pays any money or legally commits to a purchase.  This document gives 20 important items of information about the business.  The document outlines the general franchise offering, including background information of the franchisor, a summary of the franchise agreement, and a list of current franchisees as well as the cost required to start and maintain the business, and the responsibilities between the franchisor and the franchisee once the franchise is bought. 
 
The Federal Trade Commission regulates franchising at the national level.  The FTC is responsible for enforcing the FTC Rule, eliminating unfair or deceptive practices, prosecuting violators of franchising laws and consumer education.  The FTC's publication, Buying a Franchise:  A Consumer Guide  can be obtained through the link below. 
 
The NYS Office of the Attorney General regulates franchising in New York and accepts franchise prospectuses and written complaints regarding franchisor fraud.  The NYS Office of the Attorney General's publication, What to Consider Before Buying a Franchise as well state and federal franchise laws and regulations, appropriate forms to be filed by franchisors and links to other sites can be obtained through its website or by contacting their office. 
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations linked below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: General Business Information,Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
Medical billers prepare and file claims to health insurance companies, government agencies, and patients on behalf of doctors and health care providers to assure payments for procedures during office visits, emergency visits, or hospital visits.  Health care providers can consist of chiropractors, mental health professionals, dentists, social workers, nursing homes, ambulance services, pharmacists, home-health practitioners, durable medical equipment providers, and institutions such as hospitals, etc.   Medical coders primarily focus on converting a medical procedure, diagnosis, or symptom into specific codes to submit a claim for reimbursement.  

Credentials through certification are not required in New York for medical billers or coders, but certain types of certification does ensure professionalism, qualification and competency in the medical billing/coding services industry.  Accredited schools throughout New York offer programs in the healthcare information technologies to help prepare students for a career in medical billing and coding, as well as preparation to take industry certification examinations.  
 
All types of encounters (‘face-to-face contact' between a health care professional and an eligible beneficiary (patient) at a medical office, clinic, or hospital), services, tests, treatments, supplies, and procedures provided to a patient have a code which consists of a set of numbers and combinations of sets of numbers.  There are standardize-coding systems used in the United States.  These codes change annually to reflect emerging technology, services and procedures.  The Current Procedural Terminology (CPT) is the most common coding methodology used for medical, surgical, diagnostic, or psychiatric procedures as well as for specifying treatment. The maintenance of these codes is the responsibility of the American Medical Association.  For a current copy of the CPT codes, contact the American Medical Association or visit their website through the link below.   

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD) codes have the most up-to-date information on medical diagnosis and procedures coding.  Two U.S. governmental agencies are responsible for overseeing all changes and modifications to the ICD.   You may contact the National Center for Health Statistics or visit  their website for hardcopies, contact the Governmental Printing Office or the National Technical Information Services.

The Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System (HCPCS) is used for Medicare's classification of inpatient hospital services based on principal diagnosis, secondary diagnosis, surgical procedures, etc.   The HCPCS is available through the Government Printing Office or through the National Technical Information Services.

Current Dental Terminology (CDT) is a reference manual published by the American Dental Association that contains a number of useful components, including the Code on Dental Procedures and Nomenclature (Code).  The Code, published in the CDT reference manual, provides the dental profession with a standardized coding system to document and to communicate accurate information about dental treatment procedures and services, for reporting procedures on patients, and processing and reporting of dental insurance claims.  The Codes for Dental Procedures and Nomenclature is available from the American Dental Association or visit their website.

The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) requires every provider who does business electronically to use the same health care transactions, code sets, and identifiers.  HIPAA has identified ten standard transactions for Electronic Data Interchange (EDI) for the transmission of health care data.  Medical billers must understand the security and privacy standards for handling medical data provided for in the HIPAA.  The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Office for Civil Rights has issued extensive guidance and technical materials to explain the privacy
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
Oxygen is a hazardous material used in numerous business industries such as construction, health care, manufacturing, services, and transportation.  Although considered nontoxic and environmentally safe, oxygen does not burn, but does vigorously accelerate combustion. Oxygen must never strike any oily surfaces, come in contact with greasy clothes, or other combustible materials.  To avoid this harmful effect, producers and consumers should follow strict safety guidelines for storage, handling, and transporting of oxygen.   
 
The Compressed Gas Association has several pamphlets available with information on the handling and storage of oxygen as well as other types of compressed gas.  Medical grades of oxygen are subject to strict federal regulations and are for use only under the control of a licensed physician familiar with the product and its hazards.  Contact the NYS Department of Education, Board of Pharmacy  for information on requirements for the manufacturing, repacking, and distribution of medical compressed gas.   
 
For information on handling, storage, training, and fire safety contact the U.S. Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration office or visit their website.

Permit Description:
The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) enforces the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA), which also regulates telemarketing.  For more information about federal regulations, contact the FCC or visit the link below.   Many states, including New York, have laws regulating telemarketing. The FTC and the FCC are working with states to harmonize Do Not Call requirements at state and federal levels for a unified national system to help businesses seeking to comply with the requirements as well as enabling 'one-stop' service for consumers.  
 
If your telemarketing business involves any calls across state lines, whether you make outbound calls or receive calls in response to advertising, you may be subject to the Telemarketing Sales Rule's provisions. The Federal Trade Commission's publication, 'Complying with the Telemarketing Sales Rules,' describes the types of organizations and activities that are subject to the Telemarketing Sales Rules and explains how to comply.   For a copy of the publication visit the Federal Trade Commission's website through the link below. 
 
The NYS General Business Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the links below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
New York offers financial incentives to assist businesses that plan to locate, expand or modernize their facilities within the state.  Generally, these incentives support the acquisition of land and buildings or machinery and equipment.  
 
Empire State Development is the New York State agency that offers financial assistance through direct loans or grants to businesses for a portion of the eligible project costs or interest rate subsidies to reduce the cost of borrowing from private sector financial institutions. 
 
The Consolidated Funding Application (CFA) has been designed to give economic development project applicants expedited and streamlined access to a combined pool of grant funds and tax credits from dozens of existing programs. The CFA is a modern and easy-to-use online application that allows businesses and other entities to apply for multiple agency funding sources through a single, web-based application.  State agencies and authorities making resources available in the CFA include:  Empire State Development; NYS Canal Corporation; NYS Energy Research and Development Authority; Environmental Facilities Corporation; Homes and Community Renewal; Department of Labor; Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation; Department of State; New York Power Authority; Agriculture and Markets; Department of Environmental Conservation; and the Council on the Arts (NYSCA).  For further information see the CFA link below. 
 
The Start-Up New York (SUNY Tax-free Areas to Revitalize and Transform Upstate NY) initiative will transform SUNY campuses and university communities across New York into tax-free communities, including no income tax for employees, and no sales, property or business tax for ten years for the business.  Businesses eligible to participate in this program will need to align with or further the academic mission of the campus, college or university sponsoring the tax-free community, as well as have positive community and economic benefits.  The business must be a new start-up company; a company from out-of-state that is relocating to New York; or an expansion of an existing New York company.  A business will need to submit certification to the Empire State Development to participate in this incentive. 
 
Empire State Development also provides information on New York business resources for small business entrepreneurs with interactive online directories. The Small Business Revolving Loan Fund (SBRLF) is designed to create economic activity by providing greater access to capital for small businesses.  The program is targeted to small businesses that have had difficulty accessing regular credit markets.  This program supports additional small business lending in every region of the state.  Further funding incentives are outlined in the publication entitled 'New York State Directory of Small Business Programs.'   The Directory of Alternative Small Business Lending Programs is a directory of State business resources.  To view these resources plus other information, visit their website and click on Small Business.  
 
Most County Economic Development offices have loan and/or incentive programs to help business entrepreneurs start or expand their business.  For information contact your County Economic Development office. 
 
The U. S. Small Business Administration (SBA) is a Federal agency that offers numerous loan programs to assist small businesses.  It is important to note, however, that the SBA is primarily a guarantor of loans made by private and other institutions and does not offer loans to small businesses.  The SBA oversees the Basic 7(a) Loan Program and the CDC/504 Program among others.  The SBA helps lending institutions that provide financing to small businesses when funding is otherwise unavailable on reasonable terms by guaranteeing major portions of loans made to small businesses.  In guaranteeing the loan, the SBA assures the lender that, in the event the borrower does not repay the loan, the government wil
Permit Categories: General Business Information

Permit Description:
A sales tax exemption certificate enables you to make tax-free purchases of items and services that would normally be subject to sales tax.

You must give the seller a properly completed certificate within 90 days of the time the sale is made. Certain sales are always exempt from sales tax, meaning you do not need an exemption certificate to make purchases of these items or services.

You may use an exemption certificate if, as a purchaser:

• you intend to resell the property or service;
• you intend to use the property or service for a purpose that is exempt from sales tax; or
• you make purchases as an agent or employee of a tax-exempt nonprofit organization or governmental entity.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description: Effective July 24, 2003, the amended NYS Clean Indoor Air Act (Public Health Law, Article 13-E) prohibits smoking in virtually all workplaces, including restaurants and bars. The changes in the Act reflect the state's commitment to ensure the protection to all workers from secondhand smoke. Localities may continue to adopt and enforce local laws regulating smoking, however, these regulations must be at least as strict as the Clean Indoor Air Act.  Compliance guides and information on exemptions and waivers to the smoking restrictions are available at the NYS Department of Health's website.
Permit Categories: Employer Information,General Business Information,Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Food Service and Processing,Licenses and Permits, Health Care

Permit Description:
The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions. A professional license is the authorization to practice and use a professional title in New York State. If you meet all the licensure requirements, you will be issued a license number and be entitled to practice in New York State as of the effective date of licensure. To practice in New York under the authority of your license, you must register every three years (two years for medicine). You are automatically registered for your first registration period when your license is issued. 

The practice of the profession of acupuncture is the treating, by means of mechanical, thermal or electrical stimulation effected by the insertion of needles or by the application of heat, pressure or electrical stimulation at a point or combination of points on the surface of the body predetermined on the basis of the theory of the physiological interrelationship of body organs with an associated point or combination of points for diseases, disorders and dysfunctions of the body for the purpose of achieving a therapeutic or prophylactic effect. To practice acupuncture or the use of the title "licensed acupuncturist" within New York State requires licensure as an acupuncturist, unless otherwise exempt under the law. Licensed physicians and dentists may be certified to practice acupuncture in New York State, but the requirements and application process are different from those for licensure in acupuncture. 

To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions. The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms. 

Physicians and dentists who seek certification to practice acupuncture should contact the Office of the Professions for additional information.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Education,Licenses and Permits, Health Care,Professional Licenses

Permit Description:
There is no New York State license or permit to operate a social adult day care service at this time, but there are various operating guidelines that should be followed.  You should contact the NYS Office for the Aging and the NYS Department of Health for information on these operating guidelines. 
 
The definition of a social adult day care program is a structured, comprehensive program which provides functionally-impaired individuals with socialization; supervision and monitoring; personal care; and nutrition in a protective setting during any part of the day, but for less than a 24-hour period.  Additional services may include and are not limited to maintenance and enhancement of daily living skills, transportation, caregiver assistance, and case coordination and assistance.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description: All motor vehicle repair shops and dismantlers that service and/or repair or recover motor vehicle air conditioners must have equipment to recover and recycle air conditioner refrigerants.  The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation has standards and approves this equipment.  For a list of approved equipment, contact the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's Division of Air Resources.  Repair shop and dismantler applicants must attach either a manufacturer's certificate or an invoice as proof of purchase of this equipment with their application.  These documents must contain the name and address of the repair shop or dismantler and the equipment manufacturer's, the purchase date of the equipment, and the serial number of the unit.  New York requires certification for anyone who works on motor vehicle air conditioning systems.  The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency lists and approves certifying organizations, contact the EPA for additional information.  The NYS Department of Motor Vehicles, Division of Vehicle Safety, Technical Training Unit offers a course called, Systems Training and Air Conditioning (STAC).  This course goes beyond the certification requirements for servicing, handling, recycling, and retrofitting motor vehicle air conditioners.  STAC provides training in diagnosing and repairing vehicle air conditioning, mechanical, electrical and electronic systems.  Contact the NYS Department of Motor Vehicles for more information.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
If you are a contractor or repair person, whether you collect sales tax from a customer depends on whether the work you perform is a capital improvement to real property, or is repair, maintenance, or installation work.

When to collect sales tax:
When you perform work that qualifies as a capital improvement to real property, you should not charge your customer sales tax.

For sales tax purposes, a capital improvement is any addition or alteration to real property that meets all three of the following conditions:
•it substantially adds to the value of the real property, or appreciably prolongs the useful life of the real property;
•it becomes part of the real property or is permanently affixed to the real property so that removal would cause material damage to the property or article itself; and
•it is intended to become a permanent installation. 

When you perform work that qualifies as repair, maintenance, or installation work, you must charge your customer sales tax. These services cover all activities that relate to keeping real property in a condition of fitness, efficiency, readiness, or safety, or restoring it to such condition.

Purchasing materials and supplies:
Materials and other tangible personal property purchased for a project are taxable, whether purchased by a contractor, subcontractor, or the property owner, unless the property owner is entitled to an exemption.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Purchasing an Existing Business or its Assets
Permit Description:
Before purchasing an existing business, or some or all of the assets from an existing business, other than in the ordinary course of business, you must determine if the seller was required to collect NYS sales tax. If so, the sale is considered a bulk sale transaction and you, the purchaser, may be held liable for any sales or use tax the seller owes New York State. 

As a purchaser of assets in a bulk sale transaction, you are required to:
• notify the NYS Tax Department of your pending purchase or acquisition using Form AU-196.10, Notification of Sale, Transfer or Assignment in Bulk, at least 10 days before paying for or taking possession of the business assets, whichever occurs first; and
• pay sales tax when purchasing business assets, such as furniture or office equipment. 

For more information, visit the Tax Department’s website through the links below, or refer to Publication 20, New York State Tax Guide For New Businesses. 

Businesses that have an interest in real property:
If you are acquiring a business that has an interest in real property, such as a deed or a lease, the transaction may be subject to the real estate transfer tax. For more information, visit the Tax Department’s website through the links below, or refer to Publication 20, New York State Tax Guide For New Businesses. 

Additional licenses, permits, and registrations:
All the licenses, permits and registrations that are required to operate a business may not be transferable when purchasing an existing business. You will need to contact the issuing agencies for information on how to comply with New York State’s registration requirements.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description: The U.S. Gun Control Act requires each person who intends to engage in the business as a firearms dealer, importer or manufacturer or an ammunition importer or manufacturer obtain a Federal firearms license prior to commencing business.  A gunsmith by definition is a firearms dealer and needs a federal firearms license to conduct gunsmith activities such as engraving, customizing, refinishing or repairing a fireman.  Collectors of curio and relic firearms also must hold a federal firearms license.  The Federal Firearms Licensing Center (FFLC) of the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives is responsible for determining eligibility and acting upon applications for Federal firearms licenses. Inspections of applicants are coordinated with regulatory field offices.  Licensees must comply with federal laws and specific record keeping regulations.  For information and federal licensing requirements, by contacting the agency listed.

Permit Description: A salvage vehicle is a vehicle that was transferred to an insurance company because it was stolen or has significant damage.  The damage can occur because of a collision, theft, vandalism, or damage from water.   If a salvage vehicle is rebuilt for use on roadways, the NYS Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) must examine it before the DMV can issue a new title certificate or registration. The required examination is part of the NYS Auto Theft Prevention Program.  The program also includes rebuilt salvage vehicles from most other states.  The salvage vehicle examination is not a safety inspection, an emissions inspection, or an insurance examination.  The salvage vehicle examination is a separate and additional examination conducted by DMV investigators.   The salvage vehicle cannot be driven to the examination facility if it does not have a valid registration and liability insurance.  The vehicle must be transported legally to the examination facility.  The DMV Division of Field Investigations Auto Theft Unit administers the Salvage Vehicle Examination Program.  For a list of facilities, please visit the NYS Department of Motor Vehicle's  website at www.dmv.ny.gov.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Name: Pawn Shop Laws and Regulations Law
Permit Description:
A license must be obtained from the local government (City, Village, Town, or County) in order to carry on the business of collateral loan broker also known as a pawn shop. In addition, a licensed collateral loan broker must file a registration statement with the New York State Comptroller in order to carry on the business. The registration helps to ensure that the Comptroller can update Collateral Loan Brokers on the filing requirements under the NYS Abandoned Property Law. 
 
To view applicable laws for collateral loan brokers (pawn shops), please see the NYS General Business Law, Article 5 - Collateral Loan Brokers through the link below. 
 
To view applicable New York State's Codes, Rules and Regulations (NYCRR) for collateral loan brokers (pawn shops), please see Title 2, Chapter 1, Part 13 - Accounts Payable From State Funds and Funds Under Its Control'.  View 'Part 15. Collateral Loan Brokers' through the link below.

Towing services are a taxable service.

Permit Description:
An Automobile Broker Business is any person who, for a fee, commission, or other valuable consideration paid by a consumer offers to provide, provides, or represents that he will provide a service of purchasing, arranging, assisting or affecting the purchase of an automobile as an agent, a broker or an intermediary for a consumer.  An automobile broker business does not include any person registered as a dealer pursuant to Article 16 of the NYS Vehicle and Traffic Law or any person who sells, offers for sale or acts as an agent, a broker or an intermediary in effecting the purchase of three or less automobile in any calendar year.  
 
NYS General Business Law requires that an automobile broker business maintain a surety bond in the amount of $75,000 and that the bond is filed with the NYS Department of State.  The bond form can be downloaded from the NYS Department of State's website.  For more information, visit the NYS Department of State's website. 
 
To view applicable laws for automobile brokers, visit the NYS Legislature's website.  Select the link below for New York General Business Law Article 35-B – Automobile Broker Business.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
If you have a bakery shop business where you sell food or food products, the sales of these items may be exempt from sales tax. (Generally, food stores and similar establishments can sell food and food products exempt from sales tax; however, there are exceptions.) Visit the Tax Department’s website through the link below to see which kinds of food are subject to sales tax and which are exempt when sold by food stores and similar establishments, including bakery shops, supermarkets, grocery stores, convenience stores, and so on. 

In addition, your bakery shop may be able to purchase machinery and equipment tax free if it is used directly and predominantly (more than 50% of the time) in the production of tangible personal property for sale.

Permit Description:
When food or drink is sold for on-premises consumption, it is taxable, whether it is sold hot or cold. On-premises consumption includes consumption at:

• restaurants and diners,
• tables in a food court at a mall, and
• picnic tables located outside a drive-in restaurant.

When the food and drink is sold by a restaurant to-go, it is taxable unless:

• the food (other than sandwiches) or drink is being sold unheated, and
• it is being sold in the same way (in the same form, condition, quantities, and packaging) you would normally find it in a supermarket or grocery store.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
The MCTMT is imposed on certain employers and self-employed individuals engaged in business within the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD), which includes the counties of New York, Bronx, Kings, Queens, Richmond, Rockland, Nassau, Suffolk, Orange, Putnam, Dutchess, and Westchester. 

If you are an employer who does business within the MCTD, you need to compute, report, and pay the MCTMT if:
• you are required to withhold New York State income tax from wages; and 
• your payroll expense exceeds $312,500 in any calendar quarter. 

If you are self-employed and do business within the MCTD, you need to compute, report, and pay the MCTMT if your net earnings within the MCTD exceed $50,000.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: NYS Minority and Women Business Development (MWBE) Program
Permit Description:
Empire State Developments’ Division of Minority and Women’s Business (MWBE) Development (DMWBD) is designed to promote equality of economic opportunities for MWBEs and to eliminate barriers to their participation in state contracts. The important objectives of the program are to:

• Encourage and assist state agencies to award a fair share of contracts to MWBEs.
• Review applications by businesses seeking certification and maintain a NYS Directory of Certified Firms MWBEs.
• Promote the business development of MWBEs through education and outreach to NYS agencies and as well as MWBEs.

For information on becoming a New York State certified minority or woman-owned business (MWBE), contact the Empire State Development Office, Division of Minority and Women's Business Development, at the link below.
Permit Categories: General Business Information

Permit Description: Motor Vehicle Dealers who are registered with the NYS Department of Motor Vehicles are eligible to participate in the Dealer Plate Issuance Program.  This program enables dealers to issue a Temporary Certificate of Registration and, when appropriate, to issue permanent registration plates and/or interstate In-transit Permits.  To be eligible for this program, you must be a registered retail dealer of passenger vehicles, commercial vehicles, motorcycles, trailers, or ATVs for at least one year as well as meet other requirements.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description:
A health care practitioner's authority to perform health services in an office setting is established by that practitioner's license to practice his or her profession according the NYS Education Law.  The care delivered in such offices is expected to meet prevailing standards of care for the licensed profession set forth by the NYS Department of Health.

To view applicable New York State's Codes, Rules and Regulations (NYCRR) for medical facilities, see the link below.  

Under the U.S. Controlled Substances Act of 1970, all health care professionals wanting to dispense, administer, or prescribe controlled drugs must register with the Drug Enforcement Administration.  For information and guidelines, contact the U.S. Department of Justice, Drug Enforcement Administration, Diversion Control Program or  visit their website.  The processing and issuing of a DEA registration takes about four to six weeks.  

New York also has requirements and guidelines that health care practitioners need to follow regarding the dispensing, administering and prescribing of controlled substances as well as the use and disposal of hypodermic syringes and needles.  Visit the NYS Department of Health, Bureau of Narcotic Enforcement website for regulatory requirements.  

NYS Public Health Law, Article 2, Section 230-d requires a practice that performs office-based surgical or other invasive procedures using moderate sedation, deep sedation or under general anesthesia to the patient in order to perform the procedure or liposuction of greater than 500cc's of fat to become accredited on or before July 14, 2009.   A physician, physician assistant or specialist assistant, who wishes to perform procedures in an office setting, must perform the office-based surgery or other invasive procedure in an office that is accredited.  Some examples of office-based surgical or invasive procedures are endoscopy and colonoscopy, bronchoscopy, rhinoplasty, augmentation or reduction mammoplasty, and herniorrhaphy.   

The NYS Department of Health has designated three accrediting agencies.  The practice is required to have completed the process and received its Certificate of Accreditation on or prior to July 14, 2009 by one of these designated accrediting agencies.  For a list of accrediting agencies approved by the NYS Department of Health, see the link below.  

A practice or facility that is licensed through the NYS Public Health Law, Article 28 is not required to follow this law.  Examples of an Article 28 facility may include:  a hospital, an urgent care center, an ambulatory care center or a diagnostic and treatment center.  

This law does not cover procedures performed by dentists and podiatrists who are not regulated by the NYS Department of Health.  The NYS Education Department has guidelines for office-based surgery and conscious sedation that applies to dentists and podiatrist who are not regulated by the NYS Department of Health.  To view these guidelines, see the links below.

NYS Public Health Law, Article 2, Section 230-d and Article 29-D, Section 2998-e requires office-based surgeries performed by physicians, physician assistants, specialist assistants and dentists who are dually licensed as physicians to report adverse events, which are related to or may be related to an office-base surgery procedure.  A physician, physician assistant, or specialist assistance who believes that a patient complaint, complication, condition, emergency room visit, hospital admission or death that may be related to an office-based surgery must report the event to the NYS Health Department's Patient Safety Center within one business day of the occurrence of the adverse event.  For further information and forms to report an adverse event, visit the NYS Department of Health's website.

Physicians, osteopaths, dentists, midwives, nurse practitioners or podiatrist who perform laboratory tests or procedures, personally or through his or her employees, solely as an addition to the t
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care,Professional Licenses

Permit Description: The New York Vehicle Inspection Program (NYVIP2) helps New York comply with the Federal Clean Air Act to decrease the emissions from motor vehicles, and reduce air pollution.  The NYVIP2 includes a check of the on-board diagnostic system on vehicles that have a model year of 1996 and newer and that have a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) of less than 8,501 pounds.  In order for inspection stations to conduct safety inspections or emissions inspection for light-duty vehicles that weigh 18,000 lbs. or less, they must participate in the NYVIP2.  A NYS-licensed inspection station must purchase the NYVIP2 equipment from Systech.  For inspection stations to conduct safety inspections or emissions inspections for diesel-powered vehicles with a maximum gross weight (MGW) of more than 8,500 lbs. and the vehicle is registered in the Diesel Emissions Metropolitan Area (DEMA), the station must purchase a DMV-approved smokemeter.

If your business is a sole proprietorship that has New York source income, you may be required to make estimated tax payments to New York State if the income is taxable and not subject to withholding (such as self-employment income; pension or annuity income; and interest and dividend income) or MCTMT.

To learn more, visit the NYS Tax Department's website and the Internal Revenue Services's website through the links below.

Permit Description: Roadside stands, on-farm outlets and farmers markets are not required to obtain a retail food store license from the Department of Agriculture and Markets, however, they are subject to regular inspection with respect to compliance to the New York State food sanitation requirements contained in Article 17 of the Agriculture and Markets Law.  Also, certain food products may not be sold at roadside stands, on-farm outlets and farmers markets.  All packaged food products sold at roadside stands, on-farm outlets and farmers markets must be properly labeled in accordance with New York State food labeling requirements.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description: Producers, processors, packers, distributors, or retailers of Kosher food products, as well as a person who certifies food products as Kosher, or an operator of a food establishment who prepares Kosher food, may need to file product and certifying information with the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets.  For more information, contact the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets.

Permit Description:
Local government entities regulate the trade of plumbing as outlined in NYS General City Law, Article 4. To obtain a certificate of competency to conduct the trade or business of plumbing, one must pass an exam.   There are also specific signs that must be obtained and posted where the business is being conducted. Contact your local plumbing board for the licensing requirements in your area. 
 
Applicable Laws:  
 
The NYS General City Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
NYC REQUIREMENTS: 
 
Only licensed master plumbers and their employees may perform plumbing work in New York City.  A plumbing permit must also be obtained before any work begins.  The NYC Building Code defines plumbing work as 'the installation, maintenance, repair, modification extension or alteration of any waste, domestic water, gas, or firestandpipes in any building or piping system'.  NYC also issues a license for fire suppression and piping contractors.     
 
For information regarding the requirements, applications and scheduled test dates, contact the NYC Department of Citywide Administrative Services.  The New York City Department of Buildings issues the license for master plumbers after they have passed the examination and have cleared a background check.  To apply for a master plumbers license, contact their office or visit their website. 
 
Mercury Management:  Plumbers traditionally use pressure gauges (manometer) that are easily broken.  There are many alternatives to the traditional manometers and plumbers are encouraged to replace them with ones without mercury as the indicator.  For information about safety measures to take in using and disposing of the manometers and available alternatives to replace them, visit the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's website, call their office or go to the Laws link provided below. 
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations listed below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Construction

Permit Description: The NYS Department of Education, Office of Professions has requirements for professional licensing.  Some professionals practice their profession as individual licensed practitioners; others practice in some sort of corporate or business entity structure.  Not all business structures may legally provide professional services.  Generally, licensed professionals may not set up a general business corporation to provide professional services.  For information on professional licensing requirements or filing for a professional business entity, contact the NYS Department of Education, Office of the Professions or see the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care,Professional Licenses

Permit Description: Retailers that sell covered rechargeable batteries are required to accept used rechargeable batteries from consumers during normal business hours and will need to post signs informing consumers about the requirement to recycle their used rechargeable batteries.  Manufacturers of covered rechargeable batteries or groups of collaborating manufacturers are responsible for financing the collection and recycling of the batteries.  The types of rechargeable batteries covered are:  nickel-cadmium, sealed lead, lithium ion, nickel metal hydride, any other such dry cell batteries capable of being recharged and battery packs containing any of the listed batteries.  For more information on requirements, visit the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's website or see the links below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
Reiki is a technique used to promote stress reduction, relaxation and natural healing.  Reiki is a hands-on technique.  Practitioners place their hands in a series of positions on a client.  Energy travels through the practitioner's hands to the client.  Reiki practitioners believe that when Reiki energy flows freely and balanced, the body becomes healthy. 
 
The New York State Board for Massage Therapy has determined that a massage therapy license is not required to practice Reiki.  The Board defines the practice of Reiki as channeling energy to a person to use as needed without any manipulation, pressure or vibration of tissue.  For further information, contact the NYS Board for Massage Therapy or see the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care

They provide volunteer mentors who share their expertise; free and confidential  business counseling; free online business tools, templates and tip; and business workshops and webinars.  SCORE is a resource partner with the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA).   For more information and to locate an office, view the link below.

Permit Name: Sales Tax on Passenger Transportation Services
Permit Description: New York State and local sales tax applies to certain types of passenger transportation services. Sales tax applies to transportation services provided by livery services, including limousines, black cars, and certain other motor vehicles (for example, community cars or vans) with a driver. There are exemptions for taxis, buses, and any scheduled public service. The transportation services are subject to sales tax only if the service begins and ends in New York State (intrastate service). For more information on sales tax requirements for transportation services see the links below.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Social security benefits are available to self-employed persons just as they are to wage earners.  Your payments of self-employment tax contribute to your coverage under the social security system. Use the link below to view more information.

Permit Name: Unclaimed Funds Reporting (NYS Abandoned Property Law)
Permit Description: Businesses must comply with the New York State Abandoned Property Law which requires organizations to annually review their records and transfer accounts that have reached certain dormancy thresholds to the State Comptroller, who serves as custodian of the funds until they can be returned to their rightful owners.  To assist organizations with this process, the State Comptroller's Office of Unclaimed Funds provides a Handbook for Reporters of Unclaimed Funds.  You may request this publication or more information on the requirements of the NYS Abandoned Property Law by contacting the NYS Comptroller's Office directly.
Permit Categories: General Business Information

Permit Description: A UPC (Universal Product Code) is the standard bar code symbology for product marking.  They are usually obtained by manufacturers of products for use in retail packaging.  In the United States, you must register with GS1-US (formerly the Uniform Code Council (UCC)) to be assigned a unique company identification number for use on all your products. The unique company identification number which is a 6 or 7-digit number, is the first part of the product UPC code. The remaining 6 digits are assigned by the company for a specific product. There is no law that says products must contain a bar code.   However, many national retail chains and most grocery stores require all products they sell to have a bar code that is unique for the specific product. Contact information provided below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Manufacturing,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Name: Workers' Compensation/Disability and Paid Family Leave Benefits Insurance Requirement for Permit Issuance
Permit Description: Workers' Compensation Law requires that all businesses, including out-of-state businesses, applying for permits, licenses or contracts with municipal and state entities have appropriate workers' compensation and disability and paid family leave benefits coverage.  To comply with coverage provisions, a business must:  be legally exempt from the requirement; obtain New York State coverage from an insurance carrier; be a New York State Workers' Compensation Board approved self-insured employer; or participate in an authorized New York State group self-insurance plan.
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Description: NYS Environmental Conservation Law requires service stations that annually sell 500 gallons of oil and retailers that annually sell 1,000 gallons of oil to accept, free of charge, up to five gallons of used oil per person per day for recycling.  Service stations and retailers may temporarily refuse to accept used oil only if their used oil holding tanks are full.  Retailers that cannot provide collection and storage for used oil may contract with another establishment to provide these services. The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's pamphlet entitled "Quick Guide to New York’s Used Oil Regulations" provides additional information.

State law requires us to accept vehicle batteries free of charge for recycling."

Under the U.S. Controlled Substances Act of 1970, all health care professionals wanting to dispense, administer, or prescribe controlled drugs must register with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration.  The link to the FDA Regulatory Information is below.  

New York State has requirements that health care practitioners need to follow regarding the dispensing, administering and prescribing of controlled substances as well as the use and disposal of hypodermic syringes and needles. The link to the NYS Legislature Law is below.

Penal Law Section 220.65 has been amended to include information about the criminal sale of controlled substance prescriptions by a practitioner or pharmacist.  For more information see the Penal Law link below.

Penal Law Section 178.26 has been amended to address deceit related to controlled substances.  The link to the Penal Law affected, is below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care

Permit Description:
New York State, through the State Department of Health, licenses and supervises adult care facilities which provide temporary or long-term, non-medical residential care services to adults who are substantially unable to live independently.  
 
Special Needs Assisted Living Residence 
A Special Needs Assisted Living Residence (SNALR) means a residence which provides or arranges for housing, on-site monitoring, and personal care services and/or home care services (either directly or indirectly), in a home-like setting to five or more adult residents unrelated to the assisted living operator.  No adult home, enriched housing program, or ALR (Assisted Living Residence) may advertise or market itself as providing specialized services unless and until the residence has been licensed as an ALR and issued a special needs assisted living certificate. Services provided to individuals with special needs can include dementia, cognitive impairments, behavioral, medical or functional care needs.  For further information, contact the NYS Department of Health's Division of Home and Community Based Care, or visit their website. 
 
Adult Home 
An adult home is established and operated for the purpose of providing long-term residential care, room, board, housekeeping, personal care and supervision to five or more adults unrelated to the operator. Adult homes may be operated by a natural person, a partnership, a not-for-profit corporation, a public corporation, a non-publicly traded business corporation or a limited liability company. 
 
Assisted Living Program 
An assisted living program, which is available in some adult homes and enriched housing programs, combines residential and home care services. It is designed as an alternative to nursing home placement for individuals who historically have been admitted to nursing facilities for reasons that are primarily social, rather than medical in nature. The operator of the assisted living program is responsible for providing or arranging for resident services that must include room, board, housekeeping, supervision, personal care, case management and home health services. 
 
Enriched Housing Program 
An enriched housing program is established and operated for the purpose of providing long-term residential care to five or more adults, primarily persons sixty-five years of age or older, in community-integrated settings resembling independent housing units. The program provides or arranges for the provision of room, board, housekeeping, personal care and supervision. Enriched housing programs may be operated by a natural person, a partnership, a not-for-profit corporation, a public corporation, a non-publicly traded business corporation or a limited liability company. 
 
Not For Profit 
Not For Profit is defined as an Adult Care Facility. 
 
Private Proprietary Home for Adults 
Private Proprietary is defined in Title 18NYCRR, Part 487.2(b) of the Department Regulations as an adult care facility which is operated for compensation and profit. 
 
Residence - Residence For Adults 
A residence for adults is established and operated for the purpose of providing long-term residential care, room, board; housekeeping and supervision to five or more adults, unrelated to the operator. 
 
Based on new legislation, signed into law July 23 2014, an adult care facility may temporarily approve, based on certain conditions, a direct-care prospective employee while the results of the criminal history information check is being conducted. For further information, contact the agency or see the law links below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care

Permit Description: Businesses such as supermarkets, grocery stores, and delis can purchase meat processing equipment exempt from sales tax if it is used directly and predominantly (more than 50% of the time) in the production of tangible personal property for sale. To qualify for exemption, the equipment must be used directly and predominantly in production of food commonly sold by grocery stores, and not used to prepare "restaurant-type" food (food or drink sold for on-premises consumption, sandwiches, self-service salad bars, food or drink sold in a heated state, and unheated beverages that are not sold in the same form, condition, quantities and packaging as they are ordinarily sold in grocery stores). Equipment used to cook, prepare, or package restaurant-type food for sale is taxable.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
"Maternal Depression" means a wide range of emotional and psychological reactions a woman may experience during pregnancy or after childbirth. These reactions may include, but are not limited to, feelings of despair or extreme guilt, prolonged sadness, lack of energy, difficulty concentrating, fatigue, extreme changes in appetite, and thoughts of suicide or of harming the baby. Maternal depression may include prenatal depression, the 'baby blues", postpartum depression, or postpartum psychosis - - the severest form.  
 
The following information shall be made available to maternal health care providers relating to maternal depression:  
 
1) A summary of the current evidence base and professional guidelines for maternal depression screening  
2) Validated, evidence-based tools for maternal depression screening  
3) Information about follow-up support for patients who may require further evaluation, referral, or treatment including, when available, information about specific community resources and entities licensed by the Office of Mental Health, and  
4) Information on engaging support for the mother, which may include communicating with the other parent of the child and other family members, as appropriate and consistent with patient confidentiality  
 
Information shall also be posted on the Department of Health's website.  
 
Based on new legislation, signed into law August 4, 2014 with an effective date of January 28, 2015, the Public Health Law and Insurance Law have been amended in relation to the provision of maternal depression, education, screening guidelines, and referrals of treatment. For further information, see the law links below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care

Permit Description:
In general, admission charges to amusement parks are subject to sales tax.  Amusement parks have a number of different ways of charging for admission to the park and for the use of the rides and other facilities at the park. Depending on how your amusement park operates and your method of charging for admission, special rules may apply. Visit theTax Department's website through the link below.
   
The New York State Department of Labor enforces amusement ride safety throughout the state, except in New York City. Labor Department employees inspect all rides at stationary amusement parks at least once a year, and inspect rides at traveling fairs or carnivals every time the ride is set up in a new location. A ride cannot be operated without a permit from the Department of Labor. 
 
The International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions link below is for reference purposes only and does not constitute an endorsement.  However, it may be a valuable source of information, services, and advice for your business.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Budget Planner 
Only type B not-for-profit corporations as defined in section 201 of the not-for-profit corporation law of New York, or an entity incorporated in another state having a similar not-for-profit status, shall engage in the business of budget planning. 
 
For further information, contact the agency directly.
