Permit Description:
The NYS Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code (Uniform Code) prescribes minimum standards for both fire prevention and building construction. The primary responsibility for enforcing the code belongs to the cities, towns, villages and counties also known as the authority having jurisdiction. It requires that the municipalities issue building permits to ensure that minimum safety standards are met and that construction complies with the Uniform Code. Although the codes are uniform throughout the state, each municipality may have their own specific additional regulations and procedures for enforcement. 

Building permits are required for changes to properties and structures including work such as new construction, demolition, renovation/remodeling and replacement. Building permits usually require:

1. Zoning Approval – The authority having jurisdiction may require proposed construction to comply with relevant zoning laws. 

2. A completed application including construction plans or drawings, specifications and other detailed project information as necessary. A NYS licensed Professional Engineer (PE) or Registered Architect (RA) may need to prepare the plans and specifications where required by NYS Education Law.

3. Proof of Insurance – Worker's compensation insurance and disability benefits coverage is required prior to issuance of a building permit per NYS Workers Compensation Law. Certification of contractor's liability insurance allowing for coverage of damage to property while work is being done may also be required. 

4. Once approved, building permits are required to be displayed on the property or premise that it pertains to. 

5. Building inspectors conduct inspections during certain phases of construction to determine if the work was performed in accordance with the Uniform Code and application documents. 

Once construction is complete, a certificate of occupancy or a certificate of compliance is obtained. A certificate of occupancy grants permission for the use of a building or structure for a specific type of use or occupancy as defined in the approved building permit. 

The Authority having jurisdiction may require plumbing and electrical work to be an additional or separate permit(s). Inspections for electrical work and various other portions of construction must be made by an approved third party inspection agency.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
A Certificate of Occupancy or C/O is a certification issued, in the majority of cases, by the municipal buildings department where a building is located indicating that it is safe to occupy and stating the legal permissible uses of the building.   A Certificate of Occupancy is usually required any time a new business opens, there is an ownership change of an existing business, an existing business relocates or changes names, there is a change in the use of a commercial building, or to secure a business license.  Most certificates are issued after an inspection is performed and the building is deemed to comply with building, fire, and other applicable code provisions.  A fee is usually required.  
 
Below is a link to Resources for Local Governments.
Permit Categories: General Business Information

Permit Description:
New York State's Returnable Container Act requires you to collect a $.05 deposit on beverage containers containing less than one gallon of carbonated soft drinks, beer, malt beverages, wine coolers or water, sold in New York State.

Additionally, as a deposit initiator you must: 

• register online with the Tax Department as a deposit initiator before you make any sales;

• establish a refund value account;

• keep track of all deposits that you collect; and

• file quarterly reports and remit 80% of unclaimed deposits to the Tax Department online.


The New York Codes Rules and Regulations, Title 6 Part 367, Returnable Beverage Containers clarifies the provisions of the Returnable Container Act. This regulation applies to all transactions involving the sale, use or consumption of beverages in beverage containers in New York State. To view applicable New York State Codes, Rules and Regulations (NYCRR), visit the link below. 

The NYS Returnable Container Act is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 

For additional information about your requirements and New York's Returnable Container Act, visit the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's website and the NYS Tax Department’s website. 

Below is a brief description and responsibilities of the deposit and redemption system:

A Beverage Manufacturer is a brewer, soft drink bottler, etc.  A beverage manufacturer must determine the amount of the deposit and place the deposit label information on the containers. The lettering must be at least 1/8 inch high and must indicate ‘New York' or ‘N.Y.' and the amount of the deposit.  Manufacturers may also initiate the deposit on refillable containers.

A Beverage Distributor is a beverage manufacturer and/or wholesaler who sells beverages to a dealer or retailer. In addition, someone who owns a private label, purchases beverages directly from the manufacturer in containers marked with that label, then sells the beverage at retail is also considered a beverage distributor.  Distributors charge a deposit when selling beverages to retailers. Distributors must accept from dealers and redemption centers all containers of the same type they sell.  In addition to paying the refund, the distributor must pay a 3.5 cent handling fee per container to the dealer or redemption center. Distributors must pick up empties, at their expense, from dealers and redemption centers.

A Redemption Center pays the refund value of an empty beverage container to a redeemer, or any person who contracts with one or more dealers or distributors to collect, sort and obtain the refund value and handling fee of empty beverage containers for or on behalf of such dealer(s) or distributor(s). To establish a redemption center, an entity or person needs to determine the type of empty beverage containers to accept and must provide written notice to the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation, Solid Waste Reduction and Recycling. The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation will review the written notice and, if approved, will issue a registration number. The written notice must have the following information: Name, address and telephone number of owner(s); Name of operator and address of place of business of the redemption center; Name and address of any dealer(s) served or under contract; Name and address of distributor(s) served or under contract; and General geographic area served. 

A retailer selling beverages in deposit containers for consumers to take away from the premises is a dealer. Dealers must pay deposits to distributors when they purchase beverages and receive deposits from consumers when the beverage is sold. Dealers must refund the deposit on all containers of the same type regardless of where the container was originally purchased. Dealers, or their contracted sorting services (a redemption center), must sort containers for the distributor. The dealer, or whoever sorts the containers for the distributor(s), is enti
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
NYS Penal Law allows a dealer in firearms and pharmacists licensed pursuant to NYS Education Law, Article 137 to sell self-defense spray devices.  The law limits the sale to no more than two self-defense spray devices at one time to a single purchaser.  The purchaser must provide proof of age. 
 
For further information, see the links below.

Permit Description: If you will be making sales in New York State that are subject to sales tax, you must register with the Tax Department and obtain a Certificate of Authority. The Certificate of Authority gives you the right to collect sales tax on your taxable sales and to issue and accept most New York State sales tax exemption certificates.

Permit Name: Ongoing Filing Requirements for Sales Tax
Permit Description: Once you're registered for sales tax in New York State, you must file sales and use tax returns quarterly, part-quarterly (monthly), or annually with the Tax Department. You must file a sales tax return by its due date, even if you have no tax due for the filing period. Most businesses are required to file their sales tax returns online.

The auction or public sale of domestic animals such as cattle, swine, or horses to the highest bidders in New York State, requires the auctioneer to hold a NYS Domestic Animal Health Permit issued by the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets.  New York's laws and regulations contain sanitation and physical requirements for stables, livestock auction buildings or other buildings used for the housing of domestic animals at auction to prevent the spread of infection among animals, as well as the inspection of the stables and buildings.

Permit Description:
A bathing beach operated as part of a temporary residence for the use of occupants, guests, invitees or employees shall be constructed, maintained and operated so as to comply with the provisions of subpart 6-2 of the NY State Sanitary Code.   A separate permit shall not be required for a summer day camp, bathing beach, swimming pool or a service food establishment operated as part of a temporary residence for which a permit is required.

Permit Description:
Biodiesel is a clean burning alternative fuel, or biofuel, produced from domestic, renewable resources.  In the United States, most biodiesel is made from soybean oil.  However, canola oil, sunflower oil, recycled cooking oils, palm oil, animal fats, and other oils are also used as feedstock.  Biodiesel is typically manufactured through a process called 'trans-esterification'.  This process uses an industrial alcohol (typically methanol) and a catalyst (sodium methylate or sodium hydroxide) to convert the base plant oil or animal fat into a fatty-acid mono-alkyl ester fuel, known as biodiesel, with glycerin as a byproduct. Biodiesel in its pure form is known as B100.  It can be blended with conventional diesel fuel to create an alternative motor vehicle fuel or for other uses. 
 
The National Biodiesel Board (NBB) is the national trade association of the biodiesel industry and is the coordinating body for biodiesel research and development in the United States.  The NBB maintains a library of biodiesel information, as well as a list of registered fuel marketers.  For more information, visit their website or contact them.   
 
Fuel-grade biodiesel must be produced to strict industry specifications in order to insure proper performance.  ASTM International is the governing board that sets testing methods and standards for evaluating all types of substances including automotive fuels and oils.  The standard set of tests for determining the quality of biodiesel is ASTM D6751.  Biodiesel that meets ASTM D6751 and is legally registered with the U. S. Environmental Protection Agency is a legal motor fuel for sale and distribution.  For information on these standards for biodiesel, contact ASTM International.  
 
The National Biodiesel Accreditation Program is a cooperative and voluntary program for the accreditation of producers and marketers of biodiesel fuel called BQ-9000. The program is a unique combination of the ASTM standard for biodiesel, ASTM D6751, and a quality systems program that includes storage, sampling, testing, blending, shipping, distribution, and fuel management practices.   BQ-9000 is open to any biodiesel manufacturer, marketer or distributor of biodiesel and biodiesel blends in the United States and Canada.  For more information, visit their website or contact them.  
 
The permits and regulations that are required to construct and/or operate a biodiesel production facility are dependent upon the size of the plant and the location.  Listed below are some of the State, Federal and local government agencies that we recommend contacting before finalizing your business plans. 
 
The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation oversees the many environmental concerns that must be addressed with the production of biodiesel, including air emissions, the generation and disposal of waste-water, storage requirements, and the disposal of by-products. To obtain information on the required environmental permits for biodiesel production, contact the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation, Division of Environmental Permits and Pollution Prevention. 
 
The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's Air Quality Regulations, 6 NYCRR, Part 236, requires emission control, monitoring, repair, reporting and record keeping requirements. Link is provided below.  Compliance with Part 236 may require an Air Pollution Control permit.   
 
Depending on the amount of waste-water discharged during the biodiesel process, a State Pollution Discharge Elimination System (SPDES) Permit or National Pollution Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) Permit may be required.   
 
Storage tanks may need to be registered under the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's chemical bulk storage regulations.  Some ingredients used for the manufacture of biodiesel are considered hazardous substances and depending on the amount, may be subject to Part 596 of the NYS Environmental Conservation Law, Hazardous Substance Bulk Storage Re
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Manufacturing

Permit Description:
The NYS Department of Health, under the statutory authority of Public Health Law Article 4A, is currently developing statewide health regulations for tattooing and body piercing. For information on requirements as well as guidelines, visit the NYS Department of Health's website or contact them directly.  You can also contact the Local County or City Health Department.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

The disease to consider during body piercing and/or tattooing procedures is hepatitis. Hepatitis, unlike HIV, is a very hardy virus that can survive long periods outside the human body and may transmit through little more than a scratch with an infected needle. To combat this and any other infectious blood-borne pathogen, body piercing and/or tattoo specialist should autoclave their single service equipment, use individual portions of ink and lubricant, dispose of used sharps according to OSHA guidelines, use EPA registered virucidals to clean their stations between clients, and use barrier protection. These procedures are called Standard Precautions.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) urges consumers and practitioners to report any problems with permanent or temporary tattoos by contacting the FDA's Office by telephone or visit the nearest FDA district office, with the link below.  

The suggested guidelines below provide minimum standards for infection control to prevent transmission of blood-borne disease during body piercing and/or tattooing.  They are not intended to be a comprehensive review of infection control issues nor do they address all aspects of environmental sanitation in the body piercing and/or tattoo studios.  Consult with the local public health agency or trade associations for additional recommendations.

STERILE NEEDLES:

1.  All needles that penetrate the skin must be sterile.
2.  Only single use pre-packaged disposable needles shall be used.

Of the four methods of sterilization (steam heat, dry heat, liquid chemical germicides, ethylene oxide gas) the most reliable and practical sterilization method for body piercing and/or tattoo specialist is steam heat using an autoclave.

Autoclaves provide a fairly rapid sterilization cycle and can be monitored to ensure proper sterilization temperatures.  Although the time/temperature may vary slightly according to each autoclave, manufacturer cycles generally involve 250-273 degrees Fahrenheit for 30-35 minutes (from hot start) at 15-30 pounds per square inch (PSI).  Spore indicators should be used weekly and heat sensitive chemical indicator tape (changes color with heat) should be used on the outside wrapping and inside of each pack placed in the autoclave.  Manufacturer's instructions must be strictly followed.

Dry heat is not felt to be acceptable according to many in the body piercing and/or tattoo industry due to the time involved in the cycle (two hours at 350 degrees Fahrenheit) and harmful effects of high temperature on certain pieces of equipment.

Liquid Chemical Germicides are generally not acceptable for sterilization due to the long time interval required (up to ten hours), toxicity, corrosiveness, and lack of an easy to use monitoring method to gauge effectiveness.

Gas sterilization methods, such as ethylene oxide, require specialized equipment, are difficult to handle, and have special ventilation requirements.

CLEAN INSTRUMENTS AND EQUIPMENT:

Instruments/equipment that may occasionally become blood contaminated fall into two categories:

1.  Disposable Type (such as shaving razors, tattoo dye, and dye cups); these items must be discarded after each use and not reused for another client.
2.  Reusable Type (such as needle tubes, scissors, tweezers, power supply hand pieces); these items must be washed to remove blood and then sterilized before re-use.

Use of sterile, pre-packaged, single-use disposable equipment is preferred.  When reusable instruments/equipment are used, a three-step cleaning process is necessary:

1.  Wash instruments/equipme

Permit Description:
Local government entities license construction contractors.  In New York, the Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Codes governs the construction industry by addressing issues of fire prevention, life safety, structural stability, and accommodations for people with disabilities.  The code applies to all communities across New York, except in New York City, which has its own building code.  The NYS Department of State, Division of Code Enforcement and Administration regulates and interprets the NYS Building Codes.  You can contact them for further information or visit their website.   The Codes of New York State are available from the International Code Council for a fee.  Contact them for more information.

NYS Department of Environmental Conservation regulations require construction projects that disturb one or more acres of land to acquire a SPDES General Permit for Stormwater Discharges before the construction activity begins.  For more information on requirements, contact your local NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's Regional Office or visit their website. 

The distinctions between an employee and an independent contractor in the construction industry are vital regarding insurance requirements as well as for federal tax purposes.  To obtain a determination, contact the NYS Department of Labor, Liability and Determination Section, or visit their website at.  The Internal Revenue Service also has information on clarification as an employee or as an independent contractor, request Form SS-8, Determination of Employees Work Status for Purposes of Federal Employment Taxes and Income Tax Withholding and Publication 15-A, Employer's Supplemental Tax Guide or visit the links below.

For New York State tax requirements pertaining to the construction industry, contact the agency directly or visit their website.  Refer to Publication 862, New York State Sale and Use Tax Classifications of Capital Improvements and Repairs to Real Property; Form ST-120.1 Contractor Exempt Purchase Certificate; Form ST-124 Certificate of Capital Improvement; and Form AU-298 Application for a Direct Payment Permit for additional information and requirements.  Their links are below.

The NYS Office of General Services, Design and Construction Group Marketing Unit awards competitively bid contracts for use by State agencies, political subdivisions and other organizations authorized by law to purchase services from State contracts.  These contracts offer construction and consultant services.  The Empire State Builder is OGS Design and Construction Group's public notification service of construction and consultant contract bidding opportunities.  Each week, this publication provides information on:  construction contracts with plans and specifications currently available for purchase; a listing of plans purchasers for contracts to bid; bid results; future construction contracting opportunities; and other relevant OGS contracting notices. For further information contact the NYS Office of General Services, Design and Construction Group Marketing Unit office or visit their website.

OGS encourages the participation of minorities and women in its procurement and building construction projects.  The Empire State Development, Division of Minority and Women's Business Development's program assists the growth and development of businesses owned and controlled by women and minority groups.  To obtain information on becoming certified in New York contact the Empire State Development, Division of Minority and Women's Business Development  or visit their website.

The NYS Department of Labor helps businesses, including construction businesses, comply with federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standards.  The NYS Department of Labor's On-Site Consultation Services Bureau provides free on-site guidance to private employers to help businesses determine whether they are in compliance with Federal safety and health standards and to show th
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Construction

Permit Description:
New York State may require some producers of cosmetics to comply with the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's Regulation, Part 233, Pharmaceutical and Cosmetic Manufacturing Processes.  To learn more about or how to comply with this New York State regulation, contact the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation, Division of Air Resources, Bureau of Stationary Sources or visit their website.  The NYS Environmental Facilities Corporation, Small Business Assistance Program, provides assistance to complete the application form as well as help applicants comply with and understand the permit requirements once it is issued.

Cosmetics marketed in the United States, whether manufactured here or imported from abroad, must comply with the provisions and regulations of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and the Fair Packaging and Labeling Act.  The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act defines cosmetics by their intended use, as articles that someone can rub, pour, sprinkle, or spray on, introduce into, or otherwise apply to the human body for cleansing, beautifying, promoting attractiveness, or altering the appearance.  These products include skin moisturizers, creams, lotions and powders; perfume products; finger/toenail polishes, removers and cuticle softeners; makeup (lipsticks, foundation, blush and eye makeup preparations); shaving creams; shampoos (except dandruff); permanent waves; hair colors; mouthwash and toothpastes (except with whiteners or fluoride); bath oils and bubble baths; and deodorants, as well as any material intended for use as a component of a cosmetic product.

Products are considered a drug if they intend to treat or prevent disease or otherwise affect the structure or function of the human body.  Over-the-counter drugs are drugs purchased without a doctor's prescription.  Examples of products that are over-the-counter drugs are fluoride or whitening toothpastes, hormone creams, sunscreen preparations, antiperspirants, acne medications and antidandruff shampoos.  Drugs are subject to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approval.  Generally, drugs must either receive pre-market approval by the FDA or conform to final regulations specifying conditions recognizing them as safe and effective, and not misbranded.  The Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act require drug manufacturers to register every year with the FDA and update their lists of all manufactured drugs twice annually.

Some products meet the definition of both cosmetic and drug.  This may happen when a product has two intended uses.  These types of products must comply with the requirements for both cosmetics and drugs.  Before products are marketed with both a cosmetic and a drug classification, they must prove scientifically safe and effective for their therapeutic claims.

The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act excludes soap from its definition of a cosmetic.  Therefore, soap products are exempt from the FDA's jurisdiction.  The FDA interprets the term ‘soap' as the bulk of the nonvolatile matter in the product that consists of an alkali salt of fatty acids and the product's detergent properties are due to the alkali-fatty acid compounds.  The product is labeled, sold, and represented solely as soap.  In other words, soap products that consist primarily of an alkali salt or fatty acid and make no label claim other than cleansing of the human body are not considered a cosmetic.  Not every product marketed as soap meets this FDA definition.  Soap producers that use certain ingredients, such as lye, to produce soap should contact the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission.  The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission oversees consumer product safety and specifically regulates certain products under the Federal Hazardous Act or the Poison Prevention Packaging Act.  Contact the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission or visit their website  for further information.  If a soap label states a cosmetic or drug claim, then the product mu
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Manufacturing,Licenses and Permits, Retail,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
If you will be making sales in New York State that are subject to sales tax, you must register with the Tax Department and obtain a Certificate of Authority. The Certificate of Authority gives you the right to collect sales tax on your taxable sales and to issue and accept most New York State sales tax exemption certificates. Most items sold by craft vendors are taxable.

Your activity might be regulated at the local level. Please check with local authorities: town, village, city, and county clerk offices. If you are an exhibitor at a show, fair, or festival, the event promoter may have this information.

Event promoters may have packets containing contracts with individual show information (such as show set-up times, booth fees, electrical fees, table rental costs, hotel information, directions, and tax information).

The NYS Tax Department can answer questions pertaining to tax obligations. Please be aware that an exhibitor is required to post in plain view at all times during the show their Certificate of Authority to collect sales tax.

Liability insurance that is designed to cover home-based businesses, that follows you to shows, and covers theft of your product from your vehicle is recommended. Some event exhibits require liability insurance. Contact the NYS Insurance Department or visit their website for information regarding your insurance needs. 

There are three different kinds of show categories. A JURIED show means you must submit slides or photographs of your work which are reviewed by a jury which is a knowledgeable committee that reviews your work and accepts it into the show based on your technical skill, creativity, the medium, and/or other requirements. Some juries are composed of just one or two people screening for quality and trying to block manufactured and/or imported items. 

An OPEN show has strict requirements, as do the juried shows, e.g. the work must be handcrafted by the artisan, although some allow imported and manufactured items be sold alongside handcrafted work. 

An INVITATIONAL show means the exhibitors are invited. Be aware that some invitational shows are actually juried shows which artists or artisans apply, and the normal jury process selects the participants. 

Craftsmen and artists usually prefer to be with other creative people rather than be mixed in with importers, resellers, and manufacturers at an open show. Craft or fine art shows are usually either juried or open. The style of your work, that is traditional, contemporary, country etc. also can dictate the types of shows to exhibit at. Although most shows are mixed, be aware so that you don't exhibit at the wrong show. 

A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business. The 3 associations linked below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
People who provide care for one or two children at a time in addition to the provider's own children, usually in the provider's home, are not required to register with the Office of Children and Family Services.  Day care programs planning to serve three or more children for more than three hours a day on a regular basis are regulated by the Office of Children and Family Services and must be licensed or registered.  Several state and local inspections must be performed during this process.  Local fire and building codes inspections, zoning approvals and health regulations must be met.

All regulated child care providers must have prior experience caring for children and must receive ongoing training in areas such as health and safety, nutrition, and child abuse prevention to maintain a license.  Clearances from the New York State Central Register of Child Abuse and Maltreatment, as well as the New York State Department of Criminal Justice Services are also required.

On or after December 28, 2013 no child care facility or place of public accommodation shall use or have on the premises an unsafe crib.  For information on the revised General Business Law of "Prohibiting the Sales of Unsafe Cribs" see the direct link below.  To also view the Legislature's" Children's Product Safety and Recall Effectiveness Act of 2008", see the link below.

The Office of Children and Family Services provides support for people and organizations that are interested in starting day care programs in their communities. 

Child Care Resource and Referral Agencies (CCRR) provide information to new and prospective child care providers about many aspects of program start-up and maintenance such as: program design, referrals, insurance, budgeting, record keeping, zoning, training, and child and adult food programs.  Contact a Child Care Resource and Referral Agency in your area for more information.

The types of child care licensing are:

CHILD DAY CARE CENTER means a program or facility which is not a residence in which child day care is provided on a regular basis to more than six children for more than three hours per day per child for compensation or otherwise, except those programs providing care as a school-age child care.  A child day care center may provide care for children six weeks through 12 years of age.

FAMILY DAY CARE HOME means a residence in which child day care is provided on a regular basis for more than three hours per day per child for up to eight children for compensation or otherwise.  A family day care home may provide care for children six weeks through 12 years of age.  To download a Family Day Care Providers Handbook visit the NYS Office for Children and Family Services or click the link provided at the bottom.   

GROUP FAMILY DAY CARE HOME means a residence in which child day care is provided on a regular basis for more than three hours per day per child for up to 16 children for compensation or otherwise.  A group family day care home must be operated by a provider and have at least one assistant present during the hours that care is provided.   A group family day care home may provide care for children six weeks through 12 years of age.  To download a Group Family Day Care Providers Handbook visit the NYS Office for Children and Family Services website or click the link provided at the bottom. 

SCHOOL-AGE CHILD CARE PROGRAM means a program or facility which is not a residence in which child day care is provided to an enrolled group of seven or more children during the school year before and/or after the period such children are ordinarily in school or during school lunch periods.  School-age child care programs also may provide care during school holidays and those periods of the year in which school is not in session, including summer vacation.  Such programs must operate consistent with the local school calendar.  A school-age child care program may provide care for school-age children under 13 years of age.

For more i
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Name: Dissolution of a NYS Business Corporation
Permit Description:
The NYS Business Corporation Law, Section 1003 provides a procedure for voluntarily dissolving a corporation by filing a Certificate of Dissolution with the NYS Department of State. The consent of the State Tax Commission is required to voluntarily dissolve a New York business corporation. The corporation must obtain the consent of the State Tax Commission from the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance prior to submitting the Certificate of Dissolution to the Department of State for filing.  The NYS Department of Taxation and Finance grants Consent to Dissolution after a thorough review of its tax files to ensure that the corporation does not owe any tax returns or taxes accrued against the corporation.  A corporation that has dissolved and continues to do business, other than liquidating its assets, will incur additional tax liabilities.   
 
The NYS Department of Taxation and Finance has an automated processing system that will, in most cases, respond to a domestic corporation's request for consent to dissolution within five business days of submission.  Contact the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance  or go to their website.  The NYS Department of Taxation and Finance's Form TR-125 has detailed information on terminating a business corporation. 
 
You must forward the Consent of Dissolution from the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance, a Certificate of Dissolution, and the filing fee of $60 to the NYS Department of State. To obtain a Certificate of Dissolution form use the downloadable form from the NYS Department of State's website, draft your own form according to Section 1003 of the NYS Business Corporation Law, or purchase a form in a legal stationery store.  The effective date of the dissolution is the date filed by the Department of State.  The Department of State will issue an official filing receipt.  This receipt is your proof of filing.   
 
A corporation adopting a resolution or a plan to dissolve the corporation or liquate any of its stock needs to file documentation with the Internal Revenue Service within 30 days after the adoption or plan.  Contact the IRS or visit their website.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
The Bureau of Emergency Medical Services is located within the NYS Department of Health, Office of Health Systems Management.  It is responsible for the general oversight of the EMS system statewide.  It issues agency certifications, conducts periodic inspections of ambulance services and investigates complaints regarding the conduct of certified providers or services.   Applicable New York State Laws and Regulations are linked below. 
 
Federal Requirements: 
 
Under the U.S. Controlled Substances Act of 1970, all health care professionals wanting to dispense, administer, or prescribe controlled drugs must register with the Drug Enforcement Administration.  For information and guidelines, contact the U.S. Department of Justice, Drug Enforcement Administration, Diversion Control Program or by visit their website. The processing and issuing of a DEA registration takes about four to six weeks.   
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations linked below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.

It is unlawful for anyone to resell admission tickets to places of entertainment without a license.  The NYS Arts and Cultural Affairs Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.

Permit Description:
New York State does not license the inspection of fire extinguishers.  Local municipal government agencies, such as municipal building departments, regulate the inspection of fire extinguishers and sprinkler systems.  Certification may be issued to perform inspections that a building is deemed to comply with building, fire, and other applicable code provisions. 
 
NEW YORK STATE REQUIREMENTS:   
 
The NYS General Business Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS:  
 
Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR) 
 
Title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, Parts 100-199 outlines the requirements for handling hazardous materials.  Section 107.805 describes the process for persons to be approved to inspect, test, certify, repair or rebuild a cylinder in accordance with US DOT specifications.  Cylinders that have not been retested in accordance with the Hazardous Materials Regulations may not be charged or refilled with compressed gas or other hazardous materials.  For information on how to become an authorized cylinder requalifier to hydrostatically test DOT specification fire extinguisher cylinders and receive a requalifier identification number (RIN), contact the US Department of Transportation, Hazardous Materials Information Center or visit their website. 
 
The Compressed Gas Association produces pamphlets that are required in the approval process for a RIN.  Obtain pamphlets by going to the link below. 
 
The National Fire Protection Association sets standards for maintaining and testing portable fire extinguishers.  The NFPA 10: Standard For Portable Fire Extinguishers, 2002 edition contains the most widely accepted rules for maintenance, inspection, testing and recharging of portable fire extinguishers.  To purchase a copy, go to the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Construction,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
Food Stamps   
 
For information on how to apply to become an authorized retailer to accept food stamp benefits from customers, visit the US Department of Agriculture, Food & Nutrition Services'(FNS)  website at http://www.fns.usda.gov/fns.  This website also provides information on how to contact the local field office that handles your area and provides an explanation of what food items can be sold for food stamps and what things cannot be sold.  Also available is the booklet, The Food Stamp Program, Training Guide for Retailers. 
 
An application for authorization to accept food stamps may be requested by calling toll free.  The completed application form will need to be returned to the local USDA, Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) field office that is provided in the application package. Any questions regarding the application process or if additional information is needed concerning the authorization of your firm to participate in the Food Stamp program, contact the FNS field office number provided in the application package.  You cannot accept any food stamp benefits until your firm is authorized by USDA.  There are no fees/dues that a retailer must pay for food stamp authorization.  All authorized firms will be issued a Food Stamp Program Authorization Permit. This permit should be displayed in a conspicuous place at the store. 
 
When purchasing an existing business, you cannot accept any food stamp benefits until you are authorized by USDA in your name as the new owner of the business. Any previous owner's authorization is NOT TRANSFERABLE. You must contact the local FNS field office to obtain an application and apply for authorization under your ownership. FNS may impose a fine against any individual, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation or other legal entity not approved by FNS to accept and redeem food stamp benefits for any violation of the provisions of the Food Stamp Act or the program regulations, including violations involving the acceptance of coupons.   
 
WIC (Women, Infants and Children) Coupons 
 
Any retail food store desiring to be authorized to accept WIC coupons must file an application as prescribed by the US Department of Agriculture, Food & Nutrition Service.  A retail food store must meet eligibility determination factors which may be based on, but not limited to, visual inspection, sales records, purchase records, counting of stock keeping units, or other inventory or accounting recordkeeping methods that are customary or reasonable in the retail food industry.  The FNS may require that a retail food store be visited to confirm eligibility for program participation prior to the store being authorized in the program.  Once approved, an authorization card is issued.  For more information on becoming an authorized retailer contact  the New York State Department of Health, Bureau of Supplemental Food Programs, Division of Nutrition.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Name: Foreign Businesses Doing Business in New York
Permit Description:
A foreign business wanting to expand and conduct business in New York must register their business name.  Sole proprietors and partnerships register in the county where the business will be located.  Foreign corporation entities register for authority with the NYS Department of State, Division of Corporations.  Registering your business entity is NOT permission to conduct business in New York.  Some types of businesses require specific New York state licenses to operate.  Contact our office at or visit our website for your New York state business licensing requirements. 
 
A foreign business corporation entity may apply for authority to do business in the State of New York by filing an Application for Authority pursuant to the NYS Business Corporation Law, Section 1304.  The  NYS Business Corporation Law provides that a foreign corporation may not do business in New York until it has been authorized by the NYS Department of State.   An authorized foreign corporation may do any kind of business a domestic corporation may lawfully do, provided the foreign corporation is authorized to do the business in the state or country where it is incorporated.  For further information contact the NYS Department of State, Division of Corporations, or visit their website. 
 
Foreign businesses that expand or conduct business in New York should contact the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance for information on their tax responsibilities. 
 
Foreign companies and individuals wishing to expand or conduct a business in New York should contact NYS Empire State Development .   Empire State Development can assist companies located outside of the state by providing information needed to establish or expand their company.   Empire State Development has offices throughout New York and around the world.  For further information contact Empire State Development or visit their website. 
 
In order to work in the United States, you must have a valid visa, hold a Green Card, or be a citizen of the United States.  The Immigration and Nationality Act is a law that governs the admission of all immigrants into the United States.  Nonimmigrant visas are temporary in nature.  They are issued to individuals who want to enter the United States for a specific, yet temporary, purpose such as to visit, study, or work.  Individuals who successfully apply and are granted an immigrant visa are provided with permanent residency status and are issued a Green Card.  Contact the Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services, National Customer Service Center or visit their website.   The Bureau of Citizenship and Immigration Services, National Customer Service Center has regional offices throughout New York.           
   
The Consulate General of Canada can assist Canadian companies seeking to conduct business in New York.  Contact them through the link below.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation regulates gasoline vapor recovery systems through Title 6 of the New York State Codes, Rules and Regulations, Part 230, Gasoline Dispensing Sites and Transport Vehicles (Part 230).  Part 230 contains information needed to determine which facilities must comply with the vapor control requirements and it outlines three strategies used to control the amount of vapor generated during gasoline transfer.  It includes the Submerged Filling Technique, Stage I Vapor Recovery, and Stage II Vapor Recovery.   Gasoline vapors contain air pollutants and violating air pollution regulations can result in substantial penalties.  Air pollution control inspectors visit gasoline dispensing sites periodically to conduct inspections.  Below is a brief description of the three strategies used to recover the vapors generated during the sale and distribution of gasoline.   
 
The Submerged Filling Technique is a method of refilling a gasoline storage tank that helps control splashing and agitation by evenly and slowly adding gasoline to the bottom of the tank to reduce the amount of vaporization.  This process applies mainly to agricultural sites with little annual throughput.   
 
Stage I Vapor Recovery applies to nearly every retail gasoline dispensing site in New York.  It refers to the process of reclaiming vapor that was, in the past, released in the air when transferring gasoline from a tanker truck into a storage tank.  It is a system where gasoline vapors are forced from a gasoline storage tank into a vapor-tight gasoline transport vehicle or vapor control system through direct displacement by the gasoline being loaded.  Transporters of gasoline, as well as the recipient of the gasoline (the dispensing site), have the responsibility for complying with Stage I Vapor Recovery.   
 
Stage II Vapor Recovery deals entirely with capturing vapors while filling vehicle fuel tanks.  It is a system where at least 90%, by weight, of the gasoline vapors that are displaced or drawn from a vehicle fuel tank during refueling are captured and either retained in the storage tanks or destroyed in an emission control device.  The site operator or owner is responsible for installing and maintaining Stage II equipment which is currently required in the Metro New York Area and the lower Orange County Metropolitan Area. 
 
Gasoline retailers must have vapor recovery (dynamic back pressure, liquid blockage, and static leak tests) and underground tank leak tests performed and results reported every five years to the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation.  The test results must be notarized and submitted within 30 days of the tests.  Gasoline stations must retain the test results for a period of five years and upon request, provide them to a DEC inspectors. 
 
Additionally, tank tightness testing is mandated through the bulk storage regulations.  These tests ensure that liquid gasoline does not leak from the underground tanks and contaminate the groundwater.   
 
Gasoline dispensing sites are advised to perform daily self inspections of their equipment and update paperwork in order to avoid violating Part 230.   The New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation, Small Business Assistance Program provides a Self-Inspection Handbook, Stage I & II Vapor Recovery for Gasoline Facilities as well as other fact sheets, instructional videos and copies of Part 230.  To obtain any of these materials, see the link to their website below.   
 
The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation can provide information on who must comply with the requirements set forth in Part 230, as well as an approved list of equipment required for use at facilities in New York utilizing vapor recovery.  Contact your Department of Environmental Conservation Regional Office or visit their website.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Name: Beauty Salons, Barber Shops, and Hair Restoration Services
Permit Description: Sales of beautician, barbering, and hair restoration services are exempt from state and local sales tax in New York State, unless sales occur in New York City. If you sell beautician, barbering, and hair restoration services in New York City, your sales are subject to New York City’s local sales tax.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Health Care Clinical Services (Health Care Facilities)
Permit Description:
The NYS Department of Health through the Certificate of Need (CON) application process certifies hospital outpatient departments (OPD) and community clinics primarily engaged in providing medical health care services.  A diagnostic and treatment center provides a comprehensive range of primary health care services in a clinic-type setting.  Extension clinics are a component of a general hospital or a diagnostic and treatment center that offer ambulatory care programs (outpatient medical care) as well as offering services of a nonemergency nature and located on premises other than those of the hospital or diagnostic and treatment center.  These facilities are primarily responsible for the health supervision and medical care of patients.  A part-time clinic is an ambulatory care program operated at a particular site for less than 60 hours per month by a general hospital or a diagnostic or treatment center. 
 
For information on the Certificate of Need (CON) process for a medical health care services clinic contact the NYS Department of Health, Division of Health Facility Planning, Office of Health Systems Management or visit their website.  Also contact the local government regulating agency for local requirements. 
 
Additional certification through the NYS Department of Mental Health, Bureau of Inspection and Certification is required for a medical health care services clinic that offers mental health visits that exceeds 10,000 annually or over 30 percent of its annual visits are for mental health services at that site, small mental health practices such as extension or part-time clinics that have over 2,000 mental health visits annually, and independent mental health clinics.  Contact the NYS Department of Mental Health, Bureau of Inspection and Certification or visit their website.   
 
A medical health care services clinic that offers chemical (alcohol and drugs) dependence services as well as independent chemical dependence clinics may need additional certification through the NYS Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services, Health and Planning Services.  Contact their office or visit their website.   
 
A medical health care services clinic that offer services to individuals who are developmentally disabled providing services for long term therapies and habilitative services as well as independent developmentally disable provider clinics may need additional certification through the New York State Office for People With Developmental Disabilities (OPWDD), Bureau of Behavioral and Clinical Solutions.  Contact their office or visit their website.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care

Permit Description:
US DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION - Hazardous Materials Regulations:

If you transport hazardous materials, in addition to the general safety regulations, you are subject to federal requirements found in 49 CFR Parts 100 through 199.  These regulations cover items such as shipping papers, marking and labeling of packages, placarding of vehicles, and the proper packaging to use for hazardous materials.  To view these regulations, visit the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration's website at: www.fmcsa.dot.gov/safety-security/hazmat/regulations.htm.  Also provided on the website is information on How to Comply with the Federal Hazardous Materials Regulations.  Information on transporting hazardous materials in New York can be found at the NYS Department of Transportation's website.

FEDERAL MOTOR CARRIER SAFETY ADMINISTRATION - Hazardous Materials Safety Permit:

The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) enforces the Federal Hazardous Materials Safety Permit (HM Safety Permit) Program for intrastate, interstate, and foreign motor carriers transporting certain types and amounts of hazardous materials. These carriers are required to maintain a certain level of safety in their operations and certify they have programs in place as required by the Hazardous Materials Regulations and the HM Permit Regulations.

New and existing motor carriers are required to submit an MCS-150B (Combined Motor Carrier Identification Report and HM Permit) application.  New interstate hazardous materials carriers applying for a USDOT number and a HM Safety Permit are also required to submit an MSC-150A (Safety Certification Application) form.  Forms are available to download online or you can apply online through the Safety and Fitness Electronic Records (SAFER) system at  the link below.

To obtain more information on USDOT hazardous materials transportation registration requirements, contact the FMCSA's Hazardous Materials Division or visit their website.

PIPELINE AND HAZARDOUS MATERIALS SAFETY ADMINISTRATION - Hazmat Registration:

Pursuant to Title 49 CFR Part 107, Subpart G (107.601 - 107.620), certain transporters of hazardous materials, including hazardous waste, are required to file an annual registration statement with the U.S. Department of Transportation and to pay a fee. This program is administered by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA).  All companies that are required to have a FMCSA Safety Permit are required to have a PHMSA Registration.  For more information, visit the U.S. Department of Transportation, Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration's website through the link below  or call their office. 

NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER - Incident Reporting:

The National Response Center (NCR) was given the responsibility of receiving reports of incidents involving hazardous materials regulated by the U.S. Department of Transportation under the Hazardous Materials Transportation Act and reportable under 49 CFR 171 for the transportation of hazardous materials.  As soon as practical but no later than 12 hours after the occurrence of an incident involving the unintentional release of hazardous materials, notice must be made by telephone to the NRC toll free phone number. A written report (Incident Report Form 5800.1)  must also be submitted.   The Incident Report Form 5800.1 is available through the link below.  For assistance in completing the Incident Report Form 5800.1 or for questions regarding the incident reporting requirements, call the Hazardous Materials Information Center.

U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY  - EPA Identification Number:

All persons who generate, transport, recycle, treat, store or dispose of hazardous wastes are required to have an EPA Identification Number.  To obtain a Notification of Regulated Waste Activity, Form 8700-12, or for more information, contact the agency or visit their website.

NEW YORK STATE DEPARTMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES - Commercial Driver L

Permit Description: Businesses that work on Public Work Projects (government) must pay the prevailing wage and supplements (fringe benefits) to all workers under a public work contract. Assistance in complying with Articles 8&9 of the NYS Labor Law.

Permit Name: Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning (HVAC) Contractor
Permit Description:
All technicians who work on stationary air conditioners and refrigeration systems must be certified under Section 608 of the Federal Clean Air Act.  In order to maintain, repair, or service stationary equipment, technicians must pass a test demonstrating proper handling of ozone depleting refrigerants and knowledge of EPA refrigerant regulations. There are four areas of certification: Type 1 – small appliances, Type II – high pressure refrigerants, Type III – low pressure refrigerants, and Universal Certification.  Universal certification involves issues to all three specific types of equipment.  Exams are administered by organizations approved by the U.S. EPA.   A list of approved testing programs that provide technician certification is available from the EPA's Ozone Hotline (indicate your are calling about ozone, air and radiation (OAR)) or on their website.   
 
The EPA has imposed a sales restriction on the purchasing of refrigerants.  Only certified technicians can purchase any refrigerant contained in bulk containers (cylinders or drums) and pre-charged parts.   
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations linked below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services,Professional Licenses

Permit Description:
Section 276.3 of the NYS Agriculture and Markets regulations allows for the exemption from the licensing requirements of the NYS Agriculture and Markets Law, Article 20-C for home processors of food who sell or offer for sale certain food items.  In order to protect the public health and to minimize the potential of food product adulteration, the exemption is restricted to the following non-potentially hazardous home processed foods:  bakery products (breads, rolls, cookies, cakes, brownies, fudge, and double-crust fruit pies) for wholesale marketing or retail agricultural sales such as farms, farm stands, farmer markets, green markets, craft fairs, and flea markets; traditional fruit jams, jellies, and marmalades; candy (excluding chocolate); spices; herbs; popcorn; caramel corn; and peanut brittle.   
 
Internet sales are not included in this exemption.  Home processors whose residences contain separate segregated facilities for food processing while not qualifying for a home processor exemption, may apply for licensing as a food processing establishment under the NYS Agriculture and Markets Law, Article 20-C. 
 
Manufacturers of non-beverage products that require the purchase of liquor, wine or beer from duly licensed manufacturers or wholesalers for use in the process of such products require a One-Time/Three Years Non-Beverage Manufacturer license issued through the NYS Liquor Authority. 
 
All processors, including home processors, must consult with local zoning officials for approval before starting any type of food processing operation.  The NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets, Division of Food Safety  performs inspections of exempt firms.  For detailed information and to schedule an inspection, please contact the nearest regional office: 
 
The Buffalo regional office at 716-847-3185 for operations located in the counties of:  Erie, Cattaraugus, Chautauqua, Genesee, Niagara, Orleans, and Wyoming. 
 
The Rochester regional office at 585-427-0200 for operations located in the counties of:  Allegany, Cayuga, Chemung, Livingston, Monroe, Ontario, Schuyler, Seneca, Steuben, Tioga, Tompkins, Wayne, and Yates.  
 
The Syracuse regional office at 315-487-0852 for operations located in the counties of:  Broome, Clinton, Chenango, Cortland, Delaware, Franklin, Herkimer, Jefferson, Lewis, Madison, Oneida, Onondaga, Otsego, St. Lawrence, and Oswego. 
 
The Albany regional office at 518-457-3880 or toll free 800-554-4501 for operations located in the counties of:  Albany, Columbia, Dutchess, Essex, Fulton, Greene, Hamilton, Montgomery, Rensselaer, Saratoga, Schenectady, Schoharie, Ulster, Warren, and Washington . 
 
The New York/Long Island regional office at 718-722-2876 for operations located in the counties of:  Bronx, Queens, Kings, New York, Richmond, Orange, Putnam, Westchester, Sullivan, Nassau, and Suffolk.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Food Service and Processing

Permit Description:
The Home Inspection Professional Licensing Act, effective December 31, 2005, requires the NYS Department of State, Division of Licensing Services to license home inspectors.  Home inspection is the process by which a home inspector observes and provides a written report of the heating, cooling, plumbing, and electrical systems and components (foundation, roof, masonry structure, exterior and interior components or any other related residential building component) of a residential building.  A residential building consists of one to four dwelling units and their garages and carports, but does not include any structure newly constructed or not previously occupied as a dwelling unit.  Home inspections are not an appraisal, which determines market value, or a municipal inspection, which verifies local code compliance.   To view the NYS Real Property Law, Article 12-B, visit the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
Professional architects, engineers, and code enforcement officials for the state or a political subdivision can continue to engage in home inspections without the need of this license provided they are working within the scope of their profession.  However, if they open a home inspection business they are required to obtain a license.  Architects and engineers are exempt from the course work, examination requirement, and the continuing education requirements for this license as long as they can provide proof of their professional license.  Code enforcement officials must meet all qualifications.  Some banks may require a licensed professional engineer perform the inspection.   
 
This Act also requires every licensed home inspector engaged in home inspections to secure, maintain, and file with the NYS Department of State proof of a certificate of liability coverage of a minimum amount of $150,000 per occurrence and $500,000 aggregate. 
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations linked below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.

Permit Description:
Congress passed the National Gold and Silver Marking Act, referred to as the National Stamping Act, in 1906.  The Federal Trade Commission's Jewelry Guides provides information for businesses as well as consumers on how to describe jewelry products truthfully and non-deceptively and how to disclose material information to consumers.  Contact the FTC or visit their website link below for jewelry guides and information. 
 
New York passed its own law under the NYS General Business Law, Articles 13 and 13-A with regards to markings of silver, gold, diamonds, and platinum.  Article 13-B establishes guidelines for appraisers of jewelry, works of art, watches, and objects made from or containing precious stones or metals.  To view the NYS Business Law, Articles 13 – 13-B, visit the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
New York has regulations with regard to the use of scales in the retail sale of precious gems, semiprecious gems, and precious metals.  Contact the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets for guidelines or visit their website. 
 
To view the New York's lien law that protects jewelry repair shops for unpaid services,  'Article 8 – Other Liens on Personal Property', and  'Section 186 Lien of Bailees for Hire' through the links below.

Permit Description:
Accurate laboratory test results are essential to health assessment and disease or environmental exposure prevention. The NYS Department of Health, Wadsworth Center's quality and regulatory oversight programs assure the development and implementation of methods that provide accurate, reliable, reproducible test results from clinical specimens or samples collected from the environment. These programs include issuance of operating licenses to clinical laboratories, environmental testing laboratories and human tissue banks for transplantation and research. 

Clinical Laboratory Permit:  Allows a facility to accept specimens for the microbiological, immunological, chemical, hematological, biophysical, cytological, pathological, genetic, or other examination of materials derived from the human body, for the purpose of obtaining information for the diagnosis, prevention, or treatment of disease; the assessment of a health condition; or for identification purposes. Such examinations shall include procedures to determine, measure, or otherwise describe the presence or absence of various substances, components or organisms in the human body. This means that any facility issuing patient-identified results, including facilities performing research, clinical trials, insurance testing, forensic toxicology or forensic/paternity identity testing, excluding some exceptions, must hold a permit as a Clinical Laboratory.  All clinical laboratories that accept clinical specimens obtained in New York State must hold a New York State Clinical Laboratory Permit.  A clinical laboratory may operate one or more collecting or transfer stations with prior written approval from the NYS Department of Health.  

Blood Bank Permit:  A facility that collects, processes, fully tests, stores and/or distributes human blood, blood components or blood derivatives for transfusions and performs pre-transfusion tests must hold a Blood Bank Permit.  Non-hospital based facilities performing transfusions on-site that do not meet these criteria may apply for a designation as a Limited Transfusion Service.  All blood banks that accept clinical specimens obtained in New York State must hold a New York State Blood Bank Permit.

Blood bank laboratories performing immunohematology testing that includes blood typing for such groups as ABO and Rh, and cross matching, serving New York State patients must hold a permit in the category of Immunohmetology.  For further information on this requirement, contact the NYS Department of Health, Immunohematology Proficiency Testing Program at the Wadsworth Center, or visit their website. 

When a clinical laboratory and/or a blood bank are on the same premises and are under the supervision of the same director, the clinical laboratory and blood bank are considered one laboratory.  

Limited Service Laboratory Registration:  A laboratory facility operating in New York or accepting specimens from New York that perform only tests classified under the Federal Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 (CLIA) as Waived and/or Provider-Performed Microscopy Procedures (PPMP) may register for the designation as a Limited Service Laboratory.  These laboratory facilities include hospital extension clinics, nursing homes, home health care agencies, school/student health services, dialysis facilities, ambulatory surgery centers, county health departments, correctional facilities, ambulance/rescue squads and other direct patient care facilities. Laboratories which are set up as a joint venture of several practitioners, partnerships or practices and practices which are owned managed and/or operated by managed care organizations, hospitals, or consulting firms are included in this designation. 

Patient Service Center Permit:  Allows a permitted clinical laboratory facility to operate a collecting station also known as a patient service center for the collection, drawing and/or temporary storage of materials derived from the human body, until fo
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care

Permit Description:
The Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) has requirements for concrete and masonry construction safety standards including limited access zones, fall protection and respiratory protection.  The Safety and Health Regulations for Construction: Gases, Vapors, Fumes, Dusts and Mists, sets out to limit exposure of employees to airborne contaminants.  OSHA has established permissible exposure limits for crystalline silica. Crystalline silica containing dust may be produced during abrasive blasting, tuckpointing, cutting of concrete or masonry products, demolition and repair of concrete or masonry structures, and dry sweeping or pressurized air blowing of concrete, rock, or sand dust.  Respirators, which must be approved by the National Institute of Safety and Health (NIOSH), provide varying levels of protection against silica dust.  Other protections include employee training and medical surveillance.  For more information on OSHA requirements, visit their website.

Permit Description:
Sales of massage services are subject to New York City’s local sales tax when sold in New York City, even if you are a licensed massage therapist under Title VIII of the Education Law.

However, massage services performed by a licensed physician, physiotherapist, or chiropractor for medical reasons are not subject to New York City’s local sales tax.

If you sell taxable massage services in New York City, you must register for sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.

Sales of any massage services are exempt from state and local sales tax everywhere in New York State outside New York City.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
Moving companies are required by law to inform consumers of their rights as a shipper.   
 
For moves within New York State, 17 NYCRR Part 814.1 requires that each carrier of household goods give to every prospective shipper, a copy of the NYS Department of Transportation's Summary of Information for Shippers of Household Goods.  For more information on requirements for household goods movers, contact the NYS Department of Transportation or visit their website. 
 
For interstate moves, the US Department of Transportation requires the booklet, Your Rights and Responsibilities When You Move, be provided to prospective shippers.  The booklet provides information to help consumers understand the documents that they will be asked to sign as well as explains their rights if their household goods are lost or damaged.   
 
The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration also provides information on moving. Their web site Protect Your Move explains consumers' rights and responsibilities. Consumers learn to spot the red flags of moving fraud. See the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, Protect Your Move site below. 
 
NYS Department of Taxation and Finance's Tax Bulletin, TB-ST-341 Household Movers and Warehouses – Sales of moving services and related transactions provides information on how sales tax applies to household movers and warehouses.  It also provides answers to general questions generally encountered in the operation of moving or warehousing business.  To view this bulletin, the link is below or you can contact the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance.

Permit Description:
There is no difference between the terms nonprofit and not-for-profit.  They both refer to an organization established for purposes other than profit-making or financial gain.  A nonprofit corporation is a special type of corporation organized for specific tax-exempt purposes. To qualify for nonprofit status, the corporation must be formed to benefit the public, a specific group of individuals, or the membership of the nonprofit organization.  Nonprofit corporations have the same limited liability protection that regular corporations and limited liability companies have. The directors, officers, members, and employees are not responsible for the debts and liabilities of the corporation.

Directors are responsible for the management and operations of the nonprofit corporation. Nonprofit directors can serve with or without compensation. If the directors are compensated, the compensation must be deemed reasonable by the IRS.  New York State requires at least three directors be listed on the Certificate of Incorporation. The IRS also requires at least three directors when submitting a tax-exempt application.  Officers of a nonprofit corporation run the day-to-day activities. Every nonprofit corporation must have a president, treasurer and secretary.  Bylaws are the specifications of the overall structure and operation of the organization and include the rules or laws under which the organization operates. 

To begin the process to become a nonprofit corporation, the organization must file with the NYS Department of State, Division of Corporations.  This filing does not automatically qualify the organization for federal and state tax-exemption. Only a validly organized nonprofit corporation can apply for federal and state tax-exemption.

FEDERAL REQUIREMENTS

Every nonprofit organization that applies for federal tax-exempt status must have an employer identification number (EIN), whether or not it has employees.  To apply for an EIN, complete IRS Form SS-4, Application for Employer Identification Number.  For more information about EINs, request IRS Publication 1635, Understanding Your EIN.

Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) exempts payment of federal income taxes for groups who are organized for charitable, religious, scientific, literary or educational purposes, testing for public safety, fostering national or international amateur sports competitions, or the prevention of cruelty to children or animals.  

To apply for exemption from federal income tax, request application Form 1023, Application for Recognition of Exemption Under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code along and the IRS Publication 4220, Applying for 501(c)(3) Tax Exempt Status, contains general guidelines for organizations that seek tax-exempt status from federal income tax.  The publication includes references to the statute, Treasury regulations, other IRS publication that explain the requirements for tax-exempt status, and IRS forms and instructions.  

The IRS takes approximately three to five months to examine and approve a 501(c)(3) application.  If all information submitted establishes that the organization meets the requirements for exemption, the IRS will issue a favorable ruling or determination letter recognizing the exemption.   

Generally, all tax-exempt organizations must file an annual information return.  Tax-exempt organizations that do not normally have annual gross receipts in excess of $25,000 are not required to file the annual information return.  However, starting in 2008, these organizations must submit an annual electronic notice using Form 990N, Electronic Notice (e-Postcard) for Tax-Exempt Organizations not Required to File Form 900 or 990-EZ, also known as the e-Postcard.  The e-Postcard can only be filed electronically; there is no paper version.  For more information, refer to IRS Publication 557, Tax-Exempt Status for Your Organization.  In addition, Publication 4221, Compliance Guide for 501(c)(3) Tax-E
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
Pet stores and breeders engaged in the sale of more than nine dogs or cats a year for a profit to the public require licensing through the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets as a pet dealer.  Certain humane societies and breeders who sell, directly to the public, fewer than 25 animals per year that are born and raised at their residential premise are exempt from the pet dealer license.  The NYS General Business Law, Article 35-D outlines New York State's 'Pet Lemon Law' requirements.  This so-called Pet Lemon Law provides that if within 14 days of purchase, a veterinarian certifies that the animal was unfit due to illness, congenial malformation or infectious disease, the pet dealer must offer the consumer the right to choose one of the following options:  
 
(a) The right to return the animal and receive a refund of the purchase price and reasonable veterinary costs related to the certification that the animal was unfit;  
(b) The right to return the animal and receive an exchange animal of the consumer's choice and veterinary costs related to the certification; or  
(c) The right to keep the animal and receive reimbursement of the veterinary services for the purpose of attempting to cure the animal.  
 
The NYS Agriculture and Markets Law, Article 26-A outlines standards pet dealers need to follow for the care of animals.  There are standards on housing, sanitation, feeding and watering, handling, veterinary care, daily exercise and humane euthanasia, as well as records retention.  Pet dealers are also required to provide certain types of documentation at the time of purchase of dogs or cats to the consumer.  Two types of documentation are a Disclosure of Animal Pedigree Registration and an Information Statement for Purchaser of a Dog or Cat; pet dealers can obtain copies of these forms by contacting the NYS Department of Agriculture and Market.  The NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets makes yearly inspections at pet dealer facilities. 
 
For detailed information on the pet dealer license, contact the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets, Division of Animal Industry, or visit their website. 
 
Applicable Laws:  
 
The NYS Agriculture and Markets Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
The NYS General Business Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description:
Effective January 1, 2005, no person shall possess, sell, barter, or import wild animals in New York for use as a pet.  NYS Environmental Conservation Law, Article 11 has special requirements for the transportation and/or possession of wild animals by zoological and research facilities, licensed veterinarians, state universities, private college or university, state agency, wildlife sanctuary and/or rehabilitators, reptile exhibitors and persons completely paralyzed from the neck down.  Any person who possesses a wild animal as a pet prior to January 1, 2005 must apply for a license authorizing possession of the wild animal within six months of the effective date.   The license is a biennial license in the amount of not more than $175.  Owners of wild animals may also need to obtain a permit and/or license issued by the local government entity.  For detailed information, contact your Regional Office of the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation. 
 
Applicable Laws:  
 
The NYS Environmental Conservation Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
The NYS General Business Law, Article 26, Section 391-n provides posting requirements for the sale of reptiles.  The law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.
