Permit Description: A caterer provides prepared food, beverages, and various other services for events. In general, all charges by caterers related to a customer's event are taxable. Party planners and event coordinators who plan weddings and similar functions are also caterers when they arrange for and bill for food, beverages, and other services at an event.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
NYS Environmental Conservation Law, Article 17, Title 10 Control of the Bulk Storage of Petroleum requires the registration of all facilities having an aggregate storage capacity for petroleum or petroleum products of 1,101 to 399,999 gallons or any tank whose capacity is greater than 110 gallons where 10% or more of the volume of the tank is underground.  Heating oil tanks less than 1,100 gallons are excluded from this registration requirement.  Facilities with a total combined storage capacity under 1,101 must register their oil tanks but there is no fee.  The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation requires petroleum bulk storage facilities to register every five years and to perform tightness tests on their storage tanks. This applies for both underground and aboveground storage tanks and includes out-of-service facilities until the facility is properly and permanently closed.  This petroleum tank registration requirement also satisfies compliance with 6 NYCRR Part 230 Vapor Recovery Requirements. 
 
Additionally, in July 2008 changes were made to the New York State law for the Petroleum Bulk Storage program to comply with the requirements mandated by the federal Energy Policy Act of 2005.  These changes include equipment requirements, delivery prohibition, and operator training. To obtain a copy of the NYS bulk storage regulations, contact your NYS Department of Environmental Conservation Regional Office or visit their website at www.dec.ny.gov.   All bulk storage facilities and petroleum storage tank owners are responsible for complying with the New York State bulk storage regulations.  The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation has delegated the petroleum bulk storage program to Nassau, Suffolk, Rockland, and Westchester Counties.  Facilities located in these counties should contact the appropriate agencies listed below for information on regulations governing the registration of their facilities.  
 
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) provides information regarding the federal underground storage tank regulations (40 CFR, Part 280 and 281).  For information, contact the U.S. EPA Office of Underground Storage Tanks (OUST)  or visit the EPA website. 
 
Applicable NYS Laws and Regulations:  
 
The NYS Environmental Conservation Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
To view applicable New York State's Codes, Rules and Regulations (NYCRR), visit through the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail,Licenses and Permits, Services,Licenses and Permits, Transportation and Pubic Utilities

Permit Description:
Property and real estate managers are responsible for the day-to-day operations of property such as an office building, a shopping center, or an apartment complex. These managers are employed either directly by the owner or indirectly through a contract with a property management firm. Property managers perform a wide range of functions overseeing the performance of income-producing commercial or residential properties. They can oversee financial operations of the property, ensuring that mortgages, taxes, insurance premiums, payroll, and maintenance bills are paid on time. They can negotiate contracts for services such as: janitorial, security, grounds keeping, trash and snow removal. They can monitor the performance of contractors and investigate and resolve complaints from residents and tenants when services are not properly provided. Property managers purchase supplies and equipment for the property and make arrangements with specialists for repairs that cannot be handled by regular property maintenance staff. Property managers routinely inspect the grounds, facilities, and equipment to determine repairs or maintenance.

Property managers or firms who perform certain maintenance services may be required to register for NYS sales tax and collect sales tax on the charges for those services. Visit the Tax Department’s website through the links below (Publication 750, A Guide to Sales Tax in New York State, and Tax Bulletin TB-ST-129, Contractors—Repair, Maintenance, and Installation Services to Real Property (TB-ST-129)) for more information.

Property managers can work onsite or act as a liaison with the onsite manager and owner. Property managers may be required to live in apartment complexes where they work so that they are available to handle emergencies as they occur. Some property managers, called asset property managers, supervise the preparation of financial statements and periodically report to the owners on the status of the property, occupancy rates, dates of lease expiration, and other matters. 

Property managers should have a clear understanding of all federal, state, and local laws and regulations to comply with building, housing, health and safety codes. The NYS Attorney General's Office booklet, 'Tenant's Rights Guide,' available online through the link below contains information for both tenants and property owners/managers. Additionally, there are many federal, State, and local laws governing rental property that property managers should understand and comply with. Two federal laws are the U.S. Americans with Disabilities Act and the U.S. Federal Fair Housing Act. These laws can be reviewed through their respective links below. There are several New York laws governing rental property, some of these laws are: General Obligations Law, Real Property Law, Multiple Dwelling Law, and Multiple Residence Law. These laws can be reviewed in law libraries and in certain public libraries. The NYS Division of Housing and Community Renewal administers the NYS Rent Stabilization Code and the Rent Regulation Reform Act. These codes limits the rent an owner may charge for an apartment and restricts the right of an owner to evict tenants. It also obligates the owner to provide essential services and equipment. For detailed information and requirements regarding rent stabilization, contact the NYS Division of Housing and Community Renewal office or visit the link below. 

Community association managers manage the common property and services of condominiums, cooperatives, and planned communities such as homeowners' or community associations. The volunteer board of directors of a condominium, cooperatives, or homeowner's associations hires community association managers. Community association managers provide the same types of services as a property manager; as well as collect monthly assessments, prepare financial statements and budgets, negotiate with contractors, and help resolve complaints. Community association managers a
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
The NYS Department of State licenses individuals who broker, sell, or appraise real estate transactions.  The NYS Real Property Law, Article 12-A regulates licensing of real estate brokers and real estate salespersons.  The NYS Executive Law, Article 6-E regulates licensing of state certified and licensed real estate appraisers.  Real estate brokers and salespersons are also obligated to follow NYS Real Property Law, Article 14 regarding property condition disclosures.

A real estate broker means any person, firm, limited liability company or corporation, who, for another and for a fee, commission or other valuable consideration, lists for sale, sells, at auction or otherwise, exchanges, buys or rents, or offers or attempts to negotiate a sale, at auction or otherwise, exchange, purchase or rental of an estate or interest in real estate, or collects or offers or attempts to collect rent for the use of real estate, or negotiates or offers or attempts to negotiate, a loan secured or to be secured by a mortgage, other than a residential mortgage loan, as defined in §590 of the Banking Law, or other incumbrance upon or transfer of real estate, or is engaged in the business of a tenant re-locator, or who, notwithstanding any other provision of law, performs any of the above stated functions with respect to the resale of condominium property originally sold pursuant to the provisions of the General Business Law governing real estate syndication offerings. It is the responsibility of licensees to understand the Real Estate License Law, where a more detailed definition of real estate broker can be found, including information about different types of brokers.  In order to qualify for licensure as a real estate broker, an applicant must have at least two years of experience as a licensed real estate salesperson or at least three years of experience in the general real estate field (e.g., buying and selling your own property, managing property owned by your employer), have satisfactorily completed both the qualifying salesperson course of 75 hours and an additional 45-hour real estate broker course as approved by the Secretary of State, and have passed a qualifying examination.

Associate real estate broker means a licensed real estate broker who shall by choice elect to work under the name and supervision of another individual broker or another broker who is licensed under a partnership, trade name, limited liability company or corporation. Such individual shall retain his or her license as a real estate broker provided, however, that the practice of real estate sales and brokerage by such individual as an associate broker shall be governed exclusively as they pertain to real estate salespersons. Nothing contained shall preclude an individual who elects to be licensed as an associate broker from also retaining a separate real estate broker's license under an individual, partnership, trade name, limited liability company or corporation. 

A real estate salesperson is an individual under the supervision of a licensed real estate broker that facilitates the purchase and sale of property on behalf of customers, obtains lists of property for sale with an employing broker, and assists buyers of real estate to locate and purchase property.   A real estate salesperson is associated with a real estate broker to list and negotiate the sale, lease, or rental of real property for others for compensation, under the direction and guidance of a licensed real estate broker.  A real estate salesperson cannot operate independently.  In order to qualify for licensure as a real estate salesperson, an applicant must have satisfactorily completed a 75-hour salesperson qualifying education course in real estate approved by the Secretary of State, and have passed a qualifying examination administered by the Department of State. An applicant who completed the 45-hour salesperson qualifying course prior to July 1, 2008 may complete the 30-hour remedial course i
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Real Estate

Permit Description:
At this time, New York State does not license repossession of motorized vehicles.  The NYS Uniform Commercial Code, Article 9, Part 6, sets forth standards for secured parties to take possession of collateral after default.  The NYS Vehicle and Traffic Law, Section 425 sets forth procedures for the repossession of motorized vehicles to personally appear at the local law enforcement agency and notify the police agency of repossession immediately following the repossession; to deliver to the nearest NYS Motor Vehicles office within 24 hours a completed Notice of Repossession of Motor Vehicle or Motorcycle form along with the license plates from the repossessed vehicle; and to notify the vehicle owner of the repossession within 24 hours. 
 
Applicable Laws:  
 
The NYS Uniform Commercial Code is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below. 
 
The NYS Vehicle and Traffic Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.

Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
In transporting roofing supplies, you must comply with certain federal and state transportation regulations.  Roofing contractors who haul hazardous and elevated-temperature materials must comply with placard and marking requirements.  Roofing contractors who operate any vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) of 10,001 pounds or more, use tankers or haul hot materials are regulated by DOT as operators of commercial vehicles.  Vehicles having a GVWR greater than 10,001 pounds that are involved in interstate commerce must comply with Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) regulations.  Visit DOT's website for more information. 
 
Roofing contractors may come in contact with asbestos containing asphalt/bituminous roofing products and asbestos cement shingles/panels.  The handling and removal of asbestos is regulated under Article 30 of the NYS Labor Law.  Roofing contractors that deal in the handling of asbestos or who may incidentally disturb asbestos during the course of their work, should have an asbestos handling license.  To obtain more information on asbestos certificates, contact the NYS Department of Labor, Division of Safety and Health, License and Certification Unit, or visit their website. 
 
There are specific standards for the construction industry regarding fall protection.  Employers must set up the work place to prevent employees from falling off of overhead platforms, elevated work stations or into holes in the floor and walls. OSHA requires that fall protection be provided at elevations of four feet in general industry workplaces, five feet in shipyards, six feet in the construction industry and eight feet in long-shoring operations. In addition, OSHA requires that fall protection be provided when working over dangerous equipment and machinery, regardless of the fall distance.   For more information regarding fall protection, visit OSHA's website.

Permit Name: Social Work - Licensed Master Social Worker
Permit Description:
The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions.   A professional license is the authorization to practice and use a professional title in New York State.   If you meet all the licensure requirements, you will be issued a license number and be entitled to practice in New York State as of the effective date of licensure.  To practice in New York under the authority of your license, you must register every three years (two years for medicine). You are automatically registered for your first registration period when your license is issued. 
 
Social work is a profession that helps individuals, families, and groups change behaviors, emotions, attitudes, relationships, and social conditions to restore and enhance their capacity to meet their personal and social needs.  Social workers are trained to provide a variety of services, ranging from psychotherapy to the administration of health and welfare programs. They work with human development and behavior, including the social, economic, and cultural systems in which people function. 
 
The practice of the profession of licensed master social work shall mean the professional application of social work theory, principles, and the methods to prevent, assess, evaluate, formulate and implement a plan of action based on client needs and strengths, and intervene to address mental, social, emotional, behavioral, developmental, and addictive disorders, conditions and disabilities, and of the psychosocial aspects of illness and injury experienced by individuals, couples, families, groups, communities, organizations, and society.   Licensed master social workers engage in the administration of tests and measures of psychosocial functioning, social work advocacy, case management, counseling, consultation, research, administration and management, and teaching.   A licensed master social worker may provide clinical services only under supervision of a licensed clinical social worker, licensed psychologist or psychiatrist. 
 
To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions or visit their website.   The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms.  
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The association listed below is for reference purposes only and does not constitute an endorsement.

Permit Description:
A swimming pool operated as a part of, or facility of, a temporary residence for the use of the occupants, guests, invitees or employees shall be constructed, maintained and operated so as to comply with the provisions of Part 6 of the State Sanitary Code.  A separate permit shall not be required for a summer day camp, bathing beach, swimming pool or a service food establishment operated as part of a temporary residence for which a permit is required. 
 
Application Regulations: 
 
To view applicable New York State's Codes, Rules and Regulations (NYCRR), visit the website through the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Construction,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
The NYS Transportation Law, Article 7 regulates carriers of passengers by motor vehicles.  However, there are some exemptions which allow for the operation of transporting passengers without the authority of the NYS Department of Transportation.  Taxi and limousine services are usually licensed by the local municipality in which they are operating.  To view applicable laws, visit the NYS Legislature's website through the links below. 
 
There are some New York State laws which govern the solicitation of passengers for transportation services.   To view these applicable laws, visit the NYS Legislature's website through the links below. 
 
NEW YORK CITY REQUIREMENTS: 
 
The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC), is responsible for licensing and regulating New York City's medallion (yellow) taxicabs, for-hire vehicles (community-based liveries and black cars), commuter vans, paratransit vehicles (ambulettes) and certain luxury limousines.  To apply for a taxicab owner's license, contact the NYC Taxi and Limousine Commission, or visit their website.  NYC taxi drivers are also required to be licensed by the TLC.  Some of the requirements include; provide a valid chauffeur's driver's license and social security card, complete a defensive driving course, fingerprinting, drug testing, English proficiency testing and attending a TLC approved taxi school.  
 
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations linked below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Transportation and Pubic Utilities

Permit Description:
Commercial Drivers License (CDL): 
 
A federally mandated, state issued CDL is required to operate any of the following motor vehicles: a vehicle with a gross combination weight rating (GCWR) of 26,001 pounds or more with a towed unit with a gross vehicle weight rating of more than 10,000 pounds; a vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of 26,001 pounds or more; a vehicle designed to transport 16 or more passengers, including the driver; a vehicle of any size used to transport hazardous materials which is required to be placarded.  For more information on commercial drivers licenses, visit the NYS Department of Motor Vehicles website or call their office. 
 
Hours of Service Regulations (Logbooks): 
 
Part 395 of Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations regulates the hours of service of drivers and record keeping requirements.  The Hours-of-Service regulations put limits in place for when and how long commercial motor vehicle (CMV) drivers may drive.  The drivers are required to keep a daily log book of hours driven. Contact the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, Albany field office for more information on these regulations or visit their website. 
 
Medical Certificate Requirements:   
 
If you operate a commercial vehicle, you may be required to obtain a NYS Department of Transportation medical certificate. A medical certificate is issued by a doctor stating that you are physically qualified to operate a commercial motor vehicle.  Medical certificates are valid for 2 years.  For more information on the requirement for medical certificates, visit the NYS Department of Transportation's website. 
 
Identification/Marking Requirements: 
 
You are required to display a USDOT number on each commercial motor vehicle operated, whether you operate wholly within New York (intrastate), or across state lines (interstate).  The number is used to identify your business.  The letters and numbers shall be displayed on each side of the vehicle.  You must display your business name and USDOT number.  For intrastate commerce, the USDOT number must be followed by the letters NY.  The markings need to contrast sharply with the background color of your truck and be readable from 50 feet (minimum of 2 inches high recommended).  Complete Form MCS-150 (Motor Carrier Identification Report) to obtain a USDOT number.  The MCS-150 can be completed online at the Safer website link or call the US DOT toll free number to have an application mailed to you. 
 
Other Applicable Laws:  
 
The NYS Lien Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Transportation and Pubic Utilities

Permit Description:
The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation has revised its permitting rule, Part 201, in July 1996; it increased the number of exempt activities from 37 to over 100. Many small businesses are eligible for the new exemptions. If you are opening a new business and your process is exempt, or if you are expanding an existing business by adding exempt processes, you do not have to notify DEC about any new exempt processes. (The only exception to this is that exempt activities must be listed on Title V applications).  
 
If your eligibility for an exemption is based on the use of emission control equipment, you must properly operate and maintain the equipment. Other exemptions are based on material usage, which will require you to keep records on site that prove your exempt status for five years. You must also make these records available to DEC upon request.  
 
Note that your business may be exempt if located outside the New York City Metropolitan area and lower Orange County area and uses less than 25 gallons combined of coating materials (paints, stains, solvents, etc.) per month. As well as, if the operation is conducted in an enclosed building where such operations are exhausted into an appropriate emission control device.  This exemption is not exhaustive, nor is it a substitute for the actual language in Part 201. If you believe that your process is exempt, or to get advice on whether your process qualifies for an exemption, or to receive a list of all the exemptions in Part 201, please contact the New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation, Small Business Assistance Program or visit their website.

Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Construction,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
A brewery is a dedicated building for the brewing of beer.  A company that brews beer is called either a brewery or a brewing company.  The diversity of size in breweries is matched by the diversity of processes, degrees of automation, and kinds of beer produced.  A brewery is typically divided into distinct sections, with each section reserved for one part of the brewing process.  There are several steps in the brewing process, which include malting, milling, mashing, lautering, boiling, fermenting, conditioning, filtering, and packaging.  Key ingredients in the production of beer include water, starch source (such as barley), yeast and hops.

In New York, a brewer is any person or entity engaged primarily in the business to manufacture/produce and wholesale over 60,000 barrels of beer per year.  Licensing allows for the sale of beer from the premises of the beer brewed by the brewer to licensed wholesalers, retailers and permittees in New York, and to sell or deliver such beer to persons outside of New York according to the laws of the place of such sale or delivery. The license allows the brewer to sell beer at retail in bulk by the keg, cask or barrel for consumption.  

In New York, a micro-brewer is any person or entity engaged primarily in the business to manufacture/produce and wholesale under 60,000 barrels of beer per year.  The license allows the micro-brewer to sell beer in a sealed container for off-premises consumption at the New York State fair, at recognized county fairs and at farmers' markets operated on a not-for-profit basis.  

A person or entity licensed as a brewer in New York may request licensing to sell beer, wine or liquor at retail for consumption on the premises in a restaurant owned by him and conducted and operated by him in or adjacent to the brewery for which he is licensed.  Referred to as a "brew pub" license, this license allowed brewing of beer on-premises, as well as on-premises consumption of liquor, wine and beer.  The applicant can sell beer brewed on the premises to other retail licenses, where the license is held by the same person holding the restaurant-brewer license.  A person holding one or more licenses under this section may brew, no more than 20,000 barrels of beer a year.

A person or entity licensed as a brewer in New York may request licensing to sell beer, wine or liquor at retail for consumption on the premises in a restaurant owned by him and conducted and operated by him in or adjacent to the brewery for which he is licensed.  The license regulates the production and sale of beer for on and off premises consumption. This license is called a restaurant brewer or commonly referred to as a brew pub that is a bona fide restaurant that may produce up to 5,000 barrels of beer per location, not to exceed 20,000 barrels of beer per year.

The NYS Liquor Authority licenses brewers, microbrewers and restaurant brewers.  The NYS Alcoholic Beverage Control Law, Article 4, outlines the differences of each type of brewery along with other requirements.  For information on NYS Liquor Authority licensing requirements, contact the NYS Liquor Authority.  Other possible licenses from the NYS Liquor Authority may include brand labeling, wholesaling, beer tastings, outdoor events, and retail sales for off-premise consumption.

The NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets regulates any type of beverage manufacturing including breweries and micro-breweries through food processing establishment Article 20-C licensing.  Other possible licenses from the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets may include a Farm Products Dealers license.  For information on NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets licensing requirements, contact the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets.

The NYS Department of Taxation and Finance provides information on sales tax requirements and tax exemptions for manufacturing facilities.  Other requirements from the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance may include Di
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Food Service and Processing

Permit Description:
The NYS Department of Financial Services regulates the insurance industry in New York State.  Any person or entity that accepts any commission, service fee or other valuable consideration to sell, solicit or negotiate insurance must be licensed in New York.  For detailed information on licensing requirements for all aspects of the insurance industry, visit the NYS Department of Financial Services' website.

A producer is defined as any person required to be licensed to sell, solicit or negotiate insurance.  A producer is an Agent, Broker, Consultant, Reinsurance Intermediary or Excess Lines Broker.  An insurance agent represents an insurance company(ies) and sells insurance for which ever company(ies) have appointed that agent.  An insurance broker represents the public and can sell insurance for any insurance company licensed in New York State which deals with brokers.  A Resident means one who has declared New York as their home state.  Non-resident means one who has declared a state other than New York as their home state; home state is where a principal place of residence or business is maintained and where the applicant/licensee is licensed in good standing for the lines of authority for which they are applying.  For information on licensing requirements, contact the Insurance Industry's licensing bureau or visit their website.

The NYS Department of Financial Services is responsible for regulating three main insurers:  Health, Life and Property.

Health Insurer:  The following types of health insurers are regulated by the NYS Department of Financial Services:  accident and health; non-profit health services, medical expense indemnity, dental expense indemnity corporations and health maintenance organizations (HMOs).  In addition, the Department regulates health insurance products issued by fraternal benefit societies, municipal cooperative health benefit plans and continuing care retirement communities (CCRCs).

The Department oversees the solvency of these companies, corporate and marketplace conduct, and compliance with the NYS Insurance Law and regulations. The Department conducts periodic financial and market conduct examinations of these companies; reviews and approves health insurance premium adjustments; reviews and approves new rates and filings; and issues legal interpretations of contract language for health insurance, including Disability Benefits Law (DBL) coverage and continuing care retirement communities (CCRCs).  For more information, contact their office.

Life Insurer:  The Department is responsible for regulating the financial condition, market conduct activities, corporate conduct and administration of the NYS Insurance Law for the following types of life insurers:  life insurance companies, life insurance departments of savings banks, public pension funds, fraternal benefit societies, retirement systems, charitable annuity societies, life settlement companies and union welfare funds.  

The Department conducts annual reviews of reserves; issues certificates of reserve valuation; reviews actuarial opinions and memoranda; audits minimum statutory formula reserves; reviews rates and actuarial aspects of life insurance and annuity policy forms; reviews reserve procedures for separate account plans of operation; reviews applications for the creation of continuing care retirement communities; conducts legal reviews and evaluations of life insurance and annuity contracts, reviews related policy forms and life settlement contracts; and drafts regulations and proposed legislation in connection with life insurance policies and annuity contracts.  For more information, contact their office.

Property Insurers:   The Department regulates the financial condition, corporate conduct and administration of the Insurance Law for the following types of property insurers:  fire and marine, casualty and surety, title, financial guaranty and mortgage guaranty. The Department also regulates policy forms and rates for these
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Finance and Insurance

Permit Name: Serving Alcoholic Beverages in New York
Permit Description:
In New York, bartenders and wait staff that sell, dispense, handle, or serve alcoholic beverages must be 18 years of age.  New York does not license bartenders or wait staff.  However, local government entities may have a required occupational license.  For information on whether an occupational license is required, contact the village, town, or city clerk's offices, as well as the county clerk's office.   
 
The NYS Liquor Authority has developed and established minimum criteria for alcohol training awareness programs.  The voluntary program recommends owners of establishments enact a serving policy to prevent the delivery of alcoholic beverages to an intoxicated person, as well as deterring the over consumption of alcoholic beverages by their patrons.  Bartenders and wait staff should receive the necessary knowledge and techniques needed to be responsible servers of alcohol.  This voluntary program provides information on how to protect servers and establishments from liability, how alcohol affects customers, how to recognize the effects of alcohol on customers, how to prevent a customer from becoming intoxicated, how to intervene when you need to refuse a sale, how to prevent and deal with disturbances, and how to accurately check IDs and recognize minors.   
 
The NYS Liquor Authority regularly conducts information and training seminars to insure compliance with the Alcohol Beverage Control Law.  The Program also established that trade schools and other entities, such as trade associations, can administer Alcohol Training Awareness Programs (ATAP).   An approved ATAP provider will issue a certificate of completion after successful completion of the program.  For a listing of Certified Alcohol Training Awareness Programs, visit the NYS Liquor Authority's website.  New York State requires that trade schools be licensed.  The NYS Education Department's Bureau of Proprietary School Supervision licenses trade schools in New York.  For information on whether a trade school is licensed, contact the NYS Education Department's Bureau of Proprietary School Supervision.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Food Service and Processing,Licenses and Permits, Recreation,Licenses and Permits, Retail,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
Underwater logging is the salvaging of logs that loggers have abandoned after they became waterlogged and sank.  A related form of logging is the process of logging trees from underwater forests.  When artificial reservoirs and dams are built, large areas of forest are often inundated; although the trees die, the wood is often preserved.  The trees can then be felled using special underwater machinery and floated up to the surface.   

New York State and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers use the Joint Application Form for all projects, including underwater logging operations that affect streams, waterways, water bodies, wetlands, coastal areas and sources of water supply as well as projects located within or along the Adirondack Park, St. Lawrence River and the New York State Canals and canal reservoirs.  The Joint Application Form is used to seek permits and determinations for activities from certain New York State agencies as well as the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers that are mainly involved in licensing and permitting of underwater logging activities.  
 
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers uses the Joint Application Form to seek approvals for activities affecting the Waters of the United States, including navigable waters and their tributaries, and associated wetlands, coastal areas and sources of water supply.  If you have a project that involves either the placement of dredged or fill material into any waters of the United States, or the performance of any work or placement of any structure into or affecting any navigable water, then you will need authorization from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers prior to beginning the project.  For more information on the U.S. Corps of Engineers Regulatory Program, the Joint Application Form requirements, and for district office contact information, visit their website.  

The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation requires the Joint Application Form to seek approvals for licensing requirements that may affect streams and navigable waters as well as other activities in and around waters in New York.  For licensing information, contact the regional office near the location of operation.  To find a listing of regional offices, visit the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation's website.  Other possible DEC permit requirements may include the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) and Article 15 – Protection of Waters permit.  For information on SEQRA see the links provided below.

The NYS Office of General Services requires the Joint Application Form to seek approvals for easements or permits to undertake activities affecting New York State owned underwater lands.  For licensing information contact the NYS Office of General Services, Real Estate Development, Bureau of Land Management at their website or by telephone.

The NYS Department of State requires the Joint Application Form for a determination of Coastal Consistency Concurrence for activities in or affecting the New York State Coastal Zone.  Activities requiring U.S. Army Corps of Engineers permits or approvals must be determined to be consistent with the policies of the NYS Coastal Management Program and with the State approved Local Waterfront Revitalization Programs before the U.S. Army Corps permit is approved.  For information on consistency reviews by the NYS Department of State, Division of Coastal Resource, visit their website or contact their office by telephone.  

The NYS Department of Taxation and Finance provides information on sales tax requirements and tax exemptions and/or tax credits for certain types of logging equipment.  For more information on tax requirements, contact the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance or visit their website.  

Additionally, if transporting products and/ or equipment on New York State public highways, the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance may require a highway use tax (HUT) certificate of registration.  Every truck, trailer or other self-propelled vehicle with a g
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries

Permit Description:
If you sell clothing or footwear for less than $110 per item or pair of items, or you sell items used to repair this clothing or footwear, your sales are exempt from the New York State 4% sales tax. 

This exemption does not apply to local sales tax unless the county or city imposing the tax also enacted the exemption.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Miscellaneous Personal Services and Related Sales in New York City
Permit Description:
Miscellaneous personal services are generally services that affect the appearance or comfort of people. Personal services are exempt from sales tax in most locations in New York State. However, these services are taxable if you sell them in New York City. If you sell any of these taxable services in New York City, you must register for sales tax purposes, collect the New York City local sales tax, and report these sales as instructed on your sales tax returns. 

You must also register if you sell taxable products anywhere in New York State.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Sales Tax on Certain Transportation Services
Permit Description: New York State and local sales tax applies to certain types of passenger transportation services. Sales tax applies to transportation services provided by livery services, including limousines, black cars, and certain other motor vehicles, (for example, community cars or vans) with a driver. There are exemptions for taxis, buses, and any scheduled public service. The transportation services are subject to sales tax only if the service begins and ends in New York State (intrastate service). For more information on sales tax requirements for transportation services see links below.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
The service of collecting, compiling or analyzing information and furnishing reports to customers is subject to sales tax. As a general rule, furnishing information created or generated from a common database, or information that is widely accessible, is a taxable information service. The sale of a report that uses or relies on statistical models or historical data is also generally considered to be a taxable information service, as is the service of gathering information from a variety of sources and recasting that information into a report.

Certain information services are excluded from tax, including the furnishing of information that is personal or individual in nature and that is not or may not be substantially incorporated in reports furnished to other persons. In some cases, the determination of whether or not a service is a taxable information service requires a fact-intensive examination of the nature of the service being sold and what is being paid for by the purchaser.

If your sales are taxable, you must register for sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
Tanning salons are facilities that offer people the opportunity to tan indoors. Tanning salons typically have several tanning beds or booths in which people lie or stand for a set period of time to gradually tan the skin. Sales of tanning services, whether paid on a per-visit basis or paid for in advance (for example, 10 visits for $50.00), are:

• exempt from state and local sales tax everywhere in New York State outside New York City, but
• subject to New York City’s local sales tax when sold in New York City.

Sales of products to your customers, such as lotions and protective goggles, are sales of tangible personal property subject to tax throughout New York State.

You must register for sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns if:

• you sell tanning services or taxable products in New York City; or
• you sell taxable products outside New York City.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
Sales of tattooing and permanent make-up services are: 

•exempt from state and local sales tax everywhere in New York State outside New York City, but 

•subject to New York City’s local sales tax when sold in New York City.

If you sell these services in New York City, you must register for sales tax purposes, collect tax, and report these sales as instructed on your sales tax returns.

Note: Tattooing services performed in New York City for medical reasons (e.g., cancer radiation therapy) by a person who is licensed under Title VIII of the Education Law are not taxable.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description: Sales of telephone answering services are subject to state and local sales and use tax in New York State. If you provide telephone answering services, you must register for sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Telecommunications (Telephone and Telegraph) and Transmission Companies
Permit Description:
If you are a telecommunications services corporation principally engaged in telecommunications transmission activity, you are subject to a franchise tax on capital stock under Tax Law section 183.

If you are principally engaged in a local telephone business, you are subject to an additional tax on intrastate gross earnings under Tax Law section 184.

If you are a provider of telecommunications services, you are also subject to an annual excise tax on your gross receipts from sales of telecommunication services under Tax Law section 186-e.

If you do business in the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD), you may be subject to the metropolitan transportation business tax (MTA surcharge).
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: A Guide to Sales Tax In New York State
Permit Description:
If you sell taxable tangible personal property, perform taxable services, receive admission charges, operate a hotel or motel, or operate an establishment that sells food or drink, such as a restaurant or tavern, you must register for sales tax.

Once you register and receive a Certificate of Authority from the Tax Department, you must collect sales tax from your customers and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: A Guide to Sales Tax for Automobile Dealers
Permit Description: If you sell motor vehicles, motor vehicle parts, or motor vehicle accessories, your sales are subject to sales tax. If you maintain, service, repair, or install tangible personal property in or on motor vehicles, the charges for your services (your sales) are subject to sales tax. As a result, you must register for sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
To view applicable laws on mortgage brokers, please see the NYS Banking Law, Article 12-D - Licensed Mortgage Bankers through the link below.   
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The association listed below is for reference purposes only and does not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Finance and Insurance

Permit Description:
If you are a contractor or repair person, whether you collect sales tax from a customer depends on whether the work you perform is a capital improvement to real property, or is repair, maintenance, or installation work.

When to collect sales tax:
When you perform work that qualifies as a capital improvement to real property, you should not charge your customer sales tax.

For sales tax purposes, a capital improvement is any addition or alteration to real property that meets all three of the following conditions:
•it substantially adds to the value of the real property, or appreciably prolongs the useful life of the real property;
•it becomes part of the real property or is permanently affixed to the real property so that removal would cause material damage to the property or article itself; and
•it is intended to become a permanent installation. 

When you perform work that qualifies as repair, maintenance, or installation work, you must charge your customer sales tax. These services cover all activities that relate to keeping real property in a condition of fitness, efficiency, readiness, or safety, or restoring it to such condition.

Purchasing materials and supplies:
Materials and other tangible personal property purchased for a project are taxable, whether purchased by a contractor, subcontractor, or the property owner, unless the property owner is entitled to an exemption.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Film Production in New York State
Permit Description:
If you produce films (for sale) in New York State, you can make tax-exempt purchases of:

• tangible personal property used directly and predominantly (more than 50% of the time) to produce a film for sale;
• services to property used directly and predominantly (more than 50% of the time) to produce a film for sale; and
• utilities used directly and exclusively (100% of the time) to operate equipment when producing a film for sale.

To receive an exemption or exclusion from sales tax, you must register for sales tax with the New York State Tax Department.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: New York City Health and Fitness Facilities
Permit Description: If you operate a health and fitness facility in New York City, your sales are subject to the  local New York City sales tax. Health and fitness facilities are facilities that provide customers or members with access to exercise or fitness programs. Taxable sales include membership sales, charges to customers for dues and initiation fees, and sales of services the facility provides (such as child care services, personal training services, and exercise classes).
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: New York State Sales and Use Tax on Protective and Detective Services
Permit Description: Sales of protective services and detective services in New York State are subject to state and local sales and use tax. If you sell these taxable services, you must register for NY sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Sales and Use Tax Classifications of Capital Improvements and Repairs to Real Property
Permit Description:
If you are a contractor or repair person, whether you collect sales tax from a customer depends on whether the work you perform is a capital improvement to real property, or is repair, maintenance, or installation work. 

When to collect sales tax:
When you perform work that qualifies as a capital improvement to real property, you should not charge your customer sales tax.

For sales tax purposes, a capital improvement is any addition or alteration to real property that meets all three of the following conditions:
•it substantially adds to the value of the real property, or appreciably prolongs the useful life of the real property;
•it becomes part of the real property or is permanently affixed to the real property so that removal would cause material damage to the property or article itself; and
•it is intended to become a permanent installation. 

When you perform work that qualifies as repair, maintenance, or installation work, you must charge your customer sales tax. These services cover all activities that relate to keeping real property in a condition of fitness, efficiency, readiness, or safety, or restoring it to such condition.

Purchasing materials and supplies:
Materials and other tangible personal property purchased for a project are taxable, whether purchased by a contractor, subcontractor, or the property owner, unless the property owner is entitled to an exemption.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
If you are a veterinarian licensed under Article 135 of the Education Law who  practices veterinary medicine and provides only the services that your veterinary license requires, your services are not subject to sales tax.

However, if you are a veterinarian who makes taxable sales or provides taxable services, such as grooming, boarding, or pet burial services, you must register for sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax return.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
When determining whether an individual is an employee or an independent contractor, there are vital distinctions to consider for both unemployment insurance (UI) and federal tax purposes. A person is an employee if they perform services under the supervision, direction and control of the employer. The direction would include specifications as to where, when and how the work is performed, as well as the final product. It is not necessary for the employer to exercise such control for the individual to be considered an employee; it is only necessary that the employer has the right to do so. Employers use IRS Form W-2 to report wages, tips and other compensation paid to an employee. 
 
Conversely, independent contractors do not perform services under the supervision, direction and control of the employer, are often in business for themselves, and offer their services to the general public. IRS Form-1099–Misc, Miscellaneous Income, is usually issued to independent contractors to report payments made to them for their services. No taxes are withheld from monies paid. 
  
For more information as to whether an individual is an employee or independent contractor, contact the NYS Department of Labor, Liability and Determination Section or visit their website. The Internal Revenue Service also provides information regarding the distinctions between employees and independent contractors. Form SS-8, Determination of Employees Work Status for Purposes of Federal Employment Taxes and Income Tax Withholding, and Publication 15-A, Employer's Supplemental Tax Guide, are linked below.
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Name: Pet Cemeteries and Pet Crematoriums Law
Permit Description: To view the laws regarding pet cemeteries and pet crematoriums, please see the NYS General Business Law, Article 35-C, through the link below.

Permit Description:
PI/WGP entities need to be bonded:  When your application has been reviewed and approved, we will request a $10,000 surety bond.  The surety company named on the bond must be duly authorized to do business in New York State and must be recognized and approved by the NYS Superintendent of Insurance. 
 
If you employ security guards, you will also be asked to file evidence of liability coverage in the minimum amount of $100,000 per occurrence and $300,000 in the aggregate and must include:  1.  a statement that the coverage includes false arrest or false imprisonment, malicious prosecution, libel, slander and violation of privacy; 2.  A statement that the insurance company is licensed to do business in New York; and 3.  A statement that the policy will not be cancelled or modified without 30 days prior notice to the Department of State.  No security guard company may knowingly employ a security guard unless liability coverage is filed with the Department of State.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Finance and Insurance

Permit Description:
If you have a grocery store business, generally, the food and food products you sell are exempt from sales tax; however, there are exceptions. 

Visit the Tax Department’s website through the link below to learn which kinds of food are subject to sales tax and which are exempt when sold by food stores and similar establishments, including supermarkets, grocery stores, convenience stores, and so on.

Permit Description:
If you hire staff for your business, New York as well as the Federal government have rules and regulations that you must follow.  Listed below are some topics all employers should be aware of:

INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR OR EMPLOYEE

When determining whether an individual is an employer or an independent contractor, there are vital distinctions to consider for both unemployment insurance and federal tax purposes.  A person is an employee if they perform services under the supervision, direction and control of the employer.  The direction would include specifications as to where, when and how the work is performed, as well as the final product.  It is not necessary for the employer to exercise such control for the individual to be considered an employee; it is only necessary that the employer has the right to do so.  Employers use IRS Form W-2 to report wages, tips and other compensation paid to an employee.

Conversely, independent contractors do not perform services under the supervision, direction and control of the employer, are often in business for themselves, and offer their services to the general public.  IRS Form-1099–Misc, Miscellaneous Income, is usually issued to independent contractors to report payments made to them for their services.  No taxes are withheld from monies paid. 

For more information as to whether an individual is an employee or an independent contractor, contact the NYS Department of Labor, Liability and Determination Section or visit their website. The Internal Revenue Service also provides information regarding the distinctions between employees and independent contractors.  Form SS-8, Determination of Employees Work Status for Purposes of Federal Employment Taxes and Income Tax Withholding, and Publication 15-A, Employer's Supplemental Tax Guide, are linked below.

CORPORATE OFFICERS

For unemployment insurance (UI) purposes corporate officers and stockholders who perform services for the corporation are employees. Any payment they receive for such services is remuneration and is reportable and subject to contribution.

EMPLOYMENT ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION (FORM I-9)

The Immigration Reform and Control Act made all U.S. employers responsible to verify the employment eligibility and identity of all employees hired to work in the United States.  Employers must complete the Employment Eligibility Verification form (Form I-9) for all employees, including U.S. citizens.  I-9 forms are not filed with the U.S. government.  Employers must maintain I-9 records in their files for three years after the date of hire or one year after the date the employee's termination of employment. Employers must produce these documents upon inspections within three days.  For more information, contact the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service  or visit their website.  The I-9 Form is linked below.

NYS GUIDE FOR EMPLOYERS

Employer's Guide to Unemployment Insurance, Wage Reporting, and Withholding Tax (NYS50) is a complete guide that describes to employers how to comply with unemployment insurance contribution, wage reporting, and withholding tax obligations (including New York City and Yonkers). It explains employer rights, responsibilities, filing requirements, and reporting new or rehired employees.   For more information, contact the NYS Department of Taxation and Finance or visit their website.  The NYS-50 Publication link is below. 

PAYMENT OF WAGES

An employer's obligation to pay wages to his employees is defined in Article 6 of the NYS Labor Law.  The frequency of payment of wages depends on the classification of the employee.  Employers are required to maintain payroll records showing the hours worked, gross wages, payroll deductions and net wages for each employee and must furnish this information to employees with every payment of wages.  No deductions may be made from wages paid to an employee except those required by law, government rules and regulations, and which are expressly authorized, in writing, b
Permit Categories: Employer Information

Permit Description:
Car wash services are taxable when car wash personnel wash, wax, or vacuum the car or assist with these services.

Car wash services are not taxable if the car or other property is washed, waxed, or vacuumed exclusively with coin-operated equipment; the car is washed without any assistance by the car wash employees; and one of these conditions is met: 
• The customer washes, waxes, or vacuums the car or other property. (A charge for a coin-operated vacuum is not taxable whether it is located at a car wash facility or any other location.)
• The car is washed, waxed, or vacuumed by fully automated equipment.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
Hotel operators must collect sales tax on the room rate or rental charge for hotel occupancy, unless the charge is $2.00 or less per day. A room remarketer (such as an Internet travel site) is considered to be a hotel operator and must collect sales tax on the charge to its customers for hotel occupancy. 

Hotel occupancy is the use, or right to use, a room in a hotel. The term hotel includes hotels, motels, inns, and bed and breakfast establishments.

Room rate or rental charge is the amount that guests must pay to stay in the hotel room (or to have the right to use the hotel room). This amount is taxable at the full state and local sales tax rate.

Hotels in New York City:
Hotels in New York City must charge an additional hotel unit fee of $1.50 per unit per day, in addition to the state and local sales taxes on hotel occupancy.

If operating within the five boroughs of New York City (New York, Bronx, Kings, Richmond or Queens counties), contact the NYC Department of Buildings and NYC Department of City Planning or visit their websites.

Local occupancy:
Certain localities, such as counties, cities, and towns, charge an additional tax on hotel occupancy, commonly known as a bed tax. A bed tax must be shown as a separate charge on a customer’s bill. This tax is not administered by New York State and any questions regarding this tax should be directed to your local taxing jurisdiction.

The NYS General Business Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.

A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business. The association listed below is for reference purposes only and does not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
Sales of advertising services, such as consultation and development of advertising campaigns and placement of advertisements with the media, are not subject to sales tax. 

Sales of tangible personal property (such as layouts or artwork) to the customer prior to furnishing them to the media, or outright sales of tangible personal property to the customer, are subject to sales tax. Any advertising materials created by an advertising agency that are conveyed to its customer by intangible means (e.g., by digital or other electronic media) are not subject to sales tax.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
A temporary placement agency (called a temporary service contractor, or TSC) employs its own staff, which it hires and fires, pays salaries to, and withholds taxes from. A TSC also determines which of its staff members are assigned to which of its clients.

Since TSCs provide services, they must collect sales tax on amounts paid to them by their clients when the services are taxable. Amounts paid by clients to TSCs are not considered salaries or wages for tax purposes. 

TSCs are different from employment agencies. Employment agencies provide individuals who become employees of the agency’s client, who maintains no further relationship with the agency.

Examples of taxable services:
Repairing real property
Window cleaning
Pest control
Trash removal
Interior cleaning and maintenance
Providing guards, watchmen, or other security personnel
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
If you operate a health and fitness club, some of your charges may be subject to full state and local sales tax. If you operate a health and fitness club in New York City, some of your  charges may be subject only to the New York City local sales tax. Visit the Tax Department’s website through the link below for more information about sales tax requirements for health and fitness centers. 

For information regarding bonding, letter of credit, or certificate of deposit, please contact the NYS Department of State, Division of Licensing Services. 
 
To view applicable laws for health clubs, please see the NYS General Business Law, Article 30, Health Club Services through the link below.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description: If you are an operator of an automobile repair or body shop in New York State, you must register for sales tax, collect sales tax from your customers, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description: If you provide cable television transmission services in New York State, the charges for the cable television services are not subject to sales tax. However some charges to your customers, such as those for certain equipment and installation and repair work, are subject to New York State and local tax sales tax.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
New mobile homes are subject to sales tax. Tax is applied to 70% of the retail selling price of the mobile home and to any furnishings that the manufacturer has permanently installed in the home. 

Any tangible personal property that is sold with the mobile home that the manufacturer did not permanently install (such as furniture, fixtures, and appliances) is taxed at 100% of the selling price.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Sales Tax Rates, Additional Sales Taxes, and Fees
Permit Description:
If you sell taxable goods or services in New York State, you must collect New York State and local sales tax from your customers. 

To calculate the sales tax due for a sale, you must use the correct combined state and local sales tax rate. The combined sales tax rate is equal to the state rate plus any local tax a city, county, or school district imposes. Also, the state imposes an additional sales tax in those localities that are within the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District (MCTD). The MCTD is composed of New York City, which includes the counties of Bronx, Kings (Brooklyn), New York (Manhattan), Queens, and Richmond (Staten Island), and the counties of Dutchess, Nassau, Orange, Putnam, Rockland, Suffolk, and Westchester. Usually, you must determine the tax rate according to the delivery jurisdiction (locality) of the taxable goods and services. Tax rates vary by jurisdiction and by the items or services sold.

Certain businesses may be required to collect additional sales taxes or fees. You must collect and remit these taxes and fees in the same manner as the state and local sales taxes. See Tax Bulletin Sales Tax Rates, Additional Sales Taxes, and Fees (TB-ST-825) for more information about these taxes.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Sales and Use Tax on Clothing and Footwear
Permit Description:
If you sell clothing, footwear, or items used to make or repair exempt clothing for less than $110 per item or pair of items, your sales are exempt from the New York State 4% sales and use taxes. This exemption does not apply to local sales and use taxes unless the county or city imposing the taxes elects to provide the exemption.

A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business. The association linked below is for reference purposes only and does not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions.   A professional license is the authorization to practice and use a professional title in New York State.   If you meet all the licensure requirements, you will be issued a license number and be entitled to practice in New York State as of the effective date of licensure.  To practice in New York under the authority of your license, you must reregister every three years (two years for medicine). You are automatically gistered for your first registration period when your license is issued. 
 
The practice of the profession as a certified shorthand reporter is defined as engaging, under such title, in making by a written system of either manual shorthand or machine shorthand, a verbatim record of any oral court proceeding, disposition, hearing or proceeding before any grand jury, referee, commissioner, or arbitrator, or of any convention, deliberative assembly, or meeting of like character.  Certified shorthand reporters or CSRs transcribe passages from notes taken of dictated records or legal proceedings. Only individuals certified by the Board of Regents may use the certified shorthand reporter title.  Court reporters record and transcribe legal proceedings; they may or may not have State certification.  Certified shorthand reporters are professionals certified by the New York State Board of Regents, perform a range of services that include court reporting, freelance reporting, and real-time reporting such as closed captioning of live events. 
 
To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions or visit their website.   The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services,Professional Licenses

Permit Description:
The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions.   A professional license is the authorization to practice and use a professional title in New York State.   If you meet all the licensure requirements, you will be issued a license number and be entitled to practice in New York State as of the effective date of licensure.  To practice in New York under the authority of your license, you must register every three years (two years for medicine). You are automatically registered for your first registration period when your license is issued. 
 
The practice of the profession of chiropractic is defined as detecting and correcting by manual or mechanical means structural imbalance, distortion, or subluxations in the human body for the purpose of removing nerve interference and the effects thereof, where such interference is the result of or related to distortion, misalignment or subluxation of or in the vertebral column.  A license to practice as a chiropractor shall not permit the holder to use radio-therapy, fluoroscopy, or any form of ionizing radiation except X-ray which shall be used for the detection of structural imbalance, distortion, or subluxations in the human body.  The requirements and limitations with respect to the use of X-ray by chiropractors shall be enforced by the New York State commissioner of health.  Chiropractors adjust or manipulate misaligned vertebrae (the bones of your spinal column) to restore correct functioning of your central nerve system. They may also work with other parts of your body affected by the misaligned vertebrae.  Chiropractors may do this by using their hands and various mechanical and electrical instruments. D.C. stands for Doctor of Chiropractic, the degree New York licensed chiropractors must earn. 
 
To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions or visit their website.   The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Health Care,Professional Licenses

Permit Description:
The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions.   A professional license is the authorization to practice and use a professional title in New York State.   If you meet all the licensure requirements, you will be issued a license number and be entitled to practice in New York State as of the effective date of licensure.  To practice in New York under the authority of your license, you must reregister every three years (two years for medicine). The practice of the profession of dental assistant allows a person certified under Section 6608-b of the NYS Education Law, Article 133 or exempt pursuant to Section 6610 of the NYS Education Law, Article 133 shall practice certified dental assisting. Only a person certified pursuant to Section 6608-b of the NYS Education Law, Article 133 shall use the title certified dental assistant.  The practice of certified dental assisting is defined as providing supportive services to a dentist in his/her performance of dental services authorized under this article. Such support shall include providing patient education, taking preliminary medical histories and vital signs to be reviewed by the dentist, placing and removing rubber dams, selecting and prefitting provisional crowns, selecting and prefitting orthodontic bands, removing orthodontic arch wires and ligature ties, placing and removing matrix bands, taking impressions for study casts or diagnostic casts, removing periodontal dressings, and such other dental supportive services authorized by the dentist consistent with regulation, provided that such functions are performed under the direct personal supervision of a licensed dentist in the course of the performance of dental services. Such services shall not include diagnosing and/or performing surgical procedures, irreversible procedures or procedures that would alter the hard or soft tissue of the oral and maxillofacial area or any other procedures determined by the department. The practice of certified dental assisting may be conducted in the office of any licensed dentist or in any appropriately equipped school or public institution but must be done under the direct personal supervision of a licensed dentist. Direct personal supervision means supervision of dental procedures based on instructions given by a licensed dentist in the course of a procedure who remains in the dental office where the supportive services are being performed, personally diagnoses the condition to be treated, personally authorizes the procedures, and before dismissal of the patient, who remains the responsibility of the licensed dentist, evaluates the services performed by the dental assistant.  Nothing herein authorizes a dental assistant to perform any of the services or functions defined as part of the practice of dental hygiene in accordance with the provisions of subdivision1 of Section 6606 of the NYS Education Law, Article 133, except those functions authorized pursuant to Section 6608 of the NYS Education Law, Article 133. All dental supportive services provided may be performed by currently registered dental hygienists under a dentist's supervision, as defined in regulations. 

To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions or visit their website.  The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms.

The practice of the profession of a certified dietitian or certified nutritionist integrates and applies principles derived from nutrition, biochemistry, physiology, food management, and behavioral and social sciences to achieve and maintain people's health and who is certified as such by the NYS Education Department pursuant to Section 8004 of the NYS Education Law, Article 157. The primary function of a certified dietitian or certified nutritionist is the provision of nutrition care services that include:  assessing nutrition needs and food patterns; planning for and directing the provision of food appropriate for physical and nutrition needs; and providing nutrition counseling.  The title certified dietitian or certified nutritionist is used shall mean certified dietitian, certified dietician, or certified nutritionist.   
 
To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions or visit their website.  The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms.

The practice of the profession of land surveying is defined as practicing that branch of the engineering profession and applied mathematics which includes the measuring and plotting of the dimensions and areas of any portion of the earth, including all naturally placed and man- or machine-made structures and objects thereon, the lengths and directions of boundary lines, the contour of the surface and the application of rules and regulations in accordance with local requirements incidental to subdivisions for the correct determination, description, conveying and recording thereof or for the establishment or reestablishment thereof.  A New York licensed land surveyor (LS) is a professional who uses applied mathematics and other technical and research skills to measure and plot the dimensions of any portion of the earth's surface (including natural and other structures); the lengths and directions of boundary lines; and the contour of the earth's surface.  
 
To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions or visit their website.  The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms.

Permit Description:
The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions.   A professional license is the authorization to practice and use a professional title in New York State.   If you meet all the licensure requirements, you will be issued a license number and be entitled to practice in New York State as of the effective date of licensure.  To practice in New York under the authority of your license, you must register every three years (two years for medicine). You are automatically registered for your first registration period when your license is issued. 
 
An ophthalmic dispenser commonly called an optician is a licensed health care professional who adapts and fits lenses to correct deficiencies, deformities, or abnormalities of the eyes based on a written prescription from a licensed physician or optometrist. Contact lens practitioners are ophthalmic dispensers who are certified to fit contact lenses. Ophthalmic dispensers and certified contact lens practitioners work to:  achieve the best visual clarity possible for their customers; assist in the selection of frames; and choose appropriate ophthalmic lenses or contact lenses to suit your needs. 
 
Ophthalmic dispensers perform the following services:  determine what lenses will best fit a prescription; select lenses to suit the customer's visual needs and lifestyle; instruct in the proper care of glasses; and participate in customer education.  Certified contact lens practitioners do all of these things as well as fit contact lenses. 
 
Certification by the American Board of Opticianry is not equivalent to licensure in New York state. 
 
To obtain a license application or information, contact the NYS Education Department, Office of the Professions or visit their website.  The website provides a summary of the requirements for licensure or certification, links to applicable laws and regulations, as well as the required application forms.

Permit Description:
The Mold program requires that assessors, contractors and their workers in the mold remediation industry are properly trained and licensed.  The Department of Labor enforces the New York State Labor Law, which will require that a licensed mold assessor perform initial assessment and final inspection work and a separate licensed mold remediation contractor perform the cleanup and removal work. 
 
The law requires the following to ensure the proper remediation of mold: 
 
- Licensing of assessors, contractors and workers 
- A written mold remediation plan, prepared by a licensed mold assessment contractor 
 
The requirement to be licensed by the Department of Labor takes effect on January 1, 2016. 
 
For additional information, please select the link below entitled Mold Law.

The Board of Regents and the NYS Education Department oversee the preparation, licensure, and practice of the professions.
