Permit Description: A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The associations listed below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
Charges for storage services are subject to sales tax. Charges for the rental or lease of real property are not subject to sales tax even if the tenant is using the real property to store property (for self-storage).

Indicators of a rental or lease of real property include:

• the tenant contracts for a certain amount of footage in a specific location;
• the tenant has unlimited control of access to the space and exclusive possession of the space;
• the tenant's possession and control of the space must be to the exclusion of the lessor (as described below);
• the tenant is allowed to supply racks, cabinets, and other facilities for their own use in the leased space; and
• the proprietor does not provide any additional services that require the tenant to give up possession and control of their property to the proprietor (such as receiving, handling, storing, or forwarding of the tenant's personal property).

Storage in transit, which occurs in the context of a moving service, has special rules relating to sales tax. Visit the Tax Department’s website through the link below to learn more—NYS sales tax: Household movers and warehousers. 

NYS Lien Law, Article 8, Section 182.7 allows for the enforcement of a lien upon the unpaid occupancy fees or other charges for services rendered. Storage/Self-storage facility owners should file NYS Department of Motor Vehicles' Form MV-905, Self-Storage Owner/Operator Affirmation and Bill of Sale as a sworn statement concerning the sale of a vehicle or boat to obtain compensation for unpaid storage charges. NYS DMV's Form MV-905 is available on their website through the link below or by visiting a local DMV office.

The NYS General Business Law has information and requirements for the storage of household goods. The NYS Lien Law has lien information for self-storage facilities. 

Applicable Laws: 

The NYS General Business Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.

The NYS Lien Law is available on the NYS Legislature's website through the link below.

A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business. The 2 associations linked below are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: Coupons and Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
Permit Description:
The NYS Tax Department’s website provides detailed guidance to help businesses determine the amount of sales tax due when customers use store-issued coupons, manufacturers' coupons, or SNAP benefits on purchases of items that are subject to sales tax. 

In general:
•A store-issued coupon reduces the amount of sales tax due, while a manufacturer’s coupon does not.
•A food or beverage item ordinarily subject to sales tax is nontaxable when the item is purchased with SNAP benefits.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: International Fuel Tax Agreement (IFTA) for New York State Carriers
Permit Description:
New York State is a participating member of the International Fuel Tax Agreement (IFTA).
 
IFTA allows a motor carrier to report to a single base jurisdiction all the fuel use taxes it owes to the various IFTA member jurisdictions. If you’re a qualifying motor vehicle, you must file IFTA quarterly returns and you may be required to use IFTA e-file.

Under IFTA, a carrier needs only a single IFTA license for all its qualified motor vehicles.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description: Retail Establishments with 10,000 square feet or more of retail space and chain stores which operate five or more stores with greater than 5,000 square feet of retail space that provide plastic carry out bags to its customers as a result of the sale of a product, must establish an at-store plastic bag recycling program by making visible and easily accessible collection bins for plastic bag recycling available to customers, ensure that collected plastics are recycled and not disposed of, label plastic bags distributed in the establishment with appropriate messaging, keep records on their program, and sell reusable bags.  Shopping malls with 50,000 square feet or more of retail space are required to establish their own plastic carry out bag recycling programs. For more information on the specific requirements, contact the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation or see the link below.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description:
All apparel manufacturers and contractors engaged in the making, cutting, sewing, finishing, assembling, pressing or otherwise producing of any men's, women's, children's, or infant's apparel or section or component thereof must register with the NYS Department of Labor's Apparel Industry Task Force. This includes but is not limited to apparel services industries such as contractors, jobbers, or manufacturers engaged in pleating, embroidery, stitching, buttons, belts, trimmings, shoulder pads and other accessories. Exemptions are the cleaning or tailoring after the apparel has been sold at retail. Additionally, when a retailer works directly with a contractor to produce garments, the retailer is considered a manufacturer and must register as well. 

The NYS Labor Law, Article 12A requires all Apparel Industry Manufacturers and Contractors to register each year, on or before January 15th, if they produce garments or accessories for garments in New York State. Registration ensures that apparel firms meet basic standards, such as maintaining Workers' Compensation/Disability Insurance, providing Unemployment Insurance coverage, and paying outstanding civil penalties. The law requires that apparel firms do business only with registered apparel contractors and manufacturers. 

The NYS Department of Labor maintains a registration database with businesses registered as contractors or manufacturers. A garment contractor or manufacturer that fails to register is breaking state law and is considered a sweatshop operation. The NYS Department of Labor also recommends that you ask a contractor whether your order may be subcontracted out. If so, there is a chance that sweatshop labor might be used at some point in production and the garment produced may be considered 'unlawfully manufactured.' 

The NYS Department of Labor's Apparel Industry Task Force conducts monthly seminars for manufacturers, contractors, retailers and business groups to help raise working standards and strengthen voluntary compliance with state and federal laws. For further information and compliance contact the NYS Department of Labor, Apparel Industry Task Force. 

Sales Tax Obligations:
If you sell clothing, footwear, or items used to make or repair exempt clothing for less than $110 per item or pair of items, your sales are exempt from the New York State 4% sales and use taxes. This exemption does not apply to local sales and use taxes unless the county or city imposing the taxes elects to provide the exemption.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Manufacturing

Permit Name: A Dealer's Guide to Sales and Use Taxes on Long-Term Motor Vehicle Leases in New York State
Permit Description:
If you lease motor vehicles, you must register for sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.

Collect the sales tax due from the lessee on the earlier of the following dates:

• the date the first lease payment is due, or 
• the date the vehicle is registered with the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV).
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
New York State imposes an excise tax on the sale or use in New York State of beer, wine, cider, and liquor.

New York City imposes an additional excise tax on the sale or use in New York City of:
• beer; and
• liquor containing more than 24% alcohol by volume.

The Tax Department both administers and collects the state and city excise taxes. If you’re a distributor of alcoholic beverages (beer, wine, or liquor), you must register with the Tax Department.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
If you sell cigarettes or  tobacco products, you must register with the Tax Department before you start doing business in New York State. Depending on the nature of your business, you may be required to obtain more than one type of registration or license. 

Once registered, you must file tax returns with the Tax Department even if no tax is due. 

Note: There is an additional excise tax on the sale or use of cigarettes in New York City.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Description:
The NYS Agriculture and Markets Law, Article 20-C defines food processing as the processing of foods in any manner, such as by manufacturing, canning, preserving, freezing, drying, dehydrating, grinding, juicing, pickling, baking, brining, bottling, packing, repacking, pressing, waxing, heating or cooking, or otherwise treating food in such a way as to create a risk that it may become adulterated if improperly handled.  Certain types of food processors are exempt from some statutory and regulatory requirements.  Therefore, it is advisable to contact the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets for detailed requirements regarding your particular business at the Division of Food Safety and Inspection, or visit their website.

Retail food stores that conduct any type of food preparation such as meat or cheese grinding, heating foods, sandwich and beverage dispensing machines, prepare sushi, salad bars, or other ready to eat exposed foods packaging activities need to follow statutory and regulatory requirements as well as beverage plants that produce soft drinks, flavored waters, beer, wine, fruit juice, etc.

Manufacturers of non-beverage products that require the purchase of liquor, wine or beer from duly licensed manufacturers or wholesalers for use in the process of such products require a One-Time/Three Years Non-Beverage Manufacturer license issued through the NYS Liquor Authority. 

Food processors, retail food stores, and beverage plants must demonstrate compliance with sanitation regulations, as well as safe food handling, processing, and storage procedures.  The NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets, Division of Food Safety and Inspection's staff conducts sanitary inspections to ensure statutory and regulatory compliance.  The number of inspections done annually depends upon the potential hazard of the food or the process.  Food inspectors routinely collect food samples and send them to the State Food Laboratory for analysis.  The Department's Circular 933 Human Foods:  Current Good Manufacturing Practice helps food processors, retail food stores, and beverage plants meet these requirements.  

The U.S. Department of Agriculture and U.S. Food and Drug Administration as well as the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets regulate food-labeling requirements.  Contact the NYS Department of Agriculture of Markets for information on complying with these requirements.

The State Agriculture and Markets Law charges the Department with the promotion of New York’s agricultural products. Through various marketing initiatives and on-product labeling, the Department welcomes and promotes all facets of the agricultural industry, including: food processors, maple syrup and honey producers, and craft beverage manufacturers. For more information on the services offered, visit the “Marketing and Promotion” section of the official Department of Agriculture and Markets website.

The New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets inspects commercial weighing or measuring devices to assure accurate measures.  Owners of food processing and manufacturing establishments should notify the appropriate municipal to have devices inspected.  For more information on requirements and regulations, contact the local weights and measures department or the NYS Department of Agriculture and Markets, Bureau of Weights and Measures or visit their website through the link below.

The NYS Department of Environmental Conservation, Pollution Prevention Unit has several guidelines for the food processing industry regarding environmental compliance requirements.  You can contact them for a copy of the guidelines or see the link below.

Federal Law generally prohibits the sale of endangered or threatened species that may be considered an exotic meat, including parts and products, in interstate or foreign commerce.  However, the sale of such products, manufactured prior to the Endangered Species Act (1973), or otherwise legally obtained and possessed, c
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Food Service and Processing,Licenses and Permits, Manufacturing,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description:
The New York State Farmers' Market Nutrition Program (FMNP) assists low-income, nutritionally at risk families enrolled in the Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) and Senior Nutrition Programs in getting the nutritionally valuable fruits and vegetables they need from participating farmers' markets 
 
Through a collaborative effort of the Department of Agriculture and Markets, the Department of Health, the Office for the Aging, and Comell Cooperative Extension,  this program hopes to promote improved nutrition through increased consumption of locally grown fresh fruits and vegetables as well as expand sales at farmers' markets.  
 
There is no fee for farmers to participate. However they must sign up annually with the manager of the market in which they plan to participate. Farmers will receive participation materials from the Department of Agriculture and Markets after signing up.  
 
For more information on taking advantage of this program please see the link below labeled Farmers' Market Nutrition Program.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries

Permit Description:
Taste NY shines a spotlight on the high-quality foods and beverages produced in New York, and features Taste NY retail stores, concessions and other markets as well as participation in important industry events and roadside signage placed throughout the State. It also has its own website featuring up-to-date information on Taste NY locations and upcoming events. 
 
Taste NY is overseen by the Department of Agriculture and Markets and has created opportunities for local producers to showcase their goods at large public events, such as the Great New York State Fair. By opening stores at Thruway rest stops and other transportation hubs, travelers are able buy New York State's homegrown and homemade products. Approximately 1,100 local companies have participated in these opportunities, further linking their products and the state's growing food and beverage market to consumers from across the globe. 
 
The New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets is dedicated to promoting New York’s agricultural products. Through various marketing initiatives and on-product labeling, the Department welcomes and promotes all facets of the agricultural industry, including food processors, maple syrup and honey producers, and craft beverage manufacturers. For more information on the services offered, visit the “Marketing and Promotion” section of the official Department of Agriculture and Markets website.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Food Service and Processing

Permit Description:
NYS Judiciary Law, Article 15 requires the examination and admission of attorneys to practice law in New York.  Anyone wishing to practice law in New York must pass the NYS bar examination or receive a special dispensation from taking the examination.  The NYS Board of Law Examiners gives the NYS bar examination twice a year.  Contact the NYS Board of Law Examiners for further information. 
 
After passing the NYS bar examination or receiving a special dispensation from taking the examination, candidates must apply for admission, swearing in, and have a character and fitness interview.  Application materials and contact information is available at the NYS Board of Law Examiners website.  New York has reciprocity with 27 states, contact the NYS Board of Law Examiners for more information on these requirements. 
 
Section 468 – 468-a of the NYS Judiciary Law, Article 15 requires the biennial registration of all attorneys admitted in New York.  The fee for this registration is $350.  All attorneys are required to renew their attorney registration every two years.  Prior to renewal attorneys are required to fulfill Continuing Legal Education (CLE) requirements.  For detailed information, contact the Office of Court Administration or visit their website.  
 
Effective January 1, 2015 there is an addition of section 520-16 to 22 NYCRR relating to admission of attorneys and counselors of law.  For further information see the NY Courts Rule link below. 
 
Complaints against attorneys are handled by Grievance Committees in the various Judicial Districts around the State.  For further information please see the Brochure link below. 
 
A trade association is a valuable source for information, services and advice for your business.  The 2 associations linked at the bottom are for reference purposes only and do not constitute an endorsement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Services

Permit Description:
Real Estate eAccessNY is a user-friendly online license management system for real estate brokers, salespersons, and the general public. The site gives real estate professionals the ability to quickly process real estate license transactions including applications, changes and renewals. Members of the general public and licensees can also verify a real estate professional’s license status on the site.  
 
Real Estate eAccessNY is available on the New York State Department of State’s website. 
 
These services are available on eAccessNY. 
 
Salespersons can: 
• complete the initial salesperson application  
• change residence address 
• renew a license 
• request a duplicate license.  
 
Brokers can: 
• change principal or branch office 
• change residence address 
• renew a license 
• request a duplicate license  
• approve salesperson sponsorship 
• initiate and approve a change of association 
• initiate and approve a termination of an association. 
 
Examinees can: 
• schedule a real estate salesperson or broker examination at an exam site of choice 
• check scheduled exam date, time, and location 
• reschedule an exam date 
• view exam results. 
 
Schools can: 
• apply for continuing education courses  
• add course branch locations  
• renew courses.  
 
The public can: 
• search for currently approved qualifying courses 
• search for and verify that real estate salespersons and brokers are currently licensed.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Real Estate

Permit Name:
Apostille or Certificate of Authentication
 (Authentication of Public Documents)
Permit Description:
If you wish to use a certified document from New York State in a foreign country, you will need to have the document authenticated. This authentication certifies the signature on the document and the capacity of the official who has executed the document. The authentication may also validate the seal of the official.

The New York Secretary of State authenticates public documents for use in foreign countries. Only public documents that were issued in New York State and signed by either a State Official or a County Clerk can be authenticated. 

There are two types of authentication that can used in foreign countries: "Apostille" and "Certificates of Authentication." Countries that use the Apostille authentication have signed the 1961 Hague Convention abolishing the Requirement of Legalization for Foreign Public Documents. Countries that are not members of the 1961 Hague Convention require a Certificate of Authentication.

An Apostille or Certificate of Authentication is issued by the New York Secretary of State through the Department of State. It is a one-page document with a blue laser printed facsimile of the New York Department of State Seal. Both the Apostille and Certificate of Authentication include the facsimile signature of the New York Secretary of State or his/her deputy.

To learn which countries follow the Hague Convention, please see the link to the list of signatory countries below. If the country in which you wish to use the document is listed, you can use an Apostille. If it is not, you should obtain a Certificate of Authentication.

Apostille:
The 1961 Hague Convention established Apostille guidelines. The Convention provides for the simplified certification of public (including notarized) documents to be used in countries that have joined the convention. Under the Hague Convention, signatory countries have agreed to recognize public documents issued by other signatory countries if those public documents are authenticated by the attachment of an internationally recognized form of authentication known as an Apostille. The Apostille ensures that public documents issued in one signatory country will be recognized as valid in another signatory country.

Certificate of Authentication:
For countries that do not accept the Apostille certification, you need a Certificate of Authentication. The New York Secretary of State issues Certificates of Authentication to authenticate public documents for use in any country that is not a member of the 1961 Hague Convention. In some cases, Certificates of Authentication may require an additional certification from the United States Department of State prior to submission to the foreign country (See the link below).

Obtaining and Preparing Documents for Authentication:

Vital Records
To obtain Birth, Death, Marriage or Divorce Records (vital records), you should make a request to the original office where the document was filed. To determine the appropriate office to obtain the vital record we suggest you refer to the New York State Department of Health web page on vital records at the link below.

Birth, Death, Marriage and Certificate of Divorce certificates submitted to the New York Department of State for an Apostille or Certificate of Authentication must first be certified by either a New York State Official or a County Clerk. The Department of State will not issue Apostilles/Certificates of Authentication without this certification.

Please Note: Birth and death certificates issued from the New York City Department of Health will also require a Letter of Exemplification. Therefore, you must request a Letter of Exemplification when requesting a birth or death certificate. Both the birth or death certificate and the Letter of Exemplification must be certified by the New York County Clerk prior to submission to the New York Department of State.

Educational Documents
To obtain educational documents such as transcripts, diplomas or certificates, contact the school, college or un
Permit Categories: General Business Information

Permit Description:
Federal regulations provide detailed requirements for the farm production methods and products that can be used when farmers and food 
manufacturers wish to label their products "certified organic." Anyone producing over $5,000 of product that wishes to label and sell their 
farm or commercial product as "organic" must be certified. Farmers and food processors must both be certified, as must distributors involved 
in repackaging. 
 
To become certified organic you must familiarize yourself with the regulations that were finalized in 2002 by the U.S. Department of 
Agriculture and determine if you meet those standards or would like to transition over the next several years to meet those standards. Once 
you feel you are eligible to become certified organic you must contact an accredited certifying agent to begin the application process. 
Please see the link below labeled Organizations Providing Organic Certification Services for Producers and Processors in New York State 
for a list of accredited agencies. 
 
Organic farmers and processors are eligible for a reimbursement of 75% of their annual certification fee costs not to exceed $750. The 
certification must be conducted by an organization accredited by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. For more information regarding 
reimbursement please see the link below labeled Organic Certification Reimbursement.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries

Permit Description: The Stamps on Consignment program allows customers to purchase stamps at locations other than the Post Office. There are over 62,000 retail locations that bring stamps closer to your customers' fingertips. Grocery stores, convenience stores, and ATMs are just a few of the many places where customers can purchase stamps—with no additional surcharges. By participating in the Stamps on Consignment program, you provide additional convenience to your customers.  Use the link below for information on the U.S. Postal Service's Stamps on Consignment Program and to find the nearest postmaster.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description:
Domestic and foreign business corporations are required by Section 408 of the Business Corporation Law to file a Biennial Statement every two years with the New York Department of State.   The filing period for a business corporation is the calendar month in which its original Certificate of Incorporation or Application for Authority was filed with the New York Department of State. 
 
Domestic and foreign limited liability companies (LLCs) are required by Section 301(e) of the Limited Liability Company Law to file a Biennial Statement every two years with the New York Department of State.  The filing period for a LLC is the calendar month in which its original Articles of Organization or Application for Authority was filed with the New York Department of State. 
 
You may file online using the Department of State’s e-Statement Filing Service and pay the filing fee using a credit card or debit card. The e-Statement Filing Service is available Monday-Friday from 6:00 a.m. to 7:30 p.m., except legal holidays. You must have the exact name of the entity and its DOS ID number to file. The exact name of the entity and its DOS ID number may be found by searching in the New York State Department of State’s Corporation and Business Entity Database. A Biennial Statement may not be filed prior to the calendar month in which the Biennial Statement is due.  
 
If an email address has been provided to the Department of State, the Department will send an email notice at the beginning of the calendar month in which the Biennial Statement is due. Entities who wish to receive email Biennial Statement notices must provide an email address at the Department of State’s Email Address Submission/Update Service (See link below). 
 
A corporation or LLC that fails to file its Biennial Statement will be reflected in the New York Department of State’s records as past due in the filing of its Biennial Statement. Any Certificate of Status or status letter obtained from the New York Department of State will reflect that the corporation or LLC is past due in the filing of its Biennial Statement. This may prevent the corporation or LLC from completing certain business transactions. 

Corporations 
 
Domestic and foreign business corporations are required to file a Biennial Statement setting forth:  
• the name and business address of its chief executive officer, 
• the street address of its principal executive office, and  
• the address to which the New York Secretary of State shall forward copies of process accepted on behalf of the corporation. 
 
Farm corporations are exempt from filing Biennial Statements.  The term "farm corporation" means any domestic corporation or foreign corporation authorized to do business in this state engaged in the production of crops, livestock and livestock products on land used in agricultural production, as defined in section 301 of the agriculture and markets law.  If a corporation is a farm corporation, you must request a paper Biennial Statement form directly from the Department of State.  Check the Farm Corporation Exemption box, complete Part 4 on the Biennial Statement and return it to the Department of State for filing.  No filing fee is required. 

Limited Liability Companies 
 
Domestic and foreign limited liability companies are required to file Biennial Statements updating the address to which the New York Secretary of State shall mail a copy of any process accepted on its behalf.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
The agent for service of process of a corporation or other business entity may change his or her own address on file with the New York State Department of State. The agent must file a Certificate of Change. The completed Certificate of Change, together with the filing fee listed below, should be forwarded to the New York Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231.

Certificate of Change, Domestic Business Corporations
The agent for service of process of a domestic corporation may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 805-A of the Business Corporation Law.
Filing Fee $5

Certificate of Change of Application for Authority, Foreign Corporations 
The agent for service of process of a foreign corporation may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 1309-A of the Business Corporation Law. 
Filing Fee $5

Certificate of Change, Domestic Not-for-Profit Corporations
The agent for service of process of a domestic corporation may change his or her own address on file with the Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 803-A of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.
Filing Fee $20 

Certificate of Change, Foreign Not-for-Profit Corporations
The agent for service of process of a foreign corporation may change his or her own address on file with the Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 1310 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.
Filing Fee $20 

Certificate of Change, Domestic Limited Liability Companies
The agent for service of process of a domestic limited liability company may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 211-A of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law.
Filing Fee $5

Certificate of Change, Foreign Limited Liability Companies
The agent for service of process of a foreign limited liability company may change his or her own address on file with the Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 804-A of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law.
Filing Fee $5

Certificate of Change, Domestic Limited Partnerships
The agent for service of process of a domestic limited partnership may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 121-202-A of the New York State Revised Limited Partnership Act.
Filing Fee $5

Certificate of Change, Foreign Limited Partnerships
The agent for service of process of a foreign limited partnership may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 121-903-A of the New York State Revised Limited Partnership Act.
Filing Fee $5

Certificate of Change, Domestic Limited Liability Partnerships
The addressee for service of process of a domestic registered limited liability partnership may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 121-1500(j-1) of the New York State Partnership Law.   The certificate of change must be drafted by the filer by following the requirements of Section 121-1500(j-1) of the New York State Partnership Law. The certificate must be enclosed in a white cover sheet that sets forth the title of the document and the name and address of the individual to whom the receipt for the filing should be mailed. 
Filing Fee $5

Certificate of Change, Foreign Limited Liability Partnerships
The addressee for service of process of a New York registered foreign limited liability partnership may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change pursuant to Section 1

Permit Name: Certificate of Change of Address of Registered Agent
Permit Description:
Certificate of Change of Address of Registered Agent, Domestic Business Corporation 
The registered agent of a domestic corporation may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change of Address of Registered Agent pursuant to Section 805-A(b) of the Business Corporation Law. The form for filing may be purchased from a legal stationery store in New York State or may be drafted by the filer by following the requirements of Section 805-A(b) of the Business Corporation Law. The certificate must be enclosed in a white cover sheet that sets forth the title of the document and the name and address of the individual to whom the receipt for the filing should be mailed. 
 
Certificate of Change of Address of Registered Agent, Foreign Business Corporations 
The registered agent of a foreign corporation may change his or her own address on file with the New York Department of State by filing a Certificate of Change of Address of Registered Agent pursuant to Section 1309-A(c) of the Business Corporation Law. The form for filing may be drafted by the filer by following the requirements of Section 1309-A(c) of the Business Corporation Law. The certificate must be enclosed in a white cover sheet that sets forth the title of the document and the name and address of the individual to whom the receipt for the filing should be mailed. 
 
The completed Certificate of Change should be forwarded to the New York Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231. 
 
Filing Fee $5
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

The completed Certificate of Change should be forwarded to the New York Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231.

Filing Fee: $30 
 
Certificate of Change, Foreign Limited Partnerships 
Please review Section 121-903-A(a) of the New York State Revised Limited Partnership Act.

Permit Name: Certificate of Change, Domestic Corporations and Other Business Entities
Permit Description:
A corporation or other business entity may (1) change the name and address of its designated address for the New York Secretary of State to mail service of process; (2) change its county location; or (3) make, revoke, or change the designation of a registered agent by filing a Certificate of Change with the Department of State. 
 
The completed Certificate of Change, together with the filing fee below, should be forwarded to the New York Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231. 
 
Certificate of Change, Domestic Business Corporations 
Domestic corporations may change the information above in their Certificate of Incorporation. Please review Section 805-A of the Business Corporation Law. 
Filing Fee: $30 
 
Certificate of Change, Not-for-Profit Domestic Corporations 
Domestic not-for-profit corporations may change the information above in their Certificate of Incorporation. Please review Section 803-A of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. 
Filing Fee: $20 
 
Certificate of Change, Domestic Limited Liability Companies  
A domestic limited liability company may change the information above in its Articles of Organization. Please review Section 211-A of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law. 
Filing Fee: $30 
 
Certificate of Change, Domestic Limited Partnerships   
A domestic limited partnership may change the information above in its Certificate of Limited Partnership. Please review Section 121-202-A(a) of the New York State Revised Limited Partnership Act. 
Filing Fee: $30
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
New York State law permits the merger or consolidation of corporations and other business entities. A Certificate of Merger that complies with the applicable statutory requirements must be filed with the Department of State.  The Certificate of Merger must be enclosed in a white cover sheet that sets forth the title of the document and the name and address of the individual to whom the receipt for the filing should be mailed.  
 
The completed Certificate of Merger/Consolidation, together with the filing fee listed below, should be forwarded to the New York Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231. 
 
Certificate of Merger/Consolidation, Domestic and Foreign Business Corporations 
Sections 901 and 904-a of the Business Corporation Law permit the merger or consolidation of business corporations with other business corporations and/or other business entities. Certificates of Merger pursuant to Sections 904, 904-a, 905, or 907 of the Business Corporation Law may be drafted by the filer by following the requirements of the appropriate section of law. The certificate must be enclosed in a white cover sheet that sets forth the title of the document and the name and address of the individual to whom the receipt for the filing should be mailed. 
Filing Fee: $60 
 
Certificates of Merger/Consolidation, Domestic and Foreign Not-for-Profit Corporations 
Sections 901 and 908 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law permit the merger or consolidation of not-for-profit corporations with other corporations.  Certificates of Merger pursuant to 904, 906, or 908 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law may be drafted by the filer by following the requirements of the appropriate section of law. 
Filing Fee: $30 
 
Certificates of Merger/Consolidation, Domestic and Foreign Limited Liability Companies 
Section 1003 of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law permits the merger or consolidation of limited liability companies with other limited liability companies and/or other business entities. The New York Department of State provides three sample Certificates of Merger forms for Limited Liability Companies. See the links below. 
Filing Fee: $60 
 
Certificates of Merger/Consolidation, Domestic and Foreign Limited Partnerships 
Sections 121-1101 and 121-1106 of the New York State Revised Limited Partnership Act permit the merger or consolidation of limited partnerships with other limited partnerships and/or other business entities.  A Certificate of Merger (or Consolidation) pursuant to Section 121-1103 of the New York State Revised Limited Partnership Act must be drafted by the filer by following the requirements of the statute. 
Filing Fee: $60
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Certificate of Resignation for Receipt of Process, Domestic Limited Liability Partnerships

Certificate of Resignation for Receipt of Process, Foreign Limited Liability Partnerships

Permit Name: Certificate of Surrender of Authority – Foreign Business Corporation
Permit Description:
A foreign authorized corporation entity may surrender its authority to conduct business in New York State.  This process involves both the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance and the New York State Department of State.

The foreign corporation must first obtain the consent of the State Tax Commission of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. To receive the consent, the corporation must have all returns on file and taxes paid from the date it was authorized to do business in New York State. For details on procedures related to taxes in surrendering authority, see TR-199 below. Once the corporation is up to date on tax filing and payments, it will receive a Written Consent.

The foreign corporation should then file a Certificate of Surrender of Authority with the Department of State. The Certificate of Surrender of Authority (1563-f-l) can be downloaded from the New York State Department of State’s website (see link below), or it can be drafted following the requirements in Section 1310 of the New York State Business Corporation Law. 

The corporation should forward the Certificate of Surrender of Authority, Written Consent, and $60 filing fee to the New York State Department of State at New York Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231.

The New York State Department of State will review the materials.  When the Certificate of Surrender of Authority is filed, the Department of State will issue a filing receipt to the filer of the document.  

A foreign corporation that surrenders its authority does not end its obligation to pay taxes if it is subject to tax or becomes subject to tax in New York State.

Amendments:

A foreign corporation that has surrendered its authority to do business in New York State may amend the address to which the New York Secretary of State will mail a copy of any process accepted on behalf of the corporation. To do so, the corporation may file a Certificate of Amendment of Certificate of Surrender of Authority pursuant to Section 1310 of the Business Corporation Law. 
The completed Certificate of Amendment of Certificate of Surrender of Authority together with the statutory fee of $60, should be forwarded to the New York Department of State at the address above.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
A foreign authorized corporation or other business entity that has been dissolved, merged out of existence, or had its authority to conduct its business terminated or canceled in its jurisdiction of incorporation or formation must file a Certificate of Termination of Existence with the New York State Department of State.  
 
A certificate of the Secretary of State or official performing the equivalent function as to corporation or other business entity records in the jurisdiction of incorporation or formation attesting to the occurrence of any such event or a certified copy of an order or decree of a court directing the dissolution of such corporation or other business entity, the termination of its existence or the surrender of its authority must be filed with the Department of State.  Please refer to the relevant laws below. The document must contain a white cover sheet that sets forth the title of the document being submitted and the name and address of the individual to whom the receipt for the filing of the document should be mailed. 
 
The Certificate of Termination of Existence, together with the statutory filing fee, should be forwarded to the New York State Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231.  
 
Certificate of Termination of Existence, Foreign Business Corporations 
Filing Fee: $60 
Please review Section 1311 of the Business Corporation Law. 
 
Certificate of Termination of Existence, Foreign Not-for-Profit Corporations  
Filing Fee: $30 
Please review Section 1312 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. 
 
Certificate of Termination of Existence, Foreign Limited Liability Companies 
Filing Fee: $60 
Please review Section 807 of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law. 
 
Certificate of Termination of Existence, Foreign Limited Partnerships 
Filing Fee: $60 
Please review Section 121-906 of the New York State Revised Limited Partnership Act.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
The Certificate of Incorporation, Articles of Organization, Certificate of Limited Partnership, Certificate of Registration, Application for Authority or Notice of Registration of a corporation or other business entity may be amended by filing a Certificate of Amendment with the Department of State.  

Completed Certificates of Amendment, together with the statutory filing fee listed below, should be forwarded to the New York Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231. 

Certificate of Amendment, Domestic Business Corporations 
A domestic business corporation may amend its Certificate of Incorporation by filing a Certificate of Amendment under Section 805 of the Business Corporation Law. The Certificate of Amendment may amend any of the information that may be contained in a Certificate of Incorporation (name change; revision to the purpose clause; alteration of stock, etc.). 
Filing Fee: $60
 
Certificate of Amendment, Foreign Business Corporations 
A foreign authorized business corporation may amend its Application for Authority by filing a Certificate of Amendment pursuant to Section 1309 of the Business Corporation Law. The Application for Authority may only be amended to amend or add such provisions that may be lawfully contained in the Application for Authority (name change, revisions to purposes, etc.).
Filing Fee: $60

Certificate of Amendment, Domestic Not-for-Profit Corporations
A domestic not-for-profit corporation may amend its Certificate of Incorporation by filing a Certificate of Amendment under Section 803 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. The document may amend any of the information that may be contained in a Certificate of Incorporation (name change, revision to the purpose clause, etc.).  Please be sure to review Section 804 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law to determine whether any consents or approvals are required.
Filing Fee: $30

Certificate of Amendment, Foreign Not-for-Profit Corporations 
A foreign authorized not-for-profit corporation may amend its Application for Authority from time to time by filing a Certificate of Amendment pursuant to Section 1309 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. The Application for Authority may only be amended to amend or add such provisions that may be lawfully contained in the Application for Authority (i.e., name change, revisions to purposes, etc.). Please review the consent requirements under Section 1309(c) of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.
Filing Fee: $30

Certificate of Amendment, Domestic Limited Liability Companies
A domestic limited liability company may amend its Articles of Organization by filing a Certificate of Amendment pursuant to Section 211 of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law. The Articles of Organization may only be amended to amend or add such provisions that may be lawfully contained in the initial Articles of Organization (i.e., name change, etc.).
Filing Fee: $60

Certificate of Amendment, Foreign Limited Liability Companies 
A foreign authorized limited liability company may amend its Application for Authority by filing a Certificate of Amendment pursuant to Section 804 of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law. The Application for Authority may only be amended to amend or add such provisions that may be lawfully contained in its Application for Authority (i.e., name change, etc.).
Filing Fee: $60

Certificate of Amendment, Domestic Limited Partnerships 
A domestic limited partnership may amend its Certificate of Limited Partnership by filing a Certificate of Amendment pursuant to Section 121-202 of the New York State Revised Limited Partnership Act. The Certificate of Limited Partnership may only be amended to amend or add such provisions that may be lawfully contained in the initial Certificate of Limited Partnership (i.e., name change, admission/withdrawal of a general partner, etc.).
Filing Fee: $60

Permit Description:
A Certificate of Correction may be filed with the New York State Department of State. The types of informalities, errors or defects that may be corrected vary depending on the type of corporation or other business entity. 
 
The completed Certificate of Correction, together with the statutory fee listed below, should be forwarded to the New York State Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231. 
 
Certificate of Correction, Domestic and Foreign Business Corporations 
Any certificate or other instrument may be corrected with respect to any informality or error apparent on the face, incorrect statement or defect in the execution, including the deletion of any matter not permitted to be stated by filing a Certificate of Correction pursuant to Section 105 of the Business Corporation Law. Please review Section 105 of the Business Corporation Law. 
Filing Fee: $60 
 
Certificate of Correction, Domestic Not-for-Profit Corporations 
Any certificate or other instrument may be corrected with respect to any typographical or similar non-material error apparent on the face or defect in the execution, including the deletion of any matter not permitted to be stated.  Please review Section 105 Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. 
Filing Fee: $30 
 
Certificate of Correction, Foreign Not-for-Profit Corporations 
Any certificate or other instrument may be corrected with respect to any typographical or similar non-material error apparent on the face or defect in the execution, including the deletion of any matter not permitted to be stated.  Please review Section 105 Not-for-Profit Corporation Law. 
Filing Fee: $30 
 
Certificate of Correction, Domestic Limited Liability Companies 
Any certificate or other instrument may be corrected with respect to any informality or error apparent on the face, incorrect statement or defect in the execution, including the deletion of any matter not permitted to be stated.  Please review Section 212 of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law. 
Filing Fee: $60 
 
Certificate of Correction, Foreign Limited Liability Companies 
Any certificate or other instrument may be corrected with respect to any informality or error apparent on the face, incorrect statement or defect in the execution, including the deletion of any matter not permitted to be stated. Please review Section 212 of the New York State Limited Liability Company Law. 
Filing Fee: $60
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
Copies of any documents (Certificates of Incorporation, Articles of Organization, Certificates of Amendment, etc.) filed with the Division of Corporations may be obtained by submitting a written request to the New York State Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Albany, NY 12231. The written request should include the following information: 
 
1. The exact name of the corporation or other business entity.   
2. The DOS ID number or the exact date of formation or authorization. 
3. The document(s) requested. 
4. A statement as to whether the request is for plain copies or certified copies. 
5. The mailing address where the copies are to be mailed. 
 
The fee for a plain copy of a document is $5, and the fee for a certified copy of a document is $10. 
 
Copies of documents cannot be ordered through the Department of State’s website, by email or over the telephone. 
 
The Department of State does not provide copies of filing receipts. 
 
The Division of Corporations will accept written requests for copies of documents by fax. Fees for written requests received by fax must be paid using your credit card/debit card. To pay for a fee using your credit card/debit card, simply complete and sign the Credit Card/Debit Card Authorization Form (see link below) and submit it to the Division of Corporations with your written request. Written requests for copies of documents may be faxed to (518) 473-1654. 
 
The large volume of submissions and requests received each day by the Division makes it impracticable for Division staff to verify receipt of individual customer submissions. Please do not call the Division for verification of receipt after submitting a certificate or request by fax. If you do not receive correspondence from our office after a reasonable period of time has elapsed, you may contact the Division at (518) 473-2492 for further instructions. 
 
Please note that copies will be returned by first-class mail. We do not provide these copies by fax. You may request that your copies be returned to you by overnight delivery service by enclosing a prepaid shipping label with your request.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Description:
Article 17 of the Business Corporation Law ("BCL") governs the incorporation and operation of benefit corporations. Business corporations formed as benefit corporations, in addition to business purposes, are formed for the purpose of creating a "general public benefit." BCL §1702(b) provides that a "general public benefit" is a "material positive impact on society and the environment, taken as a whole, assessed against a third-party standard, from the business and operations of a benefit corporation. 

Availability of Name: (optional) In order to assure that the name of the corporation is not already in use by an existing corporation, limited liability company or limited partnership, you may request a name search. The request must be in writing to the Department of State. The search fee for each name submitted is $5.00.

Reservation of Name: (optional) If the name is available, you may reserve it while finalizing your business plans. To reserve the name for 60 days, file an "Application for Reservation of Name". The Department of State will send you a Certificate of Reservation. Attach the Certificate of Reservation to your Certificate of Incorporation when filing. The fee for reservation of name is $20.00.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Name: Dissolution of a New York Not-for-Profit Corporation
Permit Description:
A not-for-profit corporation may be voluntarily dissolved by filing a Certificate of Dissolution pursuant to Section 1003 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.   The form for filing is available on the Department of State's Website (See link below).  Please review Sections 1002 and 1003 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law to determine whether any consents or approvals are required. 
 
Approval of the Attorney General: 
Certificates of dissolution for all charitable corporations, as well as any other corporation that holds assets that are legally required for a particular purpose, require the approval of the Attorney General. You may contact the Attorney General at the Department of Law, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271. Please note that the Attorney General's website also provide instructions for the dissolution of a not-for-profit corporation. See the link below for the website of the Attorney General.  
 
Consent of the State Tax Commission of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance: 
The consent of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance is required for all certificates of dissolution.  See Section 1004 of the Not-for-Profit Corporation Law.  The telephone number, fax number, and address to call or write to request the consent is:  Telephone number - (518) 485-2639; Fax number - (518) 435-2997, New York State Tax Department, Corporation Tax Dissolution Unit, Building 8, Room 958, W. A. Harriman Campus, Albany, NY 12227. 
 
Consent of the New York City Department of Finance: 
Consent of the New York City Department of Finance must be attached to the Certificate of Dissolution if the corporation has done business in and incurred tax liability to the City of New York under Chapters 6-8, 10-15, 21, 24-25 or 27 of Title 11 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York. To obtain consent, contact the New York City Department of Finance, Collections Division, Vendor/Tax Clearance Unit, 59 Maiden Lane, 25th Floor, New York, NY 10038. Additional information is available on the New York City Department of Finance’s website at the link below.  
 
Filing with the Department of State: 
The completed certificate of dissolution, with the statutory filing fee of $30 should be forwarded to the New York State Department of State, Division of Corporations, One Commerce Plaza, 99 Washington Avenue, Suite 600, Albany, NY 12231.
Permit Categories: Legal Structures

Permit Name: Retail Requirements for Environmental Conservation Laws
Permit Description:
Many retail stores sell products or conduct operations that may have impacts on the environment and in many cases it is their responsibility to ensure that this impact is managed appropriately and minimized where possible. Because of these potential impacts, NY State has enacted a number of environmental laws that affect retail stores. We have summarized these laws for you to assist in responding to complaints and inspections. Please see the links below for a number of NY State's Environmental Conservation Laws (ECL) that impact retailers.

There are a number of additional ECL laws that impact retailers relative to the products they may sell that are not listed here. These include laws on Ewaste, hazardous packaging, bisphenol A contained in children’s toys, products containing brominated flame retardants and pesticides. For additional information on these requirements please contact NY State's Department of Environmental Conservation's Division of Materials Management.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits,Licenses and Permits, Retail

Permit Description: If you sell motor vehicles, motor vehicle parts, or motor vehicle accessories, your sales are subject to sales tax. If you maintain, service, repair, or install tangible personal property in or on motor vehicles, the charges for your services (your sales) are subject to sales tax. As a result, you must register for sales tax, collect sales tax, and report your sales as instructed on your New York State sales tax returns.

Permit Description:
Businesses that rent motor vehicles must collect sales tax.
 
Businesses must collect an additional 6% state-only tax on a short-term rental (less than one year) of a passenger car rented within New York State, or rented outside of the state for use within the state.

In addition to the statewide 6% state-only tax, there is an additional 5% special supplemental tax of a passenger car rented within the metropolitan commuter transportation district (MCTD), or rented outside the MCTD for use within the MCTD.

Permit Name: Application to become a Licensed Transportation Network Company (TNC) in New York State or renew/update TNC license
Permit Description: NYS Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) is regulating the operation of TNCs and these companies must be licensed by submitting an application to the DMV. Once licensed, the TNC must apply to the License Event Notification System (LENS) and enroll their drivers in the system. Once enrolled in LENS, drivers can conduct Ridesharing in approved areas of New York State.

Permit Name: Alcoholic Beverage Wholesale and Importer Licenses
Permit Description: Beer Wholesaler (CO 105):Allows a person to sell beer to NYS licensed beer wholesalers and retailers (grocery stores, bars, restaurants etc.) from a premises located in New York State which is used solely for such purposes. ABC Law Sections 53 and 104. Requires a $10,000 bond. Please see the associated license fees. Beer Wholesaler (C 103): Allows a person to sell beer to NYS licensed beer wholesalers and retailers (grocery stores, bars, restaurants etc.) from a New York State which is used solely for such purposes. These licensed businesses also may operate as a "beverage center" selling beer for off-premises consumption to the general public. However, the law does not allow new licenses of this type to be issued, so a business with existing license will need to be purchased and the license transferred to the buyer’s name. ABC Law Sections 53 and 104. Requires a $10,000 bond. Please see the associated license fees. Cider Wholesaler (CD 304): Allows a person to sell cider to NYS licensed cider wholesalers and retailers (grocery/drug stores, liquor/wine stores, bars, restaurants etc.) from a New York State office solely used for such purposes. ABC Law Sections 58 and 104. Requires a $1,000 bond. Please see the associated license fees. Wine Wholesaler (WW 303): Allows a person to sell wine and wine products to NYS licensed wine wholesalers and retailers (liquor/wine stores, bars, restaurants etc.) and wine products to grocery stores from a New York State office solely used for such purposes. ABC Law Sections 78 and 104. Requires a $10,000 bond. Please see the associated license fees. Liquor Wholesaler (LL 203): Allows a person to sell liquor, wine and wine products to NYS licensed liquor/wine wholesalers and retailers (liquor/wine stores, bars, restaurants etc.) and wine products to grocery stores from a New York State office solely used for such purposes. ABC Law Sections 62 and 104. Requires a $20,000 bond. Please see the associated license fees. Importer (IL 208): Allows a person to import alcohol into NYS and sell such alcohol to NYS licensed wholesalers authorized to sell such alcoholic beverages. ABC Law Section 61-b. Please see the associated license fees. Wholesale Cider (BC 104): Allows Wholesale Beer licensees to sell cider to NYS licensed cider wholesalers and retailers (grocery/drug stores, liquor/wine stores, bars, restaurants etc.). ABC Law Section 58-a. Please see the associated license fees.
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits, Wholesale

Permit Description:
Hotel: Allows a person to serve alcoholic beverages in a hotel for on premises consumption. A hotel is a building regularly used for the feeding and lodging of guests. The hotel must have a kitchen and full restaurant operating within the premises. The sale of unopened beer to go is allowed. This license is also available seasonally.
  • Hotel Beer (HB 142): ABC Law Sections 3(14), 55 and 106.
  • Hotel Wine (HW 342): ABC Law sections 3(14), 81 and 106.
  • Hotel Liquor (HL 242): ABC Law sections 3(14), 64 and 106.
Restaurant Wine (RW 341): Allows a person to serve beer, wine and cider in a restaurant for on premises consumption. The restaurant must have a kitchen and full menu. The sale of unopened beer to go is allowed. ABC Law Sections 3(27), 81 and 106. This license is also available seasonally. Tavern Wine (TW 344): Allows a person to serve beer, wine and cider in a tavern for on premises consumption. A tavern must have, at minimum, a food preparation area and menu satisfying the Authority’s minimum food requirement. The sale of unopened beer to go is allowed. ABC Law Sections 81-a and 106. This license is also available seasonally. On Premises (OP 252): Allows a person to serve beer, wine, liquor and cider in a restaurant or tavern for on premises consumption. If applying for a restaurant you must have a kitchen and full menu. If applying for a tavern you must at least have a food preparation area and menu satisfying the Authority’s minimum food requirement. The sale of unopened beer to go is allowed. ABC Law Sections 64 (restaurant), 64-a (tavern) and 106. This license is also available seasonally. Eating Place Beer (EB 141): Allows a person to serve beer and cider in a restaurant or tavern for on premises consumption. The sale of unopened beer to go is allowed. ABC Law sections 55 and 106. This license is also available seasonally. Ball Park Beer (BP 144): Allows a person to serve beer in baseball parks, race tracks and other athletic fields or stadiums where admission fees are charged. ABC Law Sections 55-a and 106. Catering Establishment: Allows a person to serve alcoholic beverages in their rentable banquet venue for private events only. The premises is never open to the general public. Such premises must have suitable and adequate facilities and accommodations to provide food and service for not less than fifty persons. This license is also available seasonally.
  • Catering Establishment Wine (WC 354): ABC Law Sections 3(7-a), 81 and 106.
  • Catering Establishment Liquor (CT 246): ABC Law Sections 3(7-a), 64 and 106.
Club (Members Only): Allows the service of alcoholic beverages by a not for profit corporation or fraternal organization in a premises for exclusive club purposes. The service of alcoholic beverages is for members and their guests only. This license is also available seasonally.
  • Club Beer (CB 143): ABC Law Sections 3(9), 55 and 106.
  • Club Wine (CW 343): ABC Law Sections 3(9), 81 and 106.
  • Club Liquor (CL 243): ABC Law Sections 3(9), 64 and 106.
Restaurant Brewer (MR 210): Allows a person to brew beer on the premises as well as operate a bona fide restaurant serving beer, wine, liquor and cider. The premises must have a kitchen and full menu. A person may operate up to five separate locations, and may produce 5,000 barrels of beer per location, not to exceed 20,000 barrels in total for all locations. ABC Law Sections 64-c and 106. Supplemental Restaurant Brewer (MR 910): Allows a person holding a Restaurant Brewer’s license to sell beer brewed on the licensed premises at retail to a person for consumption in his home, in
Permit Categories: Licenses and Permits, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Christmas Tree Farm,Licenses and Permits, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Farm Products Dealer,Licenses and Permits,

Permit Description: Grocery Store Beer (A 122): Allows a person to sell beer and cider for off premises consumption from a premises being operated as a grocery store. More than 50% of the retail floor space must be devoted to the sale of grocery items. Candy, carbonated beverages and snacks (such as chips) are not deemed to be groceries. ABC Law Sections 54, 59 and 105-a. Grocery Store Beer and Wine Products (AX 122): Allows a person to sell beer, cider and wine products for off premises consumption from a premises being operated as a grocery store. More than 50% of the retail floor space must be devoted to the sale of grocery items. Candy, carbonated beverages and snacks (such as chips) are not deemed to be groceries. ABC Law Sections 54-a, 59 and 105-a. Drug Store Beer (DS 121): Allows a person to sell beer and cider for off premises consumption from a premises being operated as a New York State licensed drug store. ABC Law Sections 54, 59 and 105-a. Drug Store Beer and Wine Products (DX 122): Allows a person to sell beer, cider and wine products for off premises consumption from a New York State licensed drug store. ABC Law Sections 54-a, 59 and 105-a. Wine Store (W 322): Allows a person to sell wine and cider for off premises consumption from a premises solely devoted to do so. Only one license of this type will be issued to any person. ABC Law Sections 59, 79 and 105. Liquor Store (L 222): Allows a person to sell wine, liquor and cider for off premises consumption from a premises solely devoted to do so. Only one license of this type will be issued to any person. ABC Law Sections 59, 63 and 105. Roadside Farm Market (RS 130): Allows a person to sell wine for off premises consumption from a roadside farm market being operated on a farm. May sell wine manufactured by two (2) licensed farm, special or micro wineries within twenty miles of the roadside farm market. ABC Law Section 76-f. Beer Vendor (E-120): Allows a person located in cities of one (1) million or more to sell beer at retail to be delivered to an individual for off premises consumption from their licensed premises. No in person retail sales shall occur from the licensed premises. The vendor may operate one vehicle for the delivery of beer. No beer shall be sold for resale. ABC Law Section 53-a. Please see the Retail Fee Chart.

Permit Description:
Prepaid wireless services You are a prepaid wireless communications seller if you make retail sales of prepaid wireless communications services. Prepaid wireless communications services include:
  • mobile phones or mobile phone cards preloaded with a set dollar amount or number of minutes, and
  • reloading mobile phones or mobile phone cards with additional minutes.
Visit the Tax Department's website through the link below to learn more about the surcharge imposed on prepaid wireless communications services. Postpaid wireless services You are a postpaid wireless communications service supplier if you:
  • are a facilities-based carrier or a reseller;
  • provide wireless communications services to customers on a recurring basis or pursuant to a contract; and
  • have one or more wireless communications customers in New York State.
Wireless communications services include all commercial mobile services which offer real-time, two-way voice or data service that is interconnected with the public switched telephone network or otherwise provides access to emergency communications services. Visit the Tax Department's website through the link below to learn more about the surcharge imposed on postpaid wireless communications services.
Permit Categories: Tax Information

Permit Name: New York State Paid Family Leave
Permit Description: In April 2016, Governor Cuomo signed the nation’s strongest and most comprehensive Paid Family Leave policy into law. Under New York State’s Paid Family Leave, employers will be able to provide employees with paid time off to care for loved ones through an insurance program fully funded by employee contributions. Beginning January 1, 2018, employees will be able to take job-protected, paid leave to: • Bond with a newly born, adopted or fostered child; • Care for a family member with a serious health condition; or • Assist loved ones when a family member is deployed abroad on active military service. Businesses play an important role in implementing Paid Family Leave. Please visit ny.gov/PaidFamilyLeave to learn how Paid Family Leave works and access important information and resources specifically for employers. If you have questions, contact the Paid Family Leave helpline at 844-337-6303.
